Originally reviewed: 4/7/10. 12oz bottle poured into a pilsner glass. Pours a dark tawny brown with some ruby highlights at the edges. A massive beige head billows out. Great retention; left lost of sticky lace in its wake. Scents of plums, currants, wood, booze, and some roasted malts. Nice. 

The body on this is much thinner than Id like. Carbonation level is low. This feels flat and unimpressive. The flavors are malty in character. Some roasted malts at the onset, but then this gives way to a dark fruity flavor, and finishes with some alcohol heat. All in all, I did not care for this beer. I know its one of the top 100 beers, but I have had better of the style for sure. Wont have this again most likely.

Bottle 330ml.
Pours brown/red, with ok beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of caramel, dark fruits, roasted malt, molasses. Taste is of roasted malt, dark fruits, molasses. Good balance. Surprisingly thin considering aroma. Refreshing and very drinkable. Very good beer.

Pours dark brown with medium beige head and a god lasting lacing. The aroma is great, very complex and well balanced: malt, honey, vanilla, caramel, dark fruit, among others. Maybe a little thin on the texture, but overall it is a very great beer that anyone might enjoy!
Robe brun foncé, avec un collet moyen beige. Arôme diversifié et bien balancé: malt, miel, vaille, caramel, fruits noirs, entre autres.Goûte ce quelle sent, mais en un peu moins intense. Un peu mince en bouche, mais cest là un bien maigre défaut pour cette excellente bière!

Bottle 330 ml. Pours brown with some reddish reflects. Small brown head and a good lacing. Powerful complex aroma with strong notes of malt, molasse, caramel, toffee, honey, dark fruits. Taste is the same as aroma, but less powerful. Theres also slight smoke notes. Medium to full body. Overall, this beer is amazing. Great nose and marvelous balance in the taste. Great all-around complexity. Also very drinkable for this type of beer.
Smooth, smoky, complex maltiness, and easy on palate. Phenomenal beer for newbies and seasoned beer drinkers.

Apariencia: color marrón muy oscuro, casi negro y casi opaco, un poco traslúcido, reflejos rojizos, poro carbónico, corona medio dedo, persistente, consistencia media, Color hueso. 
Aroma: poco intenso, dulce y maltoso, pasas, ciruelas, higos. 
Sabor: intensidad y cuerpo medios, apenas se nota el carbónico. Primera sensación de marcado carácter maltoso, dulce pero no exagerado, nada amarga, con bastantes matices a frutos secos, almendras, nueces. Retrogusto muy largo un poco seco y ahumado, notas de vainilla. Alcohol muy bien integrado. 
Es una cerveza muy equilibrada, pero sobre todo, creo que lo que la define perfectamente es sutil, es muy redonda, fácil de beber, nada extrema, pero con muchos matices. Extraordinaria.

Bottle as Ayinger Winter Bock. Very dark brown with medium beige head. Aroma is light roasted malts, caramel, dark fruits and nutty. Flavour is light roasted malts, caramel, medium sweet, dark fruits, nutty, little chocolate and a little bitter.

My first review of 2010 and my eighth Doppelbock review on BA (back then).

Brown 33cl bottle poured into a Westmalle chalice, Bockbier meets Trappist!

Lovely dark colour, a ruby red when held to the sunlight. A wispy tan coloured covering soon fell away to a small collar and occasional bubble.

Toasted, roasted malts fill your nose, I have a cold today, so cant pick anything else up on the smell front.

Bitter-sweet malts in the taste, dark coffee with demerara sugar. Add a full carbonisation and the beer comes alive in your mouth. The alcohol comes into play as the mouth drys and you can really feel its effect between sips.

I am a big fan of Bocks and Doppelbocks, this is at the top of the tree, or very close, up there is the Korbinian.
great aroma, roast finish, full body complex malt with coffee, sweet flavors and beautiful head. No very hoppy, good balance without strong alcohol flavor
Yeah, really good one although Im not a devoted fan of Doppelbocks... You should give it a try.

Dark. Low carbonation with a fizzy head. Tasted a bit like black liquorish to me. Perhaps figs and raisins. 

Bottle from wine expo

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an ominous crimson without much clarity with a short-lived finger of tan head. Perfect lacing and beading.

The nose features heavy malted wheat, toffee, brown sugar, simple syrup, very inviting.

Taste is equally inviting and approachable - oats, wheat, hard water, brown sugar, very clean. Some grassy hop bits, smooth and easy.

Very drinkable, well done brew. A perfect hint of bitterness lingers on.

Overall, this beer defines its style. Drinkable but exciting, smooth but aggressive.
UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Bottle from Meinbiershop (BBE 7/11). Deep dark brown colour with medium head. Aroma is roast, sweet. Flavour is sweet, roasted malt.
A great doublebock.  Big creamy head, sweet and malty and balanced.  Some notes of dates and maybe chocolate(?) but just enough hops to smooth out the finish.  Mouthfeel is silky and slightly thick.

500ml bottle [Winter-Bock]. Clear deep reddish dark brown with creamy beige head. Dark malty, minimal roasty aroma, decent sweetness, a hint of oak. Smooth palate. Well balanced taste, hop bitterness contributes lightness to the sweet malt basis. Some roast notes, also leather. Very good.

Deep dark pour with a huge creamy head.  Aroma of roast & grain.  Thick mouth.  Sweet flavor, but the sweetness is washed away at the end.  Incredibly balanced.  This beer is delicious.  Great roasty after taste.
A great german dopplebock that has the true characters of the style.  And you even get a little ornament too!
Love this beer.  Big chocolate, light mouthfeel, paired great with some braised short ribs I had...
Potent double....great finish leaving you a nice gift to remember it by. Comes with an award for finishing it.
Really wonderful beer. Smooth, still strong malty taste, fruity but not too sweet aroma.

A: Pours a dark yet lustrous ruby color, with a one finger off white head with unimpressive retention/lacing.

S: Rich dark fruit combined with some dark chocolate and a bit of licorice. An excellent smell.

T: Not quite as impressive as the smell would let on, but its still excellent, for the most part. Theres dark fruit, some caramel, toffee, chocolate, and licorice. All told, its pretty complex and flavorful - but I think that the chocolate flavors clash with the malt base a little more than they should. ABV is well hidden.

M: It has a medium-to-slightly-heavy body with high carbonation - though perhaps less smoothness than Id like. Also has a somewhat brief, fleeting finish.

O: The way I see it, if this is like a brilliant painting of the Last Supper, then Troegs Troegenator is like an ordinary but well executed painting of Monica Belucci - I can really appreciate the artful precision that went into making this, but Id take the Monica Belucci painting instead. Likewise, though it isnt as complex as Celebrator, Id rather have Troegenator. Dont get me wrong, though, this is a great beer either way.

On tap, Ayingers Speis und Trank. Clear brown-amber dark body. Thick off white head. Lovely, full soft malty nose, light coffee and orange. Creamy raosty malty taste, softr again, weak notes of orange again, ends in bitter hopiness. Slightly warming but no real notes of alcohol, which is quite cool. Yeah, definitely a very good beer!
Ayinger best and the best doppelbock Ive ever had. In the words of Stan Lee "nough said"

Bottle to a pint glass.  Pours a rich brown with limited head.  Lot of fruit on the nose with some roasted/toasty malts.  Nice mix between sweet and dry.  really well put together beer.  Best brew Ive had from Germany.

From notes: Poured a nice, nutty brown with a small tan head.  Aroma was caramelly and somewhat roasty, maybe some nuttiness too.  Medium-thick, with a nice depth.  Sweet, roasted malt flavor, with nutty and caramelly notes in the finish.  Very good.

Ayinger Celebrator has a medium, beige head and a clear, black (ruby-red under light) appearance, with some tiny streaming bubbles and a bit of lacing. Aroma is slight, but one detects some dark fruit and cola. Taste is strongly dark cherry and a touch of malt. Some mild bitterness is present at the back end. Mouthfeel is surprisingly light and watery, and Ayinger Celebrator finishes crisp, clean, and somewhat dry. Overall, this is a fantastic beer, and one of the best Ive ever had the privilege to sample. RJT

Im transcribing notes I had written, which were scribbled in my notebook, so theyre incomplete.

-- Delicious. Deep brown, tan head. Many flavors : caramel, toasted biscuit, sugar, dark fruit, brown bread. Smooth, not too boozy. Yum. --

330 ml bottle poured into an imperial pint glass.  Pours a very dark brown with mahogany hints capped by a light tan/off white head, slightly less than 1 finger.  Smells of prunes, figs, bready, roasty, slight alcohol, slight chocolate and coffee.  Tastes of chocolate, caramel, prunes, dark fruit, and finishes with a very slight alcohol warmth.  Not overly sweet, fairly dry finish, medium carbonation and a very smooth texture.  Very complex and yet very approachable.  Ive drinking this beer for years and I still believe it is the epitome of the Dopplebock style.  Delicious.

Bottle as Ayinger Winter Bock, velke Dekuji goes to pivnizub. This was my big want. Dark mahogany color with medium beige head. Earthy aroma with, caramel, roasted malt, molasses, dark berries. Taste, nice bittersweet with prunes, dark berries, milk chocolate, bread, caramel. Dry bittersweet finish. Nice.
.
UPDATED: AUG 31, 2012 Jus de pruneaux légèrement fumé avec un corps lourdement caramélisé. Une agréable présence des houblons floraux vient également simposer.
Dark rich color with red tinges. I actually find it a milder doppelbock than most. Not very strong at all.

Smells like spoiled milk, tastes like Copenhagen snuff tobacco. I must not be sophisticated enough. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle, dark brown-ruby color, with some reddish highlights, and a beige-kaki head, sweet toasted, biscuity, caramel, bready, dark malt, fruity nose, with a fruitcake, toffee, dried fig, raisin, light chocolate note, and with some cereal breadiness, bran muffin, molasses, date square, graham cracker accents in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet grainy toasted, biscuity, caramelizes, bready, chocolate maltiness character, with some molasses, mild coffeeish, fruitcake,bran muffin, date square, dried fig, raisin fruitiness, bready cereal, light dark chocolate flavours, with a graham cracker, faint burnt toast undertone, leading towards a sweet maltiness, light chocolatey, dried fig fruitiness, molasses, faint lingering roasty bitterness finish.
Deep ruby brown with a thick tan head. Smells of roasted malts, brown sugar, dates, and figs. The taste starts with malty, heavy sweetness and a bit too sweet for my taste.

Bottle. Thanks beerandbeyond. Clear dark brown with minimal tan foam. Prunes, raisins, chocolate aroma. Fruity taste - a little sweet and a little metallic. Full body with an abrupt alcoholic finish and soft carbonation. All in all a good, balanced beer.

330mL from LCBO. Poured cellar temp, a translucent dark reddish brown with an inch of bubbly tan head that receded rapidly. Aroma complex, dark sugary and toasted malts, nutty, dark plummy fruit, a bit of yeasty bread. Flavour surprisingly dry but still malty, toffee and caramel with roasty nuts and some red fruit. Chocolate malts come in on the finish, quite dry, a little woody and not strong in alcohol with mild hop bitterness on the finish. Mouthfeel is fairly full and creamy with soft carbonation. Fairly complex but particularly well-balanced and very drinkable doppelbock.

[355ml bottle, Appellation Wines, Edinburgh] Pours a lovely deep russet brown, large peaky white head. Really complex nose  caramel, toasted nuts, peanut brittle, a touch of marzipan  the aroma changes every time you go back for another sniff. Rich on the palate, it tastes far stronger than the abv, particularly when the deep, sticky finish arrives. Sweet caramel and toffee is the predominant flavour  the fact that theres little alcohol on the palate I found really positive, so many beers like this (from the US, mostly) pile on the booze and it rounds out the flavour  Celebrator has a much more complex finish. For that (and the plastic goat), I really like it [09032012]
Pours a deep reddish black. Aroma of dark roasted malt   Taste is very malty but without being too sweet.  Very balanced. Smooth. Classic representation of the double bock style.

Bottle. Pours a dark mahogany brown color with a tan head. Aroma is of toasted malts, nuts, caramel, toffee, dark bread, brown sugar and dark fruit. Flavor follows the nose, lots of caramel and brown sugar, kind of taste like a Hvidtøl, dark bread, toffee, nuts and the dark fruit. The body is medium with a kind of creamy mouth feel. Overall probably the best Doppelbock I have had.

Chocolatey and delicious.  Beer pours a deep dark brown, not much head to speak of.  Taste is heavy on the chocolate malt but a nice touch of smokiness as well.  Goes down smooth as can be.  Really great beer.
Appearance is a small brown head and brown color. Aroma is a sweet chocolate. Taste is some chocolate malt, but with some tart and alcohol. Overall not my favorite.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2015 33cl bottle. Pours opaque black with a red hue and a generous head. The nose has toffee and biscuits. The taste has biscuits, toffee and a ginger note. The palate is medium to full bodied with a creamy texture and a bitter finish. Overall, not as excited about this as I thought I would be.
An interesting beer, lots of raisin flavors and roasty malt. Good to give it a try, probably wouldnt become a staple.

Dark black and red with a medium tanned head (not very stable). Roasty and sweet smell. Fruity, sweet, light bitterness, vanilla, malt, berries, a bit caramel. not to sweet for a doppelbock. full body. interesting and nice.
Pours a dark brown. Lots of malt flavour. Dark and rich, but easy drinking.
Aroma is has a nutty quality to it. Big malt richness in the mouth. The most impressive thing is the smoothness. Silky quality to the taste with a very mild hint of spice from the alcohol. Tasty!

Carmel and Creaminess. Tastes sugary but not too sweet and maintains a nice balanced taste throughout. Almost tastes as if there is a raison note to it. Great beer with a kick...Make it BIGGER Ayinger...11.2 oz come on now.

Bottle from Great Grog, Edinburgh
Dark ruby brown...clear...thin white head that dissipates to rim around glass..nice bottle  
Aroma - dark rich malts...dark fruits...raisins...light nuts...smooth 
Taste - dark caramel malts...soft roasted malts...dark fruits...rich dark malts...bit of soft treacle and soft dark toffee...some bitter hops in the background...mainly dark malty...quite a complex malt flavour...luxuriant and mellow flavour 
Palate - soft to medium carb...medium to full body..dark bit treacle fruity malts...very smooth
Finish - as main flavour with dark soft rich malty finish with a light roasted bitterness 
Overall - This is a lovely smooth malty beer - really mellow and very good

A long strong and robust head contrasting with a complex looking molasses like beer.  Upon the first sip you will be guessing what all you are drinking, but enjoy and let it over take you.  Rich spices, rich malts, rich flavor.

Bottle.
Deep brown brew with lots of creamy tan head.  Nose of dark fruit, sugar sweetness, and tons of malt.  Flavors of brown sugar, dates, dates, and some chocolate.  Amazing.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/25/2010.  Poured from a 330 mL bottle into a tulip.

Celebrator has a  dark mahogany color with a fair amount of room for ruby to peer through in more narrow parts of the glass. A dark copper color sneaks into the very edge of the glass.

A very smooth aroma with components that work well together. Soft sweet molasses, some dates and spicy, herbal hoppy notes. Sweet bready notes round things out.

Chewy caramel malt flavor starts out the flavor, followed with a touch of molasses, then some spiced bread as the body fills out in my mouth. Some dates step in before a touch of herbal bitterness sets in for a second. The end of the sip approaches, telling the grain and sweetness to wrap up the show in a polite fashion. Finishes clean and a touch sweet. 

This is an absolute perfect feel. I can feel the little bubbles actually raise up off of my tongue, keeping it fresh for the next sip. Creamy, medium bodied. Sexy.

Im not ordinarily a Doppelbock drinker, but this is just phenomenal. Extraordinarily happy to have finally tried this.

From the LCBO, pours a dark brown to black with a nice tan creamy head. Caramel, chocolate, nuts, bread all hit the nose.  Very lively, on the palate, creamy and bubbly.  Sweet and strong flavoured, with a subtle alcohol note.  Fantastic beer. More please.

Pours a very dark brown with a tan head. Drank on draught from a snifter, aroma of malts and roasted malts. Very full bodied with a big roasty malt taste and nice on the palate. Notes of fruits under the malts and maybe some hops. A world class beer.

Dark brown/mahogany (almost black) with a full creamy tan-light brown head, decent carbonation, and clumpy lace. Big malty aroma -- coffeeish and almost chocolatey. Big malty coffee-ish flavor dominates with dark fruitiness noticeable. Full bodied, rich and creamy.

pours very dark brown with a nice beige head, nice retention/lacing. roasted malts, caramel, raisins, figs, sweetness, never cloying, currants, light acidity, pepper - complex aromas. soft carbonation, medium to full body, short to medium grassy finish. of course... its more than nice here...

Bottle from Stirchley Wines. World famous, long anticipated. Malty, drinkable. Some sweetness, a smidge of warmth. Very easy to swig, with a pretty short finish. This is great and supremely balanced, but Im used to more flavour. Probably my problem, not this beers. I like the smoke and I could picture myself necking a 4-pack of this, not that I have necked a 4-pack of anything during the last 10 years.

Hazy cola looking beer with a puffy, white head. Aromas of caramel, and some hops. Tastes strongly of caramel, butterscotch, toffee, and some nutty flavors. Chewy, yet very smooth. A very nice smoky aftertaste is present in the finish, and something that reminds me of bacon. Extremely delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 Denso color mogano con una schiuma beige parecchio persistente. Aroma di frutta secca e cereali tostati; gusto morbido e avvolgente di noci e nocciole con tocchi di caramello, retrogusto lievemente tostato. Al palato è ricca e corposa ma va giù che è un piacere, alla spina ha una struttura apparentemente più cremosa. Notevole.

Pours a deep brown colour with a big light beige creamy head, that stays long and gives out thick wavy lacing. Dark fruit nose with plums, raisins and caramel malt in the background... so very sweet. Smooth silky mouthfeel with a medium-light body. The fruits is present in the taste, but milder with some roasted malts and notes of coffee showing up in aftertaste. Nicely brewed and quite smooth for a Doppelbock.
Stupid good. Great look, rich creamy head and a fantastic palate and finish. One of my favs. The charm is a nice touch too
Aroma of fruit, malts and toffee. Taste of the same with a great smooth, creaminess. Very little bitterness. Goes down nice. Had to stop myself from pounding it. Hard to put down.
From a 50 cl bottle. Dark brown beer with a tanned head. Caramell and malty aroma. Malty and sweet caramell flavour with a bit smokeyness.

12oz bottle pours deep brown with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet, malty and yeast.  Taste caramel, coffee and a subtle sweetness .  Very nice beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location/Date:Bottle split with Ben M-L on February 14, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark with light red head.
Aroma: Aroma is of caramel malt.
Taste: Malty, a little smoky, and sweet from caramel.
Palate:Smooth, light body.
Summary: Second time Ive had this, but first rating, really enjoyed this beer a lot. Malt-forward, not too bad in alcohol percentage, enjoyable.

Bottle from Davis Coop. Aroma was of light, sweet malt and fruitiness. Flavor was ramped up fruitiness, floral hoppiness, and full-flavored smoky caramel. Really surprising from a dopplebock, as it is completely different than most. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle; dark red to black with small beige head; aroma-caramel, roasty, coffee, fruits; taste-medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, creamy, average carbonation. Very good.

Bottle. The best double bock out there. And you get a little plastic goat to hang somewhere odd. Im all about beers that come with a trinket of some type. The pour was a velvety dark brown, way darker than Troegenator or other double bocks, with a decent size head, half inch or so, that faded to a white ring. The scent was a malty caramel with hints of resin, and the heavy palate had a creamy texture that set it off nicely from the body. The taste was a strong biting malt that settled into more of a cereal and fruit noted flavor with a alcohol woody aftertaste. Even though this is 6.7%, I still cellared one. I think a year of age will bring down the aftertaste a little and boost the malt complexities. Well see. At the very least, Ill have another little plastic goat to play with.
Bottle. Pours deep dark brown with a frothy tan head. Looks incredible! Smells so malty and bready. Sweet malt and nut flavor with very smooth finish. Lives up to the hype.
Bottle. Pours dark red/brown with a beige head. Aroma of sweet malt and caramel. Flavour is complex - sugary raisins, plums with a slight hoppy bitterness to balance. A good clean finish. Very good.

The worlds best doppel according to ratebeer, though not all may agree.  Rich looking dark brown, though visibly lively. Massive roasted malt aroma and smokiness as well. Very sweet syrupy taste with a bitter finish. Thick, oily, and lacy. Combines the standards of heavy bock beer with elements of porter and rauchbier. Thats my two cents to add to the hundred dollar discussion.

What can I say that has not already been said? Nose is immediate sweet, sugary caramel malts, bread, nuts, and roast complexities. Flavor is sweet nutty malts with again pleasant smooth roastiness. Medium light bitterness but sweet finish. Medium full body. Nice one.
Amazing balance of malt and hop yet very smooth.  Alcohol flavor comes thru but not overpowering.

Celebrator pours a dark mahogany color with a two finger, creamy, tan head.  Lacing throughout the glass.  Smell is fantastic.  Sweet up front.  Molasses and dark fruits.  The backend has a nice bready malt aroma.   Not an overpowering aroma, just really nice. 

Taste is even better.  Once again its sweet but not overpowering.  Maybe just right.  Mixture of dark fruits, molasses, cherries, and the bready malt character.  Leaves a slight bitter aftertaste.

Mouthfeel is more on the heavy side and was chewy.  Goes down nice though.  Really smooth and creamy on the palette.
Fantastisk bock øl, der bliver brygget tæt på Øllens hovedstad. Hvis man så samtidig drikker på en lokal beværtning, så er det næsten helt i top, hvis man kan lide denne type øl

bottle.  Poured an opaque chocolate with ruby hue. Creamy beige head. Dark roasty fruit aroma. The mouthfeel is smooth and medium bodied, very drinkable.  Flavour of roasted malt, a bit smokey, a little molasses and dark fruit. Lots of flavour but not too heavy or too dry, and the alcohol is subdued.  Me likey.

Bottle (as Winter Bock). A clear dark red-brown colour with a medium high, frothy, light brown head. An aroma of roasted malt, caramel, coffee and yeast. The taste is medium sweet and light bitter. A medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a medium long duration. A nice, well balanced beer.

Pours dark brown, almost black with a small head. Dark malts make the nose caramel and chocolate. Big sugary nose. Taste is a tad bitter with a good sweet balance. Mouthfeel is creamy and a decent aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ruby/copper color with a thin tan head. Aroma of berries, malt, a bit caramel. Well balanced beer with a dry finish. Huge use of hops which gives this beer a pleasant bitter note, which doesnt disturb
Bottle. Muddy broon. Tan head. Dried raisiny goodness. Sweet. Light bitterness. Frankly delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2012 Wonderful complexity-- Caramel, Dates and a hint of sour cherry.
Slight alcohol burn as the 6.8% flexes its muscles.  Great doppelbock!
Poured very dark with little head. Very smooth and rich taste. Very enjoyable beer. Only my second dopplebock.

Ive saved my 100th rating for one that all of you tell me I would like.  I finally got a chance to try it, and my only complaint is what to do with the white plastic goat hanging of each bottle.  This one pours a very dark brown with a persistent dark beige head and some lacing.  I thought I could detect milk chocolate, molasses, caramel,  and vanilla in the aroma.  Very creamy texture and a sweet taste with a pleasant short finish.   Ive tried several other doppelbocks but this is clearly my favorite of a favorite style.
Pours a deep black with off white head. Aroma is sweet, and rich. Wonderful. Flavor is full of chocolate. Truly orgasmic.
Bottle. Very dark amber with a thin head. Aroma is sugary malt with cyrup. Sweet malty taste with caramel.
330ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is tar and raisin malt.  Taste has smoky raisin to start.  Light smoked, Tarry malt finish.

Bottle purchased at the Dundas LCBO. Pours a dark ass brown/ black, with a fast acting head that floats up huge then calms down to a perfect ring. Surprisingly no lacing left behind. Smells like a malt bomb, that is super sweet too. A little boozy alcohol smell as well. Taste is sweet malt, a little bitter that subsides rather quick. More malt on the tongue in the finish. Really nice stuff.

3 finger beige head that reduces to 5 mm, brown-black body with a tint of red. Nose: Dates, weak coffee and milk-chocolate. Aroma: Dates, milk-chocolate, prunes, nuts, roasted malt, the slighest hint of coffee and licorice 8way back in the after-taste). Smooth and silky mouthfeel.
Bottle with the goat charm to a dimpled mug.  Pours very dark, nearly black with small tan head.  Bready malt and dark fruits.  Typically sweet, but very well balanced.  A fine beer.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2012 Rerate: Pours very dark brown..almost black...off white head dissipates fairly quickly. Aromas include molasses and malty grains. Great thick and silky mouthfeel. Strong molasses and honey on the tongue..malty, sweet, so good.

500ml Bottle of the Winter-Bock.  Appearance is dark brown/black color with medium, beige head.  Aroma is thick with sweet and roast malts, some chocolate.  Taste is powerful with loads of caramel sweetness, roasted grains, dark chocolate, and subtle floral hops.  Palate is full-bodied, soft and slick texture, average carbonation, and a sweet finish.  Definitely a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2013 Tap pours dark red brown, almost black with tall foamy khaki head. The nose is mild, soft chocolaty roasted grains. The taste is immaculate, particularly cold. Loads of grain with a smooth creamy mouth feel make it go down in large gulps. There is some chocolate and a touch of dark fruit, cherries and grapes, but this is one of those that is just so near perfection I don?t look to hard, I just enjoy it. I must add that out of the bottle is good but doesn?t match the feel of the tap.
This is honestly one of my favorite beers. While it is a dark beer, and I know that turns some people off, it has a rather sweet after taste that is very pleasant.

Amber/brown pour, 1 1/2 finger of head.  Aroma of dark fruits, malty, molasses, caramel.  Figs, dried dark fruit, molasses, caramel.  Highly enjoyable, especially with a good schnitzel!  Fairly thick, very very smooth.
Really wonderful beer. Smooth, still strong malty taste, fruity but not too sweet aroma.

Pours a dark but clear amber/brown with a medium size head. Smell is coffee, cocoa, sweet caramels, sugared plums.  Taste is sugared figs, other dark dried fruits, caramel,, cocoa, and so e coffee.  Quite complex.  Much creamier of a texture than I would have anticipated.  Great beer.

500ml Bottle (as Ayinger Winter Bock) - Dark brown with some red tinges and a foamy head. Dried fruit, malt, marzipan and some ash in the aroma. Fruity, malty, smoky and slightly tangy taste with notes of raisins, sultanas, fruitcake and ash. The finish is fruity and slightly sweet.

From a 11.2 oz bottle (the metric system is the tool of the devil!) into a weizen glass.  Pours a beautiful brown almond color.  A lot of white head with no lacing and no haze on the beer.  Not too much aroma but whats there is very fruity.  Mouthfeel is oily and moderate with plenty of carbonation.  Taste is very Belgian-like without the Belgian funky ness.  Plenty of dark fruit, mild alcohol, bark and some smoke... banana is present too.  Overall, a very tasty beer.

This is my favorite beer. I love the aroma, smooth texture, rich flavor. Celebrator is the best Doppelbock out there, imo. I dont really understand the the tchotchkes on the neck, but it makes the beer seem more "celebratory".  The best beer!

Bottle at Dans. Aroma of nuttiness, cola, cheese. Complex but not entirely up my street. Taste is interesting too. Very malty - sweet and smooth. Tastes a little like a Rolo - chocolate and caramel. Very little carbonation. Nice.

Bottle at home. Dark velvety brown, medium tan head fades to nothing with very sparse lacing. Nose is big coca-cola malts, chocolate, some vanilla, beautiful but not overpowering. Palate is smooth and sweet, rich chocolate, slightly burnt toffee, an absolute triumph of malts. Finish is slightly smoky, dry, not boozy or sweet which makes it ridiculously drinkable. Fantastic!!

50cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a big brown head. Smells roasted malt. Tastes sweet roasted makt with a similar finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a very dark brown with about 2 fingers of tan head. Aroma seems to be malt oriented. Caramel, dark fermented fruit and some spicy hops. Taste is light bitter. Caramel and coffee. Spicy hops and figs or plums. Medium bodied with an oily texture. Soft carbonation and a long malty finish. Overall, not bad. Not worth the hype but very drinkable.

deep dark brown/black colour, slightly see-through, pours a thin head; a lacing settled on the edges of the glass. the aromas are not that strong but interesting nonetheless. dark bread, rye (and rye pudding), sweet bread, some meatiness and smoke with dark fruit. the taste is extremely well balanced, top-notch. light bitterness makes way for the wide sweetness and there is a lot here to experience and contemplate on. an interesting sourness adds depth to the sweetness and makes the taste complete. the body is pretty light but the steady sparky carbonation and oily/cotton-like texture makes it work well. this beer is well balanced and has a delicate and deep character.

(Flasche) Die Farbe ist ein sehr, sehr dunkles Braun, anscheinend klar filtriert mit einem hellbraunen Schaum. Das Aroma ist leicht malzig-süß mit einer gut erkennbaren Röstnote. Zuerst kommt einem ein starker Röstgeschmack entgegen, wenn dieser abflaut ist ein bisschen Süße erkennbar. Im Nachgeschmack hängt nur der Rest von dem Röstaroma im Gaumen nach. Alles in allem schmeckt es viel leichter als es ist und das Röstaroma macht es sehr interessant.

11.2 fl oz (330ml) bottle. Clear but very dark brown / red color, little khaki head leaving decent lace. Lighter carbonation, good crisp texture. Some dryness leaving an interesting and complex spicy / malty aftertaste. Really earthy indeed, very deep aroma, nice and savory with a bit of spice. Good, subtle hop profile, kind of a lighter body, relatively speaking. A very well-put-together doppelbock.

little but quite creamy head, faintly brownish. The beer itself is dark-dark brown. Dark roasted caramel, a little spice (hops?) Semifullbody and some length. Dry roasted caramel, with some dry prunes. quite fat.

Rich deep brown with hint of ruby color with a nice tan foamy one and half finger head. A nice smooth fruity roasted malt aroma. Has a silky smooth sweetness offset by the roasted malts which has an excellent balance. Has a hint of sourness in the middle. I can sense the alcohol in the finish and warming sensation which is nice.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with well kept tan head. Aroma not anything special, faint chocolate and coffee. Taste is an explosion, lots of chocolate, caramel and coffee with some dark fruits. A very nice rich malty balanced beer

50 cl bottle as Ayinger Winter‐Bock @ Nurmo, BBE 10/2012
Aroma is surprisingly light and malty with some coffee and chocolate. Flavour is really malty with dark chocolate and coffee. Nice!

Märkad som Ayinger Winterbock
Doft: brödig rostade toner och malt
Smak: Socker, malt, kola, kaffe och bränd knäck. En ganska ok julöl.

(Outstanding bock from my friend JB84, thanks!)  Une mousse généreuse qui flotte sur un liquide à la robe profondément brune.  Des parfums affolants de malts rôtis, de caramel et de chocolat avec des notes de café et des fruits foncés.  Des saveurs maltées riches, une apparition houblonnée, un goût de noisettes grillées, des papilles heureuses.  Une bouche plutôt moyenne avec un pétillement approprié et une texture huileuse.  Une finale excellente et longuement maltée.  Un doppelbock qui se hisse au sommet de mon court palmarès, devant la sublime Andechser Doppelbock Dunkel.

Bouteille de330ml couronnée dune petite chèvre de plastique. Merci Patrick. De couleur acajou (brune) ce doppelbock a un nez des plus complexe et intéressant, les effluves de fruits confits, de raisins secs, de sucre demerera, de toffee, de noix dansent sous les narines. Il est difficile dégaler la qualité de ce nez en bouche, elle est moins réussie. Tout de même les saveurs de chocolat, de coquille de noix, de vieux caramel caressent les papilles gustatives. La finale est longue et doucereuse. Un classique et la réputation de cette bière nest pas surfaite. 9/10 (comme il y a 15 ans).

Bottle. Poured a dark brown, almost black; with orange hues when held up to light. Good lacing. Smelled overwhelmingly of munich malts with some noble hop spiciness. Huge malt bomb, but the malt flavors are complex and unique. Not bready or biscuity. Again, its completely unique to the Munich malts. I get some gingerbread-spiciness, too. Body is lighter than expected, but it goes down smooth and leaves a pleasing finish. Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2012 pours dark brown with high frizzy head
aromas of dark bread, syrup, brown sugar, oak, caramel
mild palate, spices, leaves I nice aftertaste. some bitterness
well delivered doppelbock

pours clear dark brown with a lasting cream colored head and some lacing.  aroma is roasted nuts, maple, wood, and some smoked meat.  taste is rich and on the sweet side of bitter with notes of caramel, almond, root beer, some over ripened fruit and even a bit of cheese.  finish is earthy and smokey.  nice!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2013 Very dark, not much head. Smells like a pumpernickel sandwich with a cup of hot cocoa. The taste is sweet but perhaps more coffee than cocoa with its roasted bitterness towards the finish. The mouthfeel is a little oily with medium carbonation. I always find it difficult to give the 100/100 beers a fair review. It so easy to under rate because of high expectations or over rate because of peer pressure. Is this a 100/100 for me? No. But did I like it? Yes, very much.

Bought as Ayinger Winter Bock. WOW! This just might be my favorite among the Christmas brews at Systembolaget. Pours a very dark brown, against a light its slightly reddish. Big light tan head, quite fizzy. Aroma is just amazing as lagers go. Very bready, almost like a pumpernickel. Theres nuts, a touch of caramel and chocolate there. Sweet, yet intense - you just know this will taste good. And taste doesnt let it down. Opens up with a sweet, slightly chocolatey flavor. Syrup, bread (again), a touch of caramel. Sweet, yet very sturdy. Moving into the fairly long finish, theres a slight bitterness thats very controlled and never takes the upper hand. This could potentially become too sweet a concoction but the carbonation is just high enough to keep it in check, giving it a freshness that makes it very drinkable. Body is quite full, nothing unusual for a dobbelbock though, and quite creamy. A great, great beer.

Pours black with a brown head that sticks around. Aromas of plum, dried fruits and brown sugar. Medium bodied, velvety mouth feel with lots of flavours - similar to the nose - and has a bit of sticky sweetness that fades into a slight bitterness with coffee and nut flavours coming through. The alcohol emerges on the finish. This is a very well rounded and flavourful doppelbock.

On tap at Hopjacks in Mobile, AL. Poured into a snifter glass. Dark brown, almost black with a large tan head. Nose is sweet dried fruit, hops, barly. Taste is mostly the same with a rich feel and a slight bitter finish. Lively carbonation. I really enjoyed this beer.

Flaska 50 cl från Systembolaget, såld som Ayinger Winter Bock.
Mycket danskt rågbröd i aromen. samt en del pomerans. Smak av mörk sirap och mörk choklad, med hög kakaoprocent, i smaken. Aningen kolsyrig. Känns som en riktigt bra öl till julmaten.

500 ml bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on December 10. Pours deep chestnut brown with a creamy mocha-coloured head that leaves almost no trace while dissipating. Smell is sweet and intense with prunes, raisins, liquorice root and a tingling alcohol sensation. Taste is slightly sweet, slightly sour, slightly bitter and very malty with caramel, cloves, ginger, raisins, resin, peat and brandy. Finish is sweet and slightly bitter with warming alcohol.

Deep dark amber with a light brown head. Rich beer with focus on the malty body. A lot of chocolate, dark bread, coffee, dried fruits, fudge. Light touch of alcohol and metal notes. Altogether a very good double bock that is more complex than your ordinary double bock.

Bottle from systembolaget, Christmas beer tasting. Helsingborg, November 2011. 

Bottle as Winterbock. Round soft and rich aromas of caramels, toffee and chocolate. Light spicy fudge notes. Very malt heavy and full nose. The taste is just as rich with very balanced, slightly sweet malt profile. Flavours of chocolate, nuts and caramel. Warming and very drinkable.

0,33l bottle from Csakajósör, Budapest. Clear ruby brown - almost black color. The aroma is as special as stouts. Coffee, caramel, chocolate. Medium sour biterness. Well hopped, like a stout. Full body with oily texture and lively carbonation. Long astringent bitter coffee finish. Its an amazing beer. Its hard to belive that its a doppelbock. Its much better than average doppelbocks. Its alomst a stout...

so much on the smell I dunno what to say/ Looks dark pourple to light,black in front of me. Starts of tasting lighrt citurs furit basket then sips l8ter brown sugar with a hint of chockolate,then near the end I smell chocolate and taste it with hints of smokeyness I like this beer and mine says 6.9% cheers
Malty caramel and syrupy aroma and flavor with a slight alcoholic and smooth finish.
Pretty decent, malty, roasty, coffee, chocolate. Medium Dark Brown, tasty, light top, creamy. A very nice Dopplebock.

Med öl är den gamla devisen "less is more" sällan tillämplig. Det ser Ayinger till att ändra på. I produktbeskrivningen nämns inslag av dadlar, vörtbröd, mörk sirap, torkade aprikoser, kryddor, choklad... Ja, minst två inslag hade med fördel kunnat strykas från inköpslistan.
High stiff head, colored like pepparkaksdeg. Sweet toffee-like aroma with a bundle of hops and balanced bitterness. Hints of coffee and bitter chocolate. A bit too much sugar.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 First rating50 cl bottle at Rotary Pub, on November 30, 2011, as the Ayinger Winter-BockBB 05.11I was so very certain that Id tried and rated at least "Celebrator" before, but seems not, at least I dont see any rating from me. Now it gets rated though, and Im sure Ill drink it again. Nice one!Tried as "Ayinger Winter Bock"Clear dark red to brown color, medium sized light brown head. Sweet, alcohol, malty scent, also grainy. Sweet, fudge, a bit sugary, some alcohol taste. Fudge and grainy aftertaste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel. Medium high bitterness.7/4/7/4/15=3.750 cl bottle thanks to ekstedt! Sampled on March 24, 2012BB 10.12Hazy dark reddish brown color, smallish tan head. Grainy and slightly roasted scent. Malty, grainy taste, some dry ash aftertaste. Notes of alcohol. Medium mouthfeel, medium dry bitterness.6/3/7/3/12=3.1RerateOn March 15, 2014. Thanks to RobertGBG and thomat! Bottle 50 cl, BB 2011. As "Ayinger Winter-Bock.Clear brown color, tan head. Sweet, grainy, light smoked scent. sWeet, malty, grainy, light bitter taste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium low bitterness.7/4/7/4/15=3.7

Bottle from Beer Factory in Athens. Brown color with a nice creamy beige head. The aroma is full fo freshly roasted malt, not at all as asweet as most doppelbocks I am used to, if I was blindfolded I could swear that this is a stout i am smelling. full bodied and great full mouthfeel. Roasted malty taste, some coffee, chocolate ,a bit of burnt sugar , caramel, dryer and bitter as it progress . Exceptional Doppelbock.

Toasty malt and alcohol.  No hop character.  Dry and subtle flavor.  Nice mouth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Jacs.  Served in official glass.  Deep amber brown, not quite opaque.  Thin beige head.  Rich, sweet, old school.  Malty sweet, cookie dough, toffee.  Not quite as awesome as I tend to give it credit for being.  Mellow carbonation.

Date: November 20, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Ale Jail Description: Dark brown pour with large head and spotty lacing, malty and some fruit aroma, taste was similar with slight alcohol finish, medium to full bodied, smooth and creamy.
Possibly the best example of the style Ive had.  Subjectively, though, my distaste for doppelbocks keeps this out of the top tier.  Sweet, alcoholic, thick and creamy.  (5/3/2009)

330 ml bottle purchased at the Rideau and King Edward LCBO (Ottawa) on November 13, 2011. Dark brown, no head. Aroma of malted barley slightly sweet, notes of ripened fruit. Taste of barley and fruits fortified, smoked alcohol, slightly bitter fruit. Really nice with its fruity and smoky!

Ayinger Celebrator - 6,7% alkohol- és 18,5%!!!! szárazanyagtartalom. Kitöltés után a jellegzetes duplabakos pörkölt malátás jegyek mellett kiérződik az egyértelmű karamelles édesség és - meglepetésre -  a friss, virágos komló illata. Már szaglálva is nagyon harmonikus. Nagy borokat megszégyenítően összetett ízvilágú ez a sör. Az édes és a komlós illetve a pörkölt malátás keserűség csodás harmóniája hömpölyög benne. Szerintem egy igazi jin-jang sör. A keserűség és az édes között röpíti az embert, és mikor az egyik íz már-már túlsúlyba kerülne, újra átveszi a dominanciát az ellenpont, és aztán újra elölről, míg a pohár ki nem ürül. Önmagában fogyasztandó, igazi különlegesség.

50 cl bottle as Winter-Bock. BBE 10/2012.
Originally rated on 20091109. (7+4+7+4+16)
Pours dark ruby red colour with medium light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, light fruits, caramel, starch, light caramel and earth. Flavour of roasted malts, mild sweet caramel, light fruits, earth and leaves, bread, some nuts, biscuits and distant smoky chocolate. Medium CO2, full-bodied and rich in flavour.
5425

Ar: Dark toffee - hints of milk chocolate and a touch of red apple.
Ap: Dark brown, almost opaque, though red highlights on the edges when held up to the light - medium tan head with good retention and a thick lasting lacing.
T: Sweet dark toffee up front - rich chocolate, figs, and a touch of molasses - medium-low bitterness, a touch peppery - toasted deep maltiness lingers into finish.
P: Medium-fully body with medium carbonation - very lush and creamy, silky almost - finish is medium-dry.
O: This beer is delicious - the taste is complex and bold - the mouthfeel is absolutely amazing, so rich and smooth.

At a tasting, thanks DSG, a little thick beige head, clear deep brown colour, jammy aroma with hay, dried fruits and some oxidised notes, flavour of caramel, dark bread, dark fruit and some chocolate in the back,  light mellow fruity chocolate aftertaste, not to heavy. Quite nice.

Pours a very dark reddish brown. Aroma is toasty. Dark chocolate, dried prunes, dark berries. Delicate carbonation. Medium body, but full flavours of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted maltiness in the middle with a nice dry finish.  Very nice balance. Delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark, totally opaque pour with a loud lingering thin tan head.  Lots of malt in the nose.  Caramel, nuts, dark chocolate.  Wonderful scent.  Fizzy at first but mellows quickly.  More Carmel and nuts in the mouth.  Slight alcohol burn in the finish (which is something I love in a beer).  Grabbed this at random from the LCBO and found a jem.  This is one of the best beers I have had in a long time.  Very well balanced.  Nice mix of sweet and tart with a boozy after-taste.  I definitely like this one.

didnt know what to expect from this before drinking it, didnt even know the style. awesome beer. that syrupy mouthfeel with thedark fruits go great with the roasty character. dangerously drinkable and flavourful are a fantastic combination

Aroma: Wow, there is a lot there. Caramel, yeast, cloves, banana, peach, vanilla, grass, hints of licorice. Smells different with every whiff. Appearance: Opaque brown, small frothy beige head, not much visible carbonation. Palate: Smooth, creamy, full bodied, wonderful. Leaves me liking my mouth clean after every sip. Taste: Very rich, sweet, not bitter at all. I find myself taking very small sips and savouring every one. An incredible beer.

330 ml bottle - pours clear rich mahogany with a tight, creamy mocha head.  Beautiful aroma of dark candied fruit - prune, currant - brown sugar, hearty rye bread, some yeast.  Dark bread crust in the mouth, pumpernickel, dried date.  Somewhat burnt in the back of the throat, grainy.  Lingering vapours of rye bread with a round sweetness at the tail end.  Beautiful beer, truly the benchmark for the style.

Bottle, 33 cl: Extremely dark brown, yet not black beer. Intensely foamy cappuccino-colored head. Robust malty aroma with raosted notes and hints of caramel and brown sugar. Very smooth palate, sweet and sugary, yet off-dry in the mouth. subdued bitterness. Hints of chocolate, licorice and woodfire. Some alcohol, too. Oily texture, medium body, soft carbonation. Dry, lingering medium bitter finish. A good bock.

Pours almost black with a creamy brown head that very slowly dissipates.  Aroma is sweet with malty notes and hints of molasses and yeast.  Mild, slightly bitter initial taste.  Caramel, fruit and malt notes - medium body, no huge punch of flavors but nicely balanced and smooth.  Medium, bitter finish.  Great doppelbock.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2012 Bottle from LCBO.  Pours very dark brown - nearly black, slightly transparent.  Aroma is smooth roasted malt, with a little smoke and alcohol.  Taste is smooth and roasty with a sweet finish.  Toasted marshmallow notes, without being overly sweet like other doppelbocks.  Feels thick, creamy, and smooth on the tongue.  A fantastic doppelbock; love this stuff!

33cl bottle Pours a deep dark brown with a thin caramel head. Aroma is of toasty malts, yeast, caramels and dark malts...quite bready. Flavour expands upon these characteristics...lots of bread, chewy yeast, dark fruit, more caramel, more yeast...lots going on. This is really good stuff. Its the perfect kind of beer to keep you warm on a cold night...like this night. Fuck.

Tasted from bottle into nucleated tulip glass. Poured a somewhat opaque dark brown color with creamy, lasting off-white foam with nice lace. Very aromatic: grain, bread, roasted barley, caramelized sugar, fruity fermentation. Flavors of complex grainbill, very malty sweet, bready, biscuity, toasty, roasty, notes of licorice, plums, cherries, and dried fruit. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with fruity finish. Spice, fruit, banana and bubble gum yeast phenols increased as it warmed. Delicious, a true masterpiece.

Bottle. Appearance: cola black with a decent thick mocha head. Aroma: Coffee, malt, rye, dark chocolate, dark fruit. Rich and very appealing. Flavour: raisins, spicy, malty. Some dark chocolate and coffee, a teeny alcohol bite, nice yeastiness too. Dark berries in the finish. Delightful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle 
6.9% ABV (as marked on bottle) 
I tried this beer on October 7, 2011 after purchasing from the Queens Quay LCBO outlet in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent dark brown with a thin tan coloured head.  The aroma was roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, and yeast.  The mouthfeel was creamy, full bodied with good carbonation.  The flavour was dark fruits, molasses, roasted malt, and more yeasty notes.  An excellent beer.

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served cold in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep, deep mahogany with a fair tan froth.
  
Aroma:  Mash, lots of rich, deep malt aromas  molasses, dark dried fruits, treacle, brown sugar, dark rum, lighter chocolate notes, burnt sugar hints, some dark rye bread crust, hints of vanilla and root beer notes, pretty unctuous stuff.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderate, somewhat sparse effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose, with plenty of big, thick malt flavours, a touch metallic, mash, molasses, brown sugar, dark dried fruits, burnt sugar, dark rye bread, some hints of cola-like herbals, quite good; almost dry with limited bitterness and a pleasant brown/burnt sugar and rye crust finish.

Great beer.  Plus, a bonus...Christmas tree ornament?
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2013 An amazing beer.  Never had a doppelbock before but I will have a hell of a lot more in the future...

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a clear, deep slightly orange-ish brown with good-sized tan head.  Aroma is roasted chocolate, dark fruit and molasses.  Rich, modestly roasty flavour with chocolate, molassess, plum, raisin and just a hint of alcohol.  Fairly fine carbonation.  Medium-full body. Very nice.

330 mL btle. Pours deep, dark brown w/ wonderful khaki colored head. Superb malty nose w/ light hints of oxidation reminiscent of a fine Oloroso sherry (most likely from the little bit of age?). Malty nose is a battle of chocolate & nut and follows through to a creamy mouthfeel. Subtle hops bitterness is in perfect balance to the sweet chocolate & roasted malt. Full-bodied & warming w/ a surprisingly dry finish, this doppelbock should not just be saved for celebrations.

33 cL bottle from the LCBO, served in a tulip with Paulaner Salvator side-by-side. Pours clear chestnut with a moderate, dense tan head. The head remains and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of roasted malts, coffee, dark fruit, chocolate, delicate hops and a touch of smoke. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with roasted malts, coffee, molasses, pepper and spice, along with a touch of hops. The finish is long and surprisingly dry and smoky. On the palate, it is medium in body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent doppelbock with a delicate, roasty character. It is pleasantly less sweet than many examples. A great winter warmer; well worth another try. 2011-10-12

Pours a really nice deep brown with a bit of reddishness in them.  Aroma is of dark fruits and roasted malts.  Roasted malts take over in the taste, with some smokiness and the dark fruits as accents.  Really nice complex doppelbock.
A masterpiece of doppelbock...very complex beer..chocolate,spice,smoke..very looong finish...extremely balanced.

Dark brown with ruby highlights and a moderate tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel and roasted malt, and brown sugar. Taste malty sweet, but not heavily so, with a mild bitterness. Medium full bodied with a creamy feel and smooth carbonation. Excellent; very nicely balanced.

Poured a dark brown with a khaki colored head. Nose is malty as hell. Notes of caramel and chocolate with some lager notes. Hay and straw with some yeast. Tasted similar but with a distinct nutty taste like walnuts. Also, this one seemed to have a touch of smoke to it. Definitely different. Reminded me more of a brown than a dopple.
A sweet Doppelbock with relatively,  little flavor compared to strength but with good volume. Slightly hoppy aftertaste.

Poured a dark brownish with slight dark ruby amber color. Medium head. Aroma of malts and candied fruits, raison,brown sugar. Taste is medium sweetness with a slight bitterness. Great complexity. Creamy texture is very noticable. Well balanced. Great smooth malty flavor. Soft carbonation. Just a touch of hop flavor. +1 for the goat ornament, just take it off before you pour or your goat might go for a swim in your beer.

Pours dark brown with a medium, fine-grained light brown head. Nose is rich with dark malt, wheat, banana, light nuttiness, and some brown sugar. Flavor is full and smooth; hops and some roastiness come out on the front, quickly shifting to a more chocolate and coffee quality. Not as sweet as many doppelbocks but quite well balanced. Alcohol figures into the flavor a lot for a sub-7% ABV. Finish is fairly quick. Great stuff overall.

Why oh why did I wait so long to try this stellar brew?! This brew poured up a hefty dark mahogany-colored body with a thick one-fingered tan colored with retention lasting long after the beer was gone and amazing lacing effects. Aromas of warm dark bread, caramel, molasses, malts and hops, and a very slight hint of alcohol. Of the doppelbocks, I am sure that this one reigns supreme! Medium-bodied, light carbonation, very thick and creamy with a well-balanced hit of hops on the finish that is dry but not too dry.

Creamy, dark (almost black), malty doppelbock. Lovely, brown, two finger head holds for a minute. Smooth, yeast-tinged, Belgian style taste with medium body. Overall a very flavorful and enjoyable bock.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2011 Really an excellent beer. Bottle.  Would love to have on tap.  Pours a varnish brown color.  Aroma of grape and caramel malt.  Really complex, but well balanced flavor.  Dried fruits, grapes, alcohol.  Update. 9/15/2011  Tried on Tap at Bru Haus in Los Angeles on Wilshire.  Tap had a thicker mouthfeel than bottled version.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Extremely dark red that appears black unless held to the light. Thin tan head with some spotty lacing.

Aroma: Sweet molasses, candied caramel, fig, chocolate, licorice and soy sauce.

Taste: Complex and sweet upfront with strong molasses, caramel, candy, doughy bread, chocolate and raisins. Turns slightly drier towards the end with dark fruit, a light roasted character and a slight spiciness.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, somewhat full lager body that is somewhat creamy and smooth. Very slight dry finish.

Overall: Manages to be both a great sipping beer and also easy to drink quickly. The king of Doppelbocks, although I personally prefer the off-style Autumnal Fire.
Bread, caramel, cocoa, and toffee in the aroma.  More of the same in the flavor; this is a great-tasting beer with a great, creamy mouthfeel.  Outstanding.

Bottle ---> Shaker glass. Had a dark amber body with a thick tan head. The smell was floral and sweet; notes of yeast, hops and caramel were pleasant and very smooth. Tasted creamy and had a great mouth feel. Notes of toffee, lightly roasted malts, dried citrus fruits and subtle hops were inviting and provided a full palate. I can see why this is the top rated Dopplebock available.

This is another super example of a dark beer that rates well, but I may withhold a favorite mark from. 

It pours a tantalizing black/brown with ruby edges, the head doesnt last long but while it does its light tan and fragrantly frothy - as it fades it leaves little islands behind, but not really lacing.

The smell is of dark-fruited malts and with a tinge of smoke and perhaps a bit of light soy sauce. It tastes of cherry, dry cocoa, vanilla, soy sauce with a warming dark alcoholic taste. The aftertaste lasts with a nice bittersweet quality. Long into the aftertaste a grassy black licorice taste emerges - after at least a minute.

Maybe I will favorite this one.

Finish Duration: long

Pours deep reddish brown with a fluffy tan head.  Nutty aroma of cocoa and fudge.  Subtle dark fruits merge with molasses with a bright finish.  A bit of carbonation mellows out into a nice warmth.  Dont know that this deserves a double 100, but it is an excellent beer.
Dark brown color with some carbonation. Aroma of chocolatey malts. Extremely malty in flavor. No hint of alcohol in the flavor, rather easy drinking. Great beer!

Samma dubbelbock som annars går under namnet Celebrator. Mörkt mahognyfärgad med medelhögt beige skum. Stor söt doft av vörtbröd, mörk sirap och russin. Stor maltig kropp med en lätt alkoholton. Smakerna drar åt sött mörkt bröd med russin, vinteräpplen och marsipan. Liten beska i eftersmaken som håller ihop och stramar upp ölet. Kanske lite sött men annars den perfekta dubbelbocken.

Brown coloured beer with little carbonation and a medium brown head. Chocolat malty hinted aroma with some sweet cognac touches. Medium to full palate. Finish is sweet, malty, light alcholic and eldered. Very rich beer.

This wasnt bad, by any means, but it was very uninspiring. I thought it was boring and didnt get much going on. It had plenty of carbonation, but tasted flat. There was definitely some molasses, but not much else going on. Very disappointed with this one. Didnt even finish it, to be honest. Just boring.
Very dark double bock, deep molasses flavor. I appreciate this unique bock, perhaps resembling eisbock
Bottle. A beautiful dark cola appearance. Smoky aroma. Sweet, coffee notes, very nice.

Vielen Dank an ariusz für diesen Winterbock! Die Schaumkrone hält mittelmäßig, farblich ist es Schwarz mit leichtem Braunstich. Das Ayinger riecht cremig dunkelmalzig-fruchtig, röstig, man riecht den Gehalt des Bieres, das ist schonmal viel versprechend! Geschmacklich ist es dann auch leicht cremig, dazu röstmalzig-dunkelmalzig und süßlich, soweit ganz gut aber eine Aromenkombination ist noch vorhanden, die mir in diesem Fall nicht so gelungen scheint: bitter-pflaumig-leicht alkoholisch. Im Nachgeschmack bleibt es süß-bitter fruchtig-leicht alkoholisch. Fazit: Auf jedenfall testenswert, aber meiner Meinung nach nicht ganz gelungen! Für den schönen Geruch bekommt es aber nochmal einen Pluspunkt im Gesamteindruck!
	
Test vom 23.12.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,10,10,9,12,11 - 10,35

Dark brown, almost black beer with a beautiful creamy head. Smells of roasted malts and chocolate. Starts voluminous malty, with sweet chocolate aromas, slightly roasty bitterness in the background. The aftertaste shows more hoppy, slightly bitter. Again, with massive malt body, roasted malts and lots of chocolate!

Pours clear dark ruby with brown tinged head, good retention.  Aroma reminds me of a good pumpernickel bread; has a very distinct roasted grain note, a hint of dry fuit, all against a caramelly background.  Taste is very bready and caramelly but balanced with a spicy herbal/woody hop note.  Body is where this brew really stands out-- very full body, viscous creamy mouthfeel, avg carbonation, dry finish, taste goes from sweet to bitter then leaves a lingering balanced aftertaste. Usually doppelbocks are not really my style as they are often too sweet, but this one is perfectly balanced.
Draft.  Very good all around.  Brown, light tan head.  Full body, creamy, balanced caramel malt aroma.  Complex but satisfying.

Dark brown, tan head that reduces to a film gripping the sides of the glass.  Aroma is lager yeast and mild sweetness.  Flavor features mild roast, well-integrated sweetness, and slight lager-yeast (sulphur...?) in the finish.  Also, a mild yet sharp and lingering hop bitterness, somewhat distracting.  Its good, a bit dark for the style, which I like, but I really wish I could taste it in its home territory.  Not nearly as good as the Korbinian.
Bottle. Poured clear, dark brown with small head that retained. Aromas of dark chocolate, smoke, and roasted malt. Taste is very similar and finish is very smooth. Would have again.

(33 cl bottle from Bayersk.dk) In celebration of my rating #100 on Ratebeer I decided to try the best Doppelbock and the best Baltic Porter in the world (both with percentiles of 100 within and outside the style). Pours a clear but dark copper with rich, toffee head that laces the glass heavily. Aroma is complex. I detect toasted malts and what seems to me to be a hint of cherry, raisin, dust and bread? The texture is quite special. I dont think I ever tasted a beer that felt so silky before. It is very light and tender on the tongue - probably due to the aging. The carbonation is soft and the brew is medium-bodied with a dry finish. In the taste I find nuts and fruity malts. It has a sweetness of character but far more subdued and refined than more simple brews and well balanced out by nutty flavours and a very subtle hint of smoke. The celebrator is a very refined specimen in the Bock genre that I found a bit rash up until now. This is a very gentle, smooth and drinkable brew.
After a long day of tasting big hop bombs, the sweetness in this one was a nice change! Very oily sweetness in mouth. Molasses, dark bread. Good beer.
Bottle, smells decent, looks like a doppel, taste is very nice, it was pretty dry with a nice smoothness, the finish is great, really nice offering

Huge creamy brown head that leaves plenty of lacing. Pours deep amber. Nose is malts, molasses, spices. Good carbonation a bit dry. Not much bitterness and the sweetness is not overwhelming - very balanced brew. Easy to drink.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2012 Dark. Sweet. Syrupy. Burnt. Delicious. 

Rerating 8.12.2012. Flat carbon. Roasted smell. Dark brown colour. Aroma of roast, licorice, some coffee, alcohol, syrup. Very sweet, slightly bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2011 Dark, but not black, beer with not much of a head. The aroma is VERY sweet but mellow and balanced, with lots of malts, lots and lots of caramel, cake, dried fruits, honey, and a hint of chocolate. I love it. The taste is malty and dark, mostly sweet, but not very bitter. The aftertaste is sweet and a bit bitter, but not fresh-hop bitter. A mild, honey-like sensation lingers under your palate. The beer has a full body, not very carbonated.  This is a delicious treat that I like to come back to every time I get the chance. I also have to say that I like the bottle presentation very muchprobably more than other big German brews.
Bottle from Alko. Originally rated on 28.11.2009 as Winter Bock. Taste has notes of liqourice and malts. Dry finish. Nice.

Overall this is the best doppelbock Ive ever had.  Aroma is bready cereal notes with a sweet smell.  Taste is caramel very light bitterness and very malty with a dry finish that doesnt coat your mouth with sweetness.  Not my favorite style but this one does it right.

Im not normally a fan of doppelbocks, but as you can tell from my rating, Ayinger Celebrator ranks among the best beers. So if a beer of a style Im not partial to can knock my socks off - what does that say about the beer?I poured a 12oz bottle into a tumbler.Appearance: Pretty hue of dark maroon, almost purple, with a perfectly-proportioned tan, foamy head. The head sticks around until the bitter end and leaves some lacing on the glass.Smell: Many of the same scents I get in a dark Trappist ale I get here: raisin, fruitcake, rum, and a bit of cough medicine.Taste: Perhaps I should just "copy and paste" my tasting notes of certain Belgian Trappist beers since Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock seems to have many of the same flavors. As we noted in the aroma, dark fruits and confectionary flavors are strong here. Fruitcake, rum, raisin, and toffee syrup are all prominent from start to finish. Its a rich, sweet beer to be sure, but its never cloying or sticky. It finishes with a subtle, semi-sweet chocolate aftertaste to impart some bitterness and let you know its still a beer.Mouthfeel: The first thing I noticed about this beer even before the flavor was just how soft and gentle it was in the mouth. This is like getting a hug from a teddy bear.Drinkability: Theres no carbonation sensation, nor is the beer obese - its perfectly medium-bodied. Not a refreshing beer, obviously, so its not quite in league of a summer seasonal (bear in mind this beer IS a lager, not an ale). Its so darn soft and tasty that its difficult not to drink it as fast as possible.Overall, this is a pretty amazing beer I wasnt expecting to like nearly as much as I did. I think most beer drinkers will be pleasantly surprised by it as well.

Thanks to Jimmack for the bottle. 
The aroma is malty with hint of fermented fruit and a smoky finish. This Beer starts with a crisp maltiness at the beginning, but as it was slowly sipped the crispness left and the malt flavor was more pronounces. With in the final sips this beer ended with a smoky malted flavor.

on tap at Tylers Apex. Good aroma, sweet. Malty, Chocolate, little fruity plum/date kind of thing. Clean orangy brown color, Good head, ok lace, Sweet flavor. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, Dry sweet finish. Tasty, good malty beer. I like flavor best. nice range with sweet smokey kind of thing.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Special ordered  at a municipal liquor store near  Minneapolis MN...yes they will and can. Gentle poured into a rinsed, short tulip glass from the bottle. Nice dark walnut color,  bready chocolate, toffee.. smooth malty flavor. No hint of nasty wheat malt or other sub-standard ferment-able sugars. Loved it. You should also try Sclaegl Doppelbock from Austria.

Poured black like a stout with no head. Smelled of plums and tasted the same, but with some chocolate notes. It was highly carbonated and very sweet for a dopplebock.  I usually dont enjoy dopplebocks, but I would have this again...several times.
Poured from the bottle. Aroma is clean and slightly fruity and malty. Flavour is similar and delicious. This beer also burps up nicely. Overall a great double bock.

11.2 oz bottle thanks to weihenweizen, pours a very dark brown with a red hue in the light, tan head and some spotty lacing in the glass, aroma is sweet with malt with touches of chocolate and nuts as well, the flavor has a nice amount of chocolate mixed in with the sweetness of the malt, there is a tad bit of smoke and wood in the finish, the mouthfeel is nearly perfect, wonderful example of this style.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 Pours pitch black with a medium caramel head that fades quickly. Aromas are sweet malt and caramel. The taste is a very good balance between the sweetness of the malt and the bitterness of the roasted malts and hops. Thick oily mouth-feel and an aftertaste that lingers like honey in your mouth afterwards. Very good.

Pour deep dark brown almost black terrific beige head great retention and lace. Aroma malt sweetness, dark fruit, chocolate, molasses, licorice, coffee. Taste sweet, dark fruit coffee, chocolate, licorice, almost no bitterness, caramel, rye, slight earthiness, super complex. MF medium to full body nice fine carb. Overall a ridiculously well brewed beer very tasty and a excellent example of the style.
Definitely a double bock, quite hefty. A good, dark, football beer. Drinks smoother than it looks, like a dunkel. And, a bonus Christmas ornament.
Pours black with the barest of tan heads.  Smells like sweet bread, toasty and warm.  Taste of a slightly sweet malt, rich, full-bodied flavor like a robust wine without the acid.

Draft at Mikkeller bar in Copenhagen. Dark colored beer with a small off white head. A bit sweetish taste, notes of caramel, coffee and chocolate. Some bitterness at the end. Not as good as the other beers tasted that day.

This is one of my favorite bock biers, probably one of my favorite beers of all time. I was shocked that I had not reviewed it. I recently picked up a four pack from a local liquor store as part of my beer photography project where I photograph beers in the appropriate glassware, I have a Ayinger Celebrator glass, so I poured it into the glass. This beer is dark, nearly black. Has a nice head and it falls away quickly. The smell is sweet like malt, it may be dark but there are no hints of any roasted malt, just some sweetness from the alcohol and the malt. No aftertaste to speak of, amazingly smooth. A great beer.

Serving type: bottle

Pours a deep brown, think bit of tan foam, very dense. Aroma is sweet and malty, a bit of fruit - dates and figs. Taste is sweet -- malty, some brown sugar and caramel, hint of fruit -- and biting as well, with a subtle bitterness that helps make it not so cloyingly over-sweet as some doppelbocks are.

Bottle. Hazy dark cola brown with a fluffy lightly tan head.  Lots of prunes, toffee, and toast in the aroma with some slight sweetness but minerally as well.  Toffee and toast, dark fruits, prunes, some sweetness, but fairly dry finish.  Medium body with very present carbonation.  Very good, and I do use it to judge all others in the style.

Aroma of dark nuts and bitter yeast.  Pours very dark with a red hue and a small creamy head.  Tastes like a good light coffee.  This is a perfect doppelbock but not as sweet as I love them.  Recommend it to all.

From bottle pour bought in Carterville, IL.
Appearance: body pours a very dark mahogany or chestnut (theres a reddish hue if held up to the light).  Head is creamy and tan; only lasts a few minutes, significant lacing of the glass.
Smell:  dark fruits (~plums or raisons), and red meat; hint of grape juice, dark chocolate (~ dark chocolate covered cherries), molasses.  Very good smell.
Taste:  molasses, dark chocolate.  Finishes with strong dark chocolate flavor and mild bitterness that lingers with a noticeable read meat/dark fruit flavor.   
Mouthfeel: very carbonated, creamy, rich.  
Overall:  Very very good.  Not really a session beer.  Great for holidays and deserts.

Sweet, super malty mix of toffee and caramel and apple cider.  Finishes mildly bitter, yet the sweetness never leaves.  Smells a little funky, but the lovely appearance wipes away any hesitation.  Gets you good and fuzzy with little warning.  Good beer.  Bonus points for the plastic ram.  (6/08)
This brew has good and bad, smells kinda off but goes down smooth. Ok taste very Euro feel. This is cool because it seems to be the standard, and it doesnt disappoint, but it didnt change my life.

chocolate, coffee, barnyard, earthy aromas. Very brown pour with rich and creamy tan foam. Lingering  aftertaste of coffee. Overall, very strong coffee aroma and gritty. Little repeat value unless hankering for cold coffee.

Draft on tap at Craft Day Afternoon (Chicago, IL). Pours a murky dark brown hue, near opaque with some reddish orange bottom and edges. A moderate tannish head dies to a thick film and laces well. Aromas are oxidized caramel, toffee, and touches of banana esters, cherries. Light roast and cocoa. Nice and warming. Initial is medium bodied, with some toffee, cocoa, and toasty wheat bread. Some banana, touches of cherry, with roast. Toast and sweet toffee, biscuits, brown sugar. Finish is smooth and simple, goes down pretty easy with some nice darker slant. Touches of toast and toffee really linger on the finish with some cocoa banana bread. Not bad. A little sticky, just a touch of warmth. Very nice. Its amazing to me that this is what all Doppelbocks aspire to be, yet the majority end up hot boozy messes where as this is just so smooth.

Schöne dunkle Färbung mit leicht rötlichem Stich. Im Geruch malzig süßlich, vielleicht auch etwas schokoladig. 
Geschmacklich dann ein Ensemble aus fruchtigem Malz mit einer spürbaren Bitteren. Leicht röstige Züge. Angenehm über die Zunge gleitend. Erst im Abgang kommt ein wenig der Alkohol zum Tragen, was bei einem Bockbier auch so sein sollte. 
Toller Doppelbock in interessanter Flaschenaufmachung (Anhängsel eines Kunststoffziegenbocks am Flaschenhals).
Dark beer with a nice head. Taste of smoked wood with a hint of chocolate. A roasted taste is definitely there. A good dopplebock but not my favorite.

Big yeasty bread notes on the nose. Pours almost black with a large white head that doesnt leave a lot of lacing. The taste is fairly balanced between the musty caramel maltiness and the hop dryness. Finishes neat. Eminently drinkable.

330ml bottle. Deep brown with bright red highlights. Tan head of very fine bubbles that lasts and leaves a good lace. Very roasted nose with a stewed prune vibe. Theres also a little bready note in there with some earthy notes. Fairly sweet on the palate with a bready and roasted feel. Finishes dry with a lingering warmth. Definitely good, but not the spectacular brew Id expected.
Bottle ad Ayinger WInter-Bock from Systembolaget. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich fruits, nuts, caramel, malt and hops. Great beer.

Tasted on 5/18/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at Tops.  Pours deep amber with the smallest glimmer of light allowed through with a thick beige head that recedes somewhat quickly to nothing but a very thin collar of lace.  The nose is very malty with milk chocolate, cola, a bit of a savory aroma, prune, and toast.  The flavor is chocolate malt, cola, toast, and a bit of light bitterness.  The body is medium with light carbonation and a long cola, chocolate, and lightly bitter finish.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller white head that went rather quick. Aroma was malts, caramel, and bready flavors. Flavor was caramel, nuts, and other candy flavors. Good beer.

330 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown that looks like cola when held up to the light.  Two finger tan head that has good retention and never completely disappears.  Leaves a huge amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is brown sugar, a light nuttiness, roasted malt, molasses, and a yeasty breadiness.  The initial taste is a sweet nuttiness with a good amount of roast.  Brown sugar is also present along with molasses.  The finish has some more nuttiness and breadiness as well as a light bitterness.  Medium-heavy body.  Relatively low carbonation.  Could probably use a bit more carbonation.  Overall a pretty enjoyable beer.  Very smooth.

Dunkler, tief malzerner Geschmack. Das Bier ist überaus vollmundig und sehr ausgelichen was die Aromen angeht, alles ist in genau richtigem Maße vorhanden. Das Ganze ist dabei überaus süffig, phänomenal für einen Doppelbock! Im Nachgeschmack ist das Bier für einen kurzen Moment SEHR malzig. Bestes deutsches Bier? Es geht definitiv in die Richtung. 	 
Test vom 1.10.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,13,14,15,11,14
Clear dark brown with a brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and roasted malt. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. Full bodied, soft and smooth. 280411

Bottled poured into dimpled mug.  Nice deep dark brown in color with beautiful lighter brown and ruby red highlights when held against light.  One finger plus head, thats lightly tan in color, quickly fades down.  Good aroma of caramel, dark roasty malt, cookie dough, and walnuts.  Easy drinking on the palate with average carbonation.  Nice flavor with some sweetness upfront before a sticky bitter finish.  Tastes of booze, caramel, and baked bread, slight earthy hops.  Good dopplebock.
Bottle.  Seriously??  With 2100 hundred ratings, Im not adding anything new.
Great beer, picked up from whole foods in sauganash. really enjoyable beer.

I like the aroma because the hops overpowers the malt. Ginger pops up in  the aroma after you get through the hops. Very dark red in color with a creamy, frothy off-white head. The lacing was only average. Taste like a mocha from starbucks (burnt coffee). Light-bodied beer that left a watery feeling in your mouth. Being watery gave it an abrupt finish. Overall i like a beer that has a thicker texture. Something that will stick with you well after you take a drink.

Aroma: Light malty aroma--caramel and toasted, mainly.
Appearance: Dark brown, almost black, with no head.
Taste: Very rich and warm sweetness, balanced by an almost silent hint of bitterness. 
Palate: Full body, creamy, thick texture, average carbonation, long finish.
Overall: I completely understand why  folks go gaga over this beer, as its a really, really well developed beer with lots of depth and character. However, Im just not blown away enough to give it the full twenty marks.

Dark pour with huge tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate fudge, malt and molasses. Tastes just like it smells but all the flavours perfectly compliment each other. Sweet but not overly sweet. Creamy and velvety mouthfeel. Excellent beer!

The aroma is what you think of when you think BEER! It is a complexity of Carmel and Chocolate, with a tiny hint of herbs, not yeasty at all.

The color was a very rich, dark reddish brown, that when poured into a tulip glass cascaded back into itself for about 30 seconds as the head built to a good 2", that lasted until you licked it off the edge of the glass.The head was a dark amber with small bubbles. After the cascading ceased it was a very clear pour. WOW

Taste was lightly sweat and bitter at mthe same time, remarkable!

Body had a full, creamy, thick feel, and a lively, slightly bitter finishing that was just right.

WoW, this is one beer to keep around for youself, dont share it as the store may run out. Then what would you do for an excellent beer?
Deep black. Very full bodied and velvety. Very complex dopplebock . Has maltiness, fruitiness abd hoppiness which comes together really well. Fantastic beer

11.2 oz. pours dark brown with a great 1 inch thick tan head. I really like the ram /goat plastic medallion; this is a plus like a happy meal toy. I smell roasted caramel malts, some fruit and a slight belgian nuance very interesting! Big roasted malt taste, slight dark fruit note, roasted, almost burnt nuts and some smoke in the end. The mouthfeel is medium with a nice roasty bitter finish that is medium in length. Very enjoyable would love to have again!

Dark brown with a garnet hue and a tan head.  Aromas of black strap molasses, cream and earth (and that "German beer" smell).  Sweet honey/molasses flavor along with figs, vanilla, and milk and dark chocolate.  Theres just enough hop bitterness to temper this sweetness.   A light woody and slightly sour flavor linger, along with a cocoa bitterness.  This is one delicious beer thats good any time of year.
