500ml bottle, as Winter Bock. Pours a very dark brown, with a thick beige head. Clean, malty nose, quite roasted, coffee, hops, dark cocoa. Off-dry, medium body, medium bitterness. Malty, roasted taste, coffe, hops, faint diacetyl. (2011-01-03)

Bottle 500ml @ Schouskjelleren Mikrobryggeri, Oslo
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, yeast and licorice. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

great beer best doppelbock Iv e ever had (and I guess Im not the only person to think so).  Got a 4 pack at the local liquor store.  It pours a dark brown with a little head.  smell is malty and alcohol with some chocolate. Taste is about the same.  It is a great beer, highly recommended.
Best beer vie ever had.  Hands down.

Bottle. Sold as Winter-Bock. Pours a dark brown with tones of wood and dark coffee. Medium, latte head. Aroma is chocolate and bready malts. Flavor is rye bread, chocolate, sweet. Palate is easy, fairly full, no carbonation whatsoever.

12 oz bottle poured into a wine like glass at the Flying Saucer in Fort Worth.  All I can say is WOW!  Alinger has done it again.  This drinks like a fine wine with pleasent and complex aromas and tastes of toasts with thick but not too sweet syrup with mild note of heat from the alcohol. Pures black into the glass with a tan head.  Little sweet but dry on the palate with low to none hop charactoristics.  Thats the best way i can put it.  I believe this put it at my second highest rating so far.

Poured into a mug. Deep, dark brown with faint hints of red around the edges. Small head that leaves full, thick lacing. Nose of rye bread, after it warms a bit.  Taste is Rye bread with a creamy smooth finish. After taste, almost leaves you wanting more. Drinkability is high.  A excellent brew however, I would choose the Paulaner Salvator  before this one. Still overall VERY nice for the style.

Poured into a mug. Deep, dark brown with faint hints of red around the edges. Small head that leaves full, thick lacing. Nose of rye bread, after it warms a bit.  Taste is Rye bread with a creamy smooth finish. After taste, almost leaves you wanting more. Drinkability is high.  A excellent brew however, I would choose the Paulaner Salvator  before this one. Still over all nice for the style. Shared with AirForceHops.

Im an ale guy for the most part, but from the first sip of this beer, I knew I would be coming back to it again and again. This was nearly a spiritual experience for me. First, it pours dark into the glass, and creates a beautiful thick, resilient head. The smell is just fantastic, rich, malt.  The taste full bodied and complex, just brining the palate alive. I would describe this as moderately bitter, just enough to add to the beer as you drink it. There is subtle, lingering bitterness, but overall I found the finish clean and very refreshing. What an absolutely delightful beer!

At Taberna Lupulo in Old San Juan, PR.  Pours a thick dark brown with very little head and slight lace.  Aroma is slight, flavour is of roasted malts, dried fruit and figs.  Notes of yeasty banana bread. Very slight hop bitter.  Lingering caramel and slight alcohol warming.

This beer pours a dark brown with medium tan head that is about 1 finger high and lasts about 1 minute. The lacing is ok but there is lots of carbonation.

The aroma is very light on the nose, you detect the malts which come off as sweet chocolate or toffee.

The taste is very nice its very sweet, definitely tastes like toffee and at the end some light hops. 

The feel is little watery for what it is but ok, but its very drinkable.

Very effervescent head, lively and bubbly, off-white, large and diminishing. Dark in colour with maroon highlights. Strong scents of plum and toasted malt. Flavour: toasted chocolate malts with notes of plum, with a slightly bitter finish. Long lasting flavour married well with higher ABV.
palate is kinda of thin. has a assortement of flavors including, cola, toffee, caramel and nuts. fizzy and not too smooth, but tasty
Pours almost totally opaque with a medium creamy head that fades fast. Slight, but pleasant caramel/coffee aroma. A nutty flavor thats slightly bitter and leaves an almost grassy aftertaste.

33cl beer shared with friends.
Creamy off white head. Deep colour. Some raisins and caramel

Bottle pours red/brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of toffee, coffee, plum, brown sugar, light roast, and yeast.  Flavor shows the same with bready malt being reinforced and livened up by some estery fruitiness.  Overall body is moderate and creamy with balanced bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2011 ottima birra dal colore molto scuro con qualche riflesso rubino.schiuma cappuccino di media persistenza!aroma intenso di prugna frutta secca e malto torreffatto.in bocca è morbida e dolce di malto ma equilibrata benissimo con lamaro sia del luppolo che dalla torreffazione!buonissimo finale che continua a lungo stuzzicando la lingua per parecchio tempo!anche nel finale dominano la frutta secca ,la prugna e il caffe(forse anche un pizzico di cioccolato e liquirizia).
gli manca secondo me un po di forza in piu

It is really dark brown. The nose is fruity and spicy but not too potent. It is so smooth and delicious in the mouth. Creamy and intense with an excellent balance of light, chocolatey malts and peppery hops. It has a reasonable serious dryness in the finish and overall is dangerously drinkable.

Amazing brew.  This is a good sign that maybe Germany isnt as overrated as I t´hought.  Well living there for 3 years in the Rhineland-pfalz area sux, Bitburger and erdinger gets old.  So its no wonder a magnificent beer once again emerges from Bavaria, not that this is a new beer but I finally was able to try it.  So this beer smells great, nutter-butters, chocolate and fresh dark malts.  The taste is complex, rich yet subtle considering the color and abv, so well aged and designed.  Look is dark, black with a tinge of tannish head sliding down the glass.  Palate is amazing for the color and usual overpowering coffee choco flavor.  Overall, the mild espresso,choco, peanut butter, cream, and all around well put together.
Bottle enjoyed in Cologne during carnival.  Sweet, balanced, perfect maltiness, mild hope, complex.

dark bread dominates. like the finest german breads from the finest german ovens of breadmaking. hops in the background. not overly sweet by any means.  average appearance. all around pretty solid. not worth the $4 i paid for the single 11.2oz bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2011 3/1/2011 Bottle.  One-finger solid, sandy head that dissolves in two minutes to a thinning, sandy layer over a dark red body with a lot of lacing from the head to the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is a complex of sour doughy, yeasty - like uncooked bread - but also notes of something sweet and deep-roasted and basement aromas.  In contrast, the taste is roasted and lightly bitter.  There is an undertone of very good, sweet rum.  But theres a bitter finish like drinking roasted peanuts.
This beer in a 11.2 oz bottle with the mere 6.7% ABV is finely-crafted and all good.  
Aroma 6/10, Appearance 4/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 17/20 = 3.8

12/5/11 - Conducted an experiment to compare the bottle with the draught.

Bottle.  Let this one sit before drinking.  Same as above except head dissolves faster and lacing not so covering and sticky but for a ring of lacing.  And aroma is well-baked nut bread and delicious.  Taste is sweet.  Palate is lively and full.  Rating is entry of display.
Aroma 9/10, Appearance 3/5, Overall 18/20.  Total =4.1

Draught 8oz.  Let this one sit.  Same as most recent bottle except lacing is frostier than either bottle.  Aroma is much weaker - coffee, mild candy, mild basement, roastiness, and a tobacco note.  Palate kind of creamy with an abrupt finish.   This compares to other Ayinger Celebrator draughts - does not measure up to the bottle.  Leaving bottle rating as more popular and representative.  Rating is close to bottle of March:
Aroma 6/10, Appearance 4/5, Taste 6/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 16/20 = 3.6
Incredibly malty and thick, this isnt as sweet as a lot of other doppelbocks but is as close to perfect as a beer gets.
Very complex roasted aroma, not sweet like the american knock-offs, but malty, amazing doppelbock, will convert anyone!
Pours black with creamy tan head and foamy lacing.  Sweet notes of malt predominate.  Well balanced taste that is smooth and creamy.

11.2 fl oz bottle. Im pretty sure this is a really fresh bottle, but Im not 100% sure of it.

Pours into may small mug with a nice off white head and a dark brown body with hints of red.

This one smells different from the other doppelbock imports. It is what Orval is to the trappist beers. It is mostly raisin on the nose, almost exclusively, with some caramel. There is just something weird about it.

It tastes doppelbock enough, and it is pretty awesome. There are hints of chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, dark fruits, and an interesting yeast kick. It is pretty sweet.

The mouthfeel is pretty good although the drinkability could be higher.

It is a good doppelbock but Salvator reigns supreme in my mind.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-14-2010 23:06:32
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 I own the glass if that tells ya anything. Malts, hops, and fruits all brought together for a smooth flowered finish. Very easy to drink. Love it.
Pours a very dark brown with decent off white head. Aroma of chocolate and bread.  Taste smoothly sweet. So good its hard to describe....

A great brew. Smooth, easy to drink. Full of life and complexities. Malty, sweet...and this amazing subtle hoppiness poking through. Crisp and clean finish. A freest go to beer. A gateway beer for all who are intimidated by those brews with a ton of power. Great balance. I wonderful beer.I love it.

Pours a solid dark brown with orange/red highlights when held to light. Stingy beige head dissipates quickly to form a cap and light lacing on the sides. Very malty nose. Caramel, brown sugar, plums, berries and a touch of alcohol. Taste of caramel and raisins up front followed but some nice fruity notes, dark pitted fruit, finishing with a long lingering molasses. Mouthfeel is creamy body is medium to thick, carbonation is ample. Beautiful Bock! Very complex. This is one of those Id love to try it at the source beers.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2011 Ahhhh, the infamous Ayinger. Had to fly to America to get this since I cant seem to find it in Germany... Nice roasted flavors, slight coffee, burnt, raisins - like a stouts little brother. Slightly metallic end game. A nice double bock, but definitely does not deserve to be the #1 beer in Germany...

Bottle.  Clear and very dark brown pour, lasting carbonation/head and a light sweet plum aroma.  Flavor is creamy and slightly roasted malt, some plums and slightly sweet on the aftertaste.  Decent beer, but dont quite understand why its rated as high as it is.

Celebrator pours an inviting mahogany with a thin tan head. Theres a malty must in the smell with some spice in the background. Very similar flavors in the taste. Its full of malt but is subtly sweet, bread, and just a kick of spice at the back. Aftertaste of some chocolate and hazelnut. Its smooth, creamy, and amazingly drinkable
Bottle 0,5l. Very strong tar taste, maybe too much for my taste. Quite flat and long after taste.

Clear brown pour, little head dissipated quickly.  Malty aroma, reminds me of raisin bread.  The flavor follows the aroma with a touch of bitterness, just enough to compliment rather than overpower.  There is a hint of sweetness, but also not overpowering.  The flavor lingers nicely on the tongue.  I like this one.
Bread aroma and sweet malt.  Excellent flavor of malt and a small bite from the carbonation, alcohol on the finish.  This is a great beer.
Very malty in aroma and taste. Very smooth. Nice fruit background. Great beer

Pours rich ruby-brown, some translucence.  Even three-finger head.  Took multiple attempts to get it all in a 12oz. tulip.

Aroma is bready and rich.  Sweet malts, caramel, dark toast, pumpernickel.  Mild scents but indicating complexity.

Taste is part lager, part stout, part quad.  Rich but subtle roast up front, followed by malt sweetness.  Pumpernickel, oats, berries, toffee/caramel.  Nothing is big in here.  It has a wide array of flavors but all are just noticeably present.  

Very smooth and pretty light drinking.  Sweet aftertaste with no lingering roast or dryness.  Again, its not overly sweet.  

Better as it warms.  Remarkably so.  This is a beer I almost dismissed as I started it, but by the end I wanted another.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2016 At Bavarian Lodge in Lisle.  Very nice stuff. Very drinkable. Dried fruit flavors and smooth palate. None of the soy sauce flavor that some dopplebocks can have. Well done. Serving: Bottle
Great full bodied beer.  Bold in flavor and and strong aroma makes this a great beer.

33 cL bottle from Noble Green Wines poured into a Westmalle glass.   Dark black beer with a light head.  Looks the business.  Has an aroma of character, deeply fruity.  Has an excellent flavour of porter, trappist and stout.  This is truely excellent.  I am a Belgiumaphile when it come to beer but this is right up there, truely excellent.  Its an exquisite blend, both menacing and beautiful, as truely excellent Belgian trappists are.

If you enjoy this, go on to enjoy the Gouden Carolous Christmas beer as well - youll love it too!  I loved the Andecheser Dunkel - this is the best German beer Ive tried to date.  Its Belgium-tastic!!!
A very fine doppelbock. Toasty malt, some dark fruits, molasses all packaged in one bottle. A very nice beer that I would recommend.

Poured into a stange.

4.5 A: Dark brown color. Two fingers of light tan colored, creamy-as-hell head with excellent retention and some lacing.

4.5 S: Dark fruits are dominant in the aroma with the focus on raisin and prune. Sweet caramel and toffee maltiness next with evidence of alcohol.

4.0 T: Much, much drier than I was expecting based on the nose. Also much less flavorful than I was expecting. Toffee notes accompanies a light nuttiness. Raisin and other dark fruits again. Good, but the nose had me expecting big stronger flavors.

4.5 M: Velvety heavy medium body. Incredibly smooth, but could use a bit more carbonation. Slight warming on finish.

4.0 D: Good brew with no real problems.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-22-2009 00:33:09

On tap at SD Brew Co.  Dark brown-almost black, with murky brown tints.  Head leaves subtle lace.  Nose deep dark rich fruity.  Brown sugar and molasses below.  Taste big big roast malt, sweet spices and raisin.  Brown sugar.  Heavy.

330ml bottle pours a deep brown beer with a small tan head that leaves a nice laceing on the glass. Aroma is somewhat sweet with notes of dark fruit, brown sugars and malts. Also a slight alcohol note in the aroma but not to strong. Taste is great with malts up front a great body and a slight alcohol finish. An amazing beer that has tons of body and great flavor, very easy to drink and enjoy.

Pours a nice dark brown with a lighter tan head. Smells of nuts, some fruit sugars, and a bit of caramel. The taste is fantastic, with a deep malt background supporting various hop and fruit tastes. Nuttiness is very noticeable as well near the end. Finish is dry and pleasing. Extremely well bodied and rich, giving a sense of fullness when completed (I wish protein shakes tasted like this).

Bottle. Dark red brown color with beige head. Sweet Roasted malt aroma very gentle and soft, almost a dark Belgian smell. Soft mouthfeel delicate roasted malts and very low alcohol perception, so easy to drink.

Ho trovato la numero uno delle teutoniche( almeno stando a questo sito) davvero una birra eccellente, con un bel colore ambrato e schiuma abbondante. Aroma curato, tra malto e fruttato leggero. In bocca molto molto delicata.

First Boch beer in a long time. Poured from a bottle it has a dark appearance in the glass with a nutty aroma that is very noticeable. The taste has some figs & raisins but the nuttiness still is the dominant  taste. There is a smooth finish with a mild carbonation. Tasty beer.

Bottle from Brewery Creek in Vancouver. Pours a deep brown with thin head. Sweet taste of molasses and licorice, with some smoke. Nicely carbonated. Medium-thick mouth feel. Finish lasts and lasts. An exceptional beer.

Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle into a pilsner glass.

Pours a deep mahogany brown with ruby highlights and a 2-3 finger creamy khaki colored head. Good lacing.

Smell: Sweet caramel malt, raisins, freshly cured tobacco and a mild nutty aroma.

Taste: Bready malt and a faint hint of chocolate up front followed by caramel malt and dried fruit in the middle middle then finishing with a mix of nuttiness and hoppy bitterness. Aftertaste mildly sweet with a bit of bitterness. Extremely well balanced. Delicious.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Very smooth and somewhat creamy.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. The alcohol is completely hidden by the excellent flavor.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Arguably the best doppelbock in the world. You cant go wrong with this beer. Buy it.

bottle from market street.  poured dark brown with a beige head.  aroma was malty with hints of chocolate.  the flavor was pretty much the same but more like fudge than chocolate.  body was medium with creamy carbonation.
Another Beer I forgot to write notes about. This really reminded me of vegemite. Very smooth and well made, though I have had better doppelbocks, with more going on. Very yeasty. Some dark fruit.

Dark, dark brown nearly black in the glass with a nice tan head.  Aroma is smooth and sweet roasted malt with light background raisin/date - some light honey and caramel as it warms.  Smooth feel in the mouth with the sweet/roasted malt up front in the taste followed by a somewhat dry mid-palate (perhaps a slight bitterness from dated hops) and ending into soft and subtle dark fruit notes before a crisp and dry finish.  Great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2012 Bottle as Ayinger Winter-Bock. 2010, infected bottle:
Aroma: buttered corn on the cob. Taste: malty and roasted, with a dominating corn flavour and something like rancid butter. Score 1.4
2011, lets try again
Dark reddish brown with a medium-sized beige head that leaves lacing. 
Aroma: fruity, malty, lightly roasted.
Taste: large maltiness, sweet, svagdricka, some licorice, some butter, earthy bitterness.
Medium-bodied.

This was everything a doppelbock should be, from start to finish. Poured a dark mohagony with a thick lasting head. Tasted of roasted malts and was perfectly hoppy. What I liked about this beer is that it was thick but refreshing. That is a tough mix to find for me. I loved everything about this one.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Tämä bock näyttää valoa vasten katseltuna jotakuinkin Coca Colan väriseltä. Oluen päälle muodostuva vaahto on jotakuinkin beigeä. Tuoksu on tumman hedelmäinen, karamellisen maltainen ja lakristsinen, Makeahko, hieman kahvimainen, lakritsinen, miedosti humaloitu maku, jossa myös paahtuneisuutta. Maussa oleva katkeruus kääntyy loppua kohden kuivuuteen. Tämä on päivitetty arvio. Viime vuodelta olevaa arviota lukiessa tuntui, kuin olisi ihan eri oluesta kyse. Saattoi olla totaalisen epäonninen pullo kyseessä. 27-> 40 Aika kova pisteiden nosto. Kanatti kuitenkin kokeilla uudelleen, vaikka viime vuonna sanoin, etten niin tee. Mukava ylläri.

Ayinger Winter Bock. Pours dark brown with a fluffy brown head leaving nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, bread, sweet fruits, syrup and caramel. very nice aroma indeed. Fullbodied sweet and malty mouthfeel. Flavor is roasted, alcohol, fidges, chocolate and raisins. Lean and slightly acidy palate. Finishes with a great tart hoppy longlived aftertaste.

Bottle, 330 mL.  Extremely good!  Tastes of caramel, maltiness, some nuttiness.  Almost flowery at times.  Great flavor, great texture, pours a nice reddish-brown, just like the picture on the bottle.

Poured a dark brownish with slight dark ruby amber color.  Medium head.  Aroma of malts and candied fruits, raison,brown sugar.   Taste is medium sweetness with a slight bitterness.  Great complexity.  Creamy texture is very noticable.   Well balanced. Great smooth malty flavor.  Soft carbonation.  Just a touch of hop flavor.  Good stuff.  And it comes with a trendy ornament that you can hang on your ear...

Pours very dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is spices, roasted malts and alcohol. Flavor is a bit lighter than expected, but not in a watery way. Its mostly roasted malts and spices. Among my favourite winter beers.

Botlle thanks to The Wolf. Dark brown to mahongany with decent slightly offwhite head. Nice lloking beer. Really good aromas of toffee and dark fruits. Flavours are quite sweet as expected with some slight bitterness coming through on the finish. Fullish mouthfeel. Great beer.

330 ml bottle, BB reads 04.2011, into tulip. Pours creamy tan head with good retention & stickage atop of opaque yet clear dark brown body with ruby highlights. Aroma is rich maltiness with melanoidin-toasty qualities, dark fruits (plum, prune and dried grapes) originating from the malts used rather than fruity esters of yeast,  dark chocolate and some caramel. Malty flavor with melanoidin-toasty qualities, chocolaty with roasty notes, non-harsh alcohol warmth and some hoppy bitterness towards the finish which is quite dry for such a dark Doppel Bock. Very clean lager character with less fruitiness than in the aroma. The body is medium with moderate yet fine carbonation allowing smoothness to this nearly flawless beer.
In short: An excellent, rather dry  Doppel Bock with clean lager character.
Deep mahogany brown in color... Aroma of caramel and toffee...Flavor is not terribly rich, mouthfeel is kind of watery, nice notes of caramel, finish of maple syrup... Pretty good beer

Ive heard good things about this, and they were right.  Very good.  

Aroma: roasty, floral
Appearance: clear, brown, tan foam
 Taste:  lightly bitter, light sweetness, 
Palate: full body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter

Nagyon sötétbarna, de már inkább fekete színe van, szürkésbarna habja pedig krémes és könnyű, de nem túl kitartó. Az illata medvecukros, gyümölcsös, gyógynövényes és enyhén karamellás, a sokszor leginkább jelenlévő pörköltmaláta itt csak "másodhegedűs". Azonban az ízében már sokkalta inkább megjelenik, és kapunk egy füstös, dohányos ízhatást, ami az édeskés medvecukorral és líkőrös mellékízzel ötvözve egy nagyon eltalált valami, de tényleg. A lecsengése száraz, és nem túl édes, abszolút élvezhető, az alkohol is rejtve van benne. Elég testes, valahogy olyan nehéz, szirupos az állaga. Éppen ezért precíz kortyokban ajánlatos fogyasztani, kiélvezve az ízeket, és szinte mindig ad valami újat. Az biztos, hogy megéri az árát, még karácsonyi sörnek is el tudom képzelni.

Bottle from Alko.  Opaque dark brown beer with beige head. Terrific aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate and licorice. Pleasant malty taste with quite the same characteristics as the taste. Very soft mouthfeel and great balance. A true classic!

On tap at the Nook in Huntsville, AL. Pours black, with a minimal head and some lacing. The aroma is primarily dark fruits; plums and raisins in particular; molasses, and spices. The flavor is sweet, with a slight bitter finish. The palate is very heavy, sticky and syrupy. The mouthfeel is a little astringent, and there is bit of alcohol warming in the finish. Overall, very flavorful and forward.

Very dark brown with ruby and burnt orange highlights.  Clear when held to the light.  Decent head produced with the pour.  Tan with good retentin and nice lacing.  Complex roasty and smokey notes.  Seems to be a lot going on with the smell.  Dark, rich malt.  One review I read mentioned the smell of "lard" and Im certainly picking that aroma out.  Some chocolate in there also.  Again getting a roasty, smokey flavor.  A bit sweet, but not overly sweet.  Again, I am detecting that "lard" taste.  Different for sure.  Chocoalte is also coming through.  No real alcohol flavor, which is ok with me.  As the beer warms it becomes more rich in sweetness.  Medium to full mouthfeel.  Creamy and Smooth.  Almost an oily finish.  Plenty left on the palate.  Nice.  Very nice.  This beer may be a bit advanced for my amateur palate and nose.  This brew has a lot of different characteristics.  Honestly, it wasy not that easily drinkable for me.  This is probably a brew I will have to try again in a few yrs.  First Doppelbock I have ever tried and it was a bit overwhelming.
Pours brown with a begie head. Aroma and flavor is spicy and roasted malty. Nose has some toffee.
Pours a dark copper body with a medium sized head. Malty aroma with raisins and roasted notes. Fresh dark fruitiness with toffee in flavor. Very refreshing despite its strength. Really nice.
Pours a nice dark brown/black with whitish tan head; smells of sweet malt and Bavarian yeast; taste is nicely balanced bock with nice backgrounds of milk chocolate and coffee; a nice bock

Black body with a brownish creamy head.
Smooth medium body.  A slight sweetness ending with a sharp twist toward bitter.  Some notes of caramel?
Got better as it warmed.  Respectable brew but for the money I can find better.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours black, colalike colour with a fluffy beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, syrup and fudge. You can feel somekind of warmth in the aroma as well. Flavour is malty and sweet with tones of brown sugar and swedish limpa bread. Great and delicious doppelbock.

Dark reddish brown pour with a light tan head. Aroma is roasty, caramel malt and lots of dark fruit and berries. Just a trace of hops and alcohol. Flavor is caramel and chocolate malts with lots of underlying plum and raspberry flavor. Very slight bitterness and alcohol in what is otherwise a very clean finish. Body is rich but not chewy, quite pleasing to the palate. Great stuff.

Kissé aggódtam mert nekem a bak fajták édesek szoktak lenni plusz még a 6,7%-kos "kraft"... De kellemes meglepetés ért ízlett.
Mini buborékokból álló hab, jól zubogtatva a pohárba szemet gyönyörködtető átalakuláson ment át. Az először csak 1-2 centis sörmagasság csodálatosan emelkedett fölfelé és végül meghagyott kb. 3 újjnyi tetszetős capucinó barna sűrű habsapkát. Viszonylag sokáig meg is maradt. Sötétbarna sörlé ami éppen, hogy csak átlátni.  
Illata bódítóan édes, malátás, pirított, karamelles. Érdekes de íze egyáltalán nem gej. Végén barátságos füstös, hamus ajándék nagyon kicsi keserűséggel. Csak a szénsavasság hiányzott de az belefér.

This poured a deep reddish brown from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter, raising a thin khaki head that dissipated into a hint of lacing as I drank it down. With aromas and flavors of raisins, prunes, and double cream, this is silky smooth and a perfect accompaniment to roast fowl at your holiday table. Celebrator indeed, it is the brewers version of a mullet: half Belgian quad, half milk stout, and all party!

Bottle from the cheese shop across street that I can never remember name.  Pours a dark cola color with one finger of frothy creamy head.  Tastes of pure toasted malt, some caramel, tobacco, and coffee.  Very little hops or carbonation but really enjoyable.  sweet plastic goat.

500 ml bottle. Dark mahogany with reddish hues. Crystal clear. Tall off-white fine-laced head that clings to the glass. Delicate peppery malt aroma. Smooth texture. Crisp bitterness that balances the rich malts. Toffee and dark chocolate with hints of marzipan and soy sauce. Delicious and very delicate. Perfect carbonation. Nice refreshing bitterness in the finish. Excellent balance and a very nice beer.
330mL bottle.  Dark pour with a heavy tan head which dissipates quickly.  Nutty aroma and strong nutty flavor.  Mild finish.  Rich malty flavors.  Would make a great night cap beer.
Tried this Doppelbock and I cant wait for another. So much flavor. Its a pretty intense taste for those who are used to light beers.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 A: Cola-colored as it comes out of the bottle. A fairly-light cream head with minimum amounts of carbonation. In the glass, its a deep brown that is nearly opaque. Lacing in decent amounts as it goes down. Additionally, bonus points for having by far the coolest bottle I have seen to date, completed by the plastic goat.

S: Rich, rich malt with underlying complexity. Slight sugars of dates behind a caramel scent.

T: Very rich--much like the nose--and slightly sweet. Hints of light molasses, although the malt dominates--in a very good way.

M: Excellent creamy texture with low to moderate amounts of carbonation. Extraordinarily smooth with little to no alcohol presence.

D: Exceedingly drinakble. Beautiful taste and fairly light in body, combined with a low enough ABV to be quasi-sessionable, this is an excellent choice for the summer months ahead.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 Beautiful black color and off-white bubbly head. Aroma smells a bit like a clean wet dog as well as nutty. That probably doesnt sound like a good thing, but the aroma was my favorite part of this beer. I think my lack of experience with this doesnt allow me to give an informed rating on the taste. Its a good beer, but relative to some of my other favorite styles, there was nothing in the taste that jumped out at me. Edit on dec 4, 2011: taste rating has been increased. Good stuff!

Bottle courtesy of yngwie.Pours dark brown with an white head.Aroma is malty and spicy with some yeast, cocoa, coffee ,caramel and toasted malt.Flavor is sweet and malty with some beef stock notes.Medium body, average to soft carbonation, long malty finish.Very nice bock.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 Pours a rich dark, dark brown with a tight, frothy, creamy white head (ideally). Smells of fruits and roasted malts. Tastes strong, but not too strong, and has malty notes and faint fruitiness and some very subtle hops. Celebrator Doppelbock is full-bodied and creamy and has kinda thick texture and has  a surprisingly lively carbonation that isnt apparent until its in your mouth; the carbonation is a little off-putting and prickly. The finish is lightly smoky and a little dry. I think this is an alright brew, but not amazing.
A superb brew, balancing sweet grain, chocolate & caramel with non-hoppy bitter finish.  Particularly good with "Nonnis" brand biscotti.  Arguably the finest example of a doppelbock.
aroma- bread, honey, brown sugar, roasted malt, oatmeal.  pours dark brown red with tan head.  taste is roasted malt, bread, some rye flavors, honey. palate is medium bodied and carbonated.

this is exaclty the way i love my beer, full bodied and full of flavor. i was lucky enough to find a distributor to order me a case, wasnt cheap, but you cannot put a price on this beer. My favorite beer of my favorite style
bottle - dark brown beer with a nice beige head. Proper caramel toffee aroma! Flavour is very round. Lots of toffee and caramel with a thin hops note. Full body. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2013 Dark cocacolaish with small head. Aroma roasted malt, chocolate, plum. Taste  sweet and roasted malt, plum, yeast, bitter mocha. Full body, carb average. Finish bittersweet chocolate. Reminds of a porter.

12oz btl. Pours a rich dark deep brown with a thick light tan head. Strong aroma of nuttiness and candied fruit with a sweet malty foundation. Delicious distinctive aroma.Awesome medium to thick bodied mouthfeel. Sweet maltiness and caramel flavor leading into a dark fruit resonance.The candied fruit comes across so pleasantly almost pit fruit or plums. Nice molasses and toffee notes sneaking in there to.Rich but not overpowering. Great.

From a 12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Smells nutty.  Tastes sweet, chocolate, nuts, caramel.  No bitterness to speak of.  Tasty beer.  Love the little plastic goat that is tied to the bottle.
Very dark brown with two finger brown head. Aroma is nuts, caramel and a slight fruity tang. Flavor is roast and nuts. Crisp, with a light, nutty finish.

Bottle pours dark brown with small light brown head.  Aroma dark malts.  Taste dark malts with a bit of roast, really not much else.  Finish brief with mild hops.  Palate on the thin side, highly carbonated.  Alcohol not apparent.

Really kind of a disappointment after the good reviews.  Flavor is very average.  I would guess it would go well with anything since the flavor is so bland.

bottle, donated by pivnizub - slava! Deep brown, almost black colour, large beige head. Spicy nose with caramel and chocolate. Full-bodied, lots of caramel, chocolate and espresso coffee going on. Smooth palate, well-balanced.
Sweet malt aroma with a tart undertone. Flavor is bittersweet and vaguely burnt malt and alcohol. After-taste is slightly dry. Not my kind of "beer", I rather drink a cup of tea...
Pours dark chocolate with small tan head.Aroma is of fermented fruit and coco.It is great beer t for the fall,malty,smoth and rich.Over all great gift form bmoresnuggly.
Pours like dark muddy water, with a mid. ten head. Aroma of dark fruit. The palate does not last, great at the finish but drops off at the end. overall i would rate this beer a good one. So drink up.

i love this beer. in my thoughts i didnt think this beer had a great aroma, which in my opinion isnt a big deal though the appearance is great. i love the taste of this beer it doesnt sit in your mouth long but i like that and the taste is so smooth i could drink this beer with anything. continuing might thoughts on taste the the palate sucks it doesnt sit long but i really like that some people may beg differ... to eachs own...overall because nothing is perfect i scored it a 4 room for improvement but not needed.
Great tasting beer, was not impressed with the aroma, but my overall opinion is that this is a must try.
Dark brown, good thick head.  Aroma is brown grass and light toast.  Taste is very malty with some coffee and roastiness.  Mouthfeel is great - thick.  Im getting to like Ayinger too.

This beer is awesome! The aroma is pumpkin pie and cinnamon which I thought was very enjoyable. Not much head to speak of but what blew my mind is that the head turned red on the top when I first poured it before fading into tan. The taste was definitely malt based, you had this bready taste that slowly turned into coffee as it was held and then swallowed. The palate was full bodied and silky smooth. Celebrator was certainly a fitting name because it definitely made me want to celebrate.

Pours a black /  mahagony with a nice creamy lasting tan head. Aroma of sweet toasted caramel malts, dark dried fruit. Taste is a combination of sweet toasted malts dark fruits, raisins, some slight chocaltiness. Palate is nice full body, good carbonation, smooth creamy oily texture. Finish is toasted caramel malt, a lingering tangy flavor of dark fruits with some slight bitterness for balance. Overall a very nice and complex DB. Very enjoyable and tasty brew.

Pour a nice deep brown with a small disappearing head. The aroma has dark rye bread, pumpernickel, caramel, grain, wort, hints of smoke and chocolate. The taste is lovely with black malt, bread crust, caramel, nuts, smoke notes, the dry coffee taste of coffee powder. Soft and creamy palate. Everything about this beer is so subtle and insanely balanced. Just an insanely pleasant beer.

Bottle. Courtesy of EnjoyIt. Near-black pour with a small collar of iron foam. Very nice aroma, a symphony of different malt-types. There are lots of malty characteristics, chocolate and smoked malts being the most prominent. It smells like very dark bread (schwartzbrot), chocolate, nuts, coffee-beans. It is as though you are standing with pure, onprocessed black-malt of high quality. Taste is very much like the aroma. Black malts, some smoke, moderate but adequate bitterness, chocolate, coffee, some sugar and dark bread. Low carbonation, medium duration, medium-big body.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 A dark ruby red color to this one. Aroma dominated by malt and a touch of something else I cant place. Somewhat sweet taste, slightly roasty malt, nutty, slight alcohol; no hop presence.  Good, but maybe a bit too much like Cola. Needs to be a bit richer/thicker and less soda like.

Bottle.  Pours a mahogany brown with a quickly dissipating egg shell head.  Very fine carbonation.  Very fragrant.  Figs, cabernet grapes, and raisins are all present.   Extremely drinkable.  Flavor is a roasty presentation of dark molases and agave nectar beautifully balanced by a hop background.  Slippery mouthfeel and very full given the low abv.  Lives up to the hype.

12oz bottle poured into a dimpled mug.   This beer pours brown with a thin linen-colored head.  Smells of nuts, sweet molasses and alcohol dominate the nose.  The body is medium in heaviness with a nicely balanced carbonation and sweetness profile.  The molasses flavors compliment the sweet prune flavor while a nice hop bill compliments a bitter burnt malt flavor.  This beer lingers on the palate a bit allowing you to enjoy the complex flavors even after youre finished.
Pours dark brown with ruby highlights. Aroma is sweet, malty, and roasty. Flavor is rich caramel malt, roast, light fruitiness.
sjov kombo af sød duft rådden frugt og nødder/teak med en meget ulig tør og brødfuld hvedeagtig smag. Faktisk ret god med masser af carb og heavy feel
Bottle. Dark brown, body with an mocha/off-white head. No visible carbonation once poured. Sweet and creamy

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 14.11.2009.
Pours a beautiful dark brown colour with a large, slightly off-white head. Rich and medium sweet aroma of rye, roasted malts, flowers and citrus. Very good. The flavour is medium sweet with bread, mild roasted malts, syrup and mild smokiness too. Full bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Delicious Doppelbock.

Bottle. Nose is spice and coffee and dark fruit -- it almost smells like a date loaf or a good fruitcake. Pours an opaque matte brown-black; I can get light through it, but only if I hold it right in front of the bulb. Taste -- espresso, chocolate, malt sweetness, and an amazing mouthfeel like cream. It deserves the hundred.

Bottle at Teresas. Dark brown pour with a good head. Very malty nose. Tastes very malty with good balance of woody German flavors with alcohol peeping through the palate. Finishes cleanly like a good German style beer but with a slight stickiness with the malt. Great beer
From the tap. Dark brown in color with big, creamy head.  Sweet and malty aroma.  Taste is well-balanced: a little bit of sweet caramel followed by a pleasant hop bitterness.  Great lager!
Bottle pours clear dark brown color with off white head.  Aroma is malty sweetness with cinnamon, grape, and plum.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose and finishes semi dry.  Great brew.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a nice thick head. Aroma and flavour of dark fruit, yeast, hops, alcohol, caramel and toffee.

Nice malty aroma. Some hops present. Very dark brown with a fingers worth of thick tan head. Taste is heavy complex malt, tangy peppery hops, Dark fruits. Chocolate finish that lingers. Slightly hot alcohol. Palate is medium full but still remains somewhat crisp for such a malty rich beer. Overall this is very nice. I enjoy this beer and its a nice drinker. Goes down well for a rich beer.
From a bottle,dark brown,rich dark fruit flavor,very tasty,roasty,probably my favorite doppelbock.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a deep, fairly dark brown color, with a small to moderate off-white head.  The nose shows characters of caramel and complex German character malt notes.  Carbonation levels lift the flavors without thinning mouthfeel.  Hops to not play any sort of prominent role.  The finish is nicely malty, but otherwise beautifully clean.  The beer seems to achieve a flavor profile and level of drinkability that is seldom seen with other examples of the style.  Overall, clearly the benchmark against which all other examples must be measured; enjoyable in the extreme.

Pours a dark amber brown color with a thick white foam head.  Has a yeasty aroma of dark fruit and toffee.  Has a dry bitter taste with notes of dark fruit and caramel.  The mix doesnt work for me.  Too doughy.  Too sweet.  To each their own.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany with deep ruby and slightly orange hues on the edges. Slightly larger than average size, sticky, frothy, khaki colored head. Nice retention leaving a nice, thick, creamy layer of lace.

S - Dark bread aromas with a good amount of burnt molasses and brown sugar. A touch of licorice with plenty of dark fruit similar to other Doppelbocks with a slight touch of tart aroma. Nice touch of spice and herbal aroma in the background.

T - A good amount of burnt brown sugar/molasses with lots of toasted dark bread. Big kick of spice (mostly clove and pepper but others) mid sip with a good amount of grassy and herbal hop flavors with a touch of bitterness. Nutty and earthy flavors also come out mid sip. Some dark fruit (plum, fig, date, touch of raisin) provides a background taste through out. Also a slight tartness with that fruity flavor. Perfectly balanced flavors.

M - Medium body with a lot of carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy, but could use just a touch more for the style. Touch of a drying finish.

D - Pretty drinkable beer with perfectly balanced flavors. Only thing that really holds it back is the slightly sweet and drying finish.

Notes: Very good beer and a great example of a Doppelbock. Perfectly balanced with the dark bread, dark fruit, nut/earth, brown sugar/molasses, and spice with a good kick of hops, bitterness, sweetness, and tartness. Quite a lovely beer that I would definitely recommend.

Sötétbarna (a fény felé tartva, rubinvörös) a színe, közepes méretű, bézs habja viszonylag hamar összeesik és idővel nyomtalanul eltűnik.
Illata pörkölt és malátás, édeskés.
Íze medvecukros és melaszos, aromája pörkölt és enyhén füves ill. fűszeres.
Befejezése étcsokoládésan kesernyés, melengető és száraz, mely egy keserű utóízben marad meg.
Teste sima, az alkohol meg szinte teljesen rejtve marad, emiatt könnyen kortyolgatható.
Kerek és igen kellemes főzet Bajorországból.
Slightly alcoholic noise. Sweet scent. Wonderful palate, great long aftertaste, caramel, toffee, lasts a long time. Warming, medium to full bodied. Wonderful brown beer, not overly carbonated either.

330 mL bottle.  (2008 vintage).  Dark ruby brown with a beautiful brown head.  Lovely beer.  Medium malty aroma, with nuts, dates and cocoa powder standing out.  These same flavours swirl around in the taste, where they are joined by a hint of alcohol.  Beautiful dryish, bittersweet finish.  Full body.  Great beer.

Pours very dark brown-red.  Quickly vanishing beige head. Deep smokey aroma.  Very heavy mouthful and incredibly filling beer, like eating a delicious desert ... Fruity and sweet, lots of malt.  Very warm alcoholic feel without harshness like a good cognac.  Can only recommend!

Egészen sötét vörösesbarna színe van, szinte teljesen átláthatatlan. Vékony, krémes hab fedi be a tetejét, ami elég gyorsan semmivé lesz. Illata édeskés, melaszos, gyógyfüves, pemete cukros és gyümölcs likőrös, amibe egy kocka fekete csokit is dobtak. Nagyon összetett! Íze karamellás,medvecukros, pörkölt malátás. Van benne egy jó adag egy finom házi szilvalekvárból, Ferences barátok finom gyomorkeserűjéből, amit egy adag komlóval és egy kis eredeti magas kakaó tartalmú csokoládéval is megtámogattak. Ahogy melegszik a poharunkban ez a fantasztikus ital, úgy jönnek elő újabb és újabb ízek! Olajos teste van, de nem nehézkes, az alkohol is inkább a háttérből melegít és pont megfelelően buborékos. Utóízében sötét színű gyümölcsök, egy kis jóféle pipadohány is felsejlik és kellemesen keserédes, hosszan tartó. Komoly sör, különleges alkalmakra. Alkalmat pedig mindig találunk!

Smells really malty, chocolaty, coffeey... but it has like, this interesting sweet fruit lingering smell. Huh. Not quite opaque, but dark dark brown with red tones, creamy lookin head. Tastes roasty, well-balanced, Im really digging the fruitiness of the entire thing... compliments the chocolate flavor really well. Better with a slight bit of warmth. Creamysmooth palate, a little thicker than I thought itd be--which is good.

Nice aroma of dark fruit and biscuit.  Head disappears quickly but was a nice creamy, two-finger head.  Very viscious and thick mouthfeel.  Taste is of dark fruits with a bitterness that hits late and a nice, alcohol warmth to the aftertaste.  This is a great beer!!  Highly recommended.

Definitely one of the best beers in the world. Pours dark brown with nice thick head. Head stays for over 2 minutes which is really good. Aromas of coffee, chocolate, smoked wood chips, caramel and bread. Incredible taste and palate.

Very faint smell of french toast with wood chips sprinkled on top.  The flavor is slightly salty, but then again bottle was probably not kept very well.  Has a bit of roasty malt, cacao nibs.  Appears pitch soupy black, but with a red glow when put up to the light.
Aroma is coffee, figs.  Pours dark brown with a nice head. Great creamy mouthfeel. Nice beer.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown/Red, with a nice fluffy off white head. Smells of raisin and fig sweetness, and a light smoked malt. Flavors are complex,and are difficult to pinpoint for me with every sip. Raisin, Fig, Malt, Smoke, Chocolate, Coffee, Toffee. This Brew is incredible.
Smoky sweet malty aromas.  Good carbonation.  Alcohol well integrated.  Flavors of caramel and dried cherries.  Overall a very good dopplebock.

Bottle; from the ever generosity of Sir Mes. At home, watching tv and thinking hmm I need a descent beer and something to celebrate the start of the new football season with? Bang - that beer that Mes gave me!! Open it up. Pour it from the bottle into my Budvar stain glass. 

Opaque tar colour red on the edge, smells of raisins, figgs, toast. Drinks similarly, including chocolate, roasted malts, a nice blend of aged leather, some small notes of oxidisation, however extremely irrelevant, great drinkabilitiy, alcohol is there but not too harsh, just a great beer. Very heart warming and not burning which shows the delicacy of ths fine brew. Excellent.

Bottle. A strong malty aroma, bread, quite sweet. The head is large, creamy and beige with a normal duration. The body is dark red. The taste is very malty, some cacao and some chocolate. The body is very creamy and medium strong with a soft carbonation. A very good beer.
Brown with a nice dense grey head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel, basement, oak and smoke. The flavour is sweet and complex - full bodied and thick texture. A nice doppelbock.

Poured from 12oz bottle into Pilsner glass.

A - Pours a dark dark brown, if not black, with an light tan-colored head. After the initial pour, theres still a good amount of head retention and some lacing along the sides of the glass.

S - Sweetness is the main note right away - dark fruits, chocolate, and malts. Theres some oak notes in there as well, but truthfully, the sweetness is pretty overwhelming for me.

T - Roasted notes of malts, chocolate, coffee beans are the primary flavors on this beer. Its not as sweet as the nose suggests, which Im thankful for. There is some sweetness, but the roasted notes really balance this beer out nicely. Slightly bitter finish.

M - Medium to full bodied, lighter carbonation, rich and creamy on the palate. Creamy finish.

D - This beer is perfect if Im not looking for a huge stout or porter. Its great to have another option when its cold outside!

First I will say that after trying a few Doppelbocks. I am not into them. They are too malt liquor like for me. This is the best one I have tried but I will not be trying any more. Oily and licorice and stink. Not my cup of tea.

Pours magnificently dark (with some dark rasperrby ruby when held up to light) with a rich creamy head. The Nose is hard to describe, but it just smelled like beer, and nothin to really relish before the first sip. But its all a ruse! The taste is rich and surprisingly complex. Had a very silky texture with not much carbonation, letting your palate focus on the hard working flavors. The taste, however, is probably an aquired one. Its deeply smoky and reminded me of fresh wood. Quite malty, but it was malts roased over a smokey wood stove. Not bad, but not the bock (or doublebock) experience I was looking for.

11.2 oz bottle into my all-purpose Sam Adams glass. Aroma is raisiny, grain, hayfield. Pours a deep ruby red with a nice beige colored head that hangs around for a few minutes, then dissipates, leaving a collar of foam and creamy lace. Taste is grainy and meaty. Taste is malty sweet with little bitterness. Carbonation is high, body is full. Finish is long and full of grain. This is a good, quality beer, but not as good as I remember.

Burnt amber and garnet drown in a sea of browns and blacks while a cappuccino head hovers with little lace to speak of at the moment. As I admire my Celebrator sitting pretty in a proper Ayinger Celebrator bock glass, I fall in love once more as her bouquet of aromas reach my nose. Black fruits, burnt caramel, black strap molasses, figs, dates, prunes, licorice root, cherries with their stones, black plums, and apples. Phew! None dominates the other; instead they weave in and out of the other with subtle finesse. Of course, in a balanced doppel-bock, this is what you want. We may be old friends, but that doesnt mean I am any less eager to dive in. Creamy and light sweetness evolves into tart prunes and black-skinned plums. A bitter finish is charred wood and burnt sugars. The middle of her palate is the heaviest while her front and finish are lighter on the senses. Truffle powder and bakers chocolate are wispy after-images and in my breath there is a faint kiss of boozy warmth. Imperial by no means, Celebrator is still a doppel-bock which means a more pronounced ABV than the standard bock. Black licorice and black strap molasses offer an earthy presence while someone somewhere is smoking a cigar. It all sounds complicated, but her palate caresses my tastebuds with ease, each flavor melding, melting, and weaving into the other. It should come as no surprise then that even with tasting notes, my glass empties rather quickly.


The Ayinger Celebrator was my first doppel-bock and is still my favorite, of that style at least. A little known fact about bocks in general is they are part of the lager family. Dark, light, I dont really care. Its about flavor, and Celebrator is where it is at for this style.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2016 very dark clear brown, smooth lacing light brown head.
faint dark fruity, dark malty aroma. good aroma
flavor is roasted stuff, dark malts, dark caramel, dry, hops used to do some balance, but blends in real well. nutty. aftertaste is roasted malts, dark caramel, dryness.(7,4,7,4,16)
rerate clear brown, smooth brown head. mild boozy, mild wheaty, mild dark fruity aroma. some roasted malts, some dark caramel.Flavor is dark bitter caramel, malts.  a bit onesided flavor but with a good solid herbal bitterness consisting of both malts, caramel and herbal notes probably from hops.

Bottle- Deep ruby red with a light off white head that fades to a light lacing.
Dark fruit, roasted malt, sweet with hints of chocolate. A lot going on here.
Initially chocolate and malt with hint of spices. Finishes with an excellent touch of bitterness.Medium body, light carbonation, silky smooth & creamy. Very satisfying. Delicious, probably one of the best dobbelbocks I have tasted. One of the few beers that lives up to the hype.

Bottle, thanks secret summer santa! pours a dark, dark brown with reddish highlights and a fizzy tan head that quickly fades. Aroma isnt big and in your face. Had to really fill my lungs a few times on this one. Obvious caramel and dark fruits, plums, a little bit of sour smokiness, and as usual for me in bocks; a hint of tomato purée. Not sure what does this, perhaps the hops. Its what always drags them down for me anyway. Obviously quite sweet at first, its got this smoky sourness and metallic/tomatopurée hop finish that balances it out. Very creamy and silky in the mouth though, Ill give it that.

Appearance:  beautiful--nearly black with ruby notes that fade to rich red-gold when you tip it; short bubbly tan head that quickly fades; no lacing.  Aroma:  raisins, figs,earth and smoked wood; rich vanilla, caramel and toffee notes with roasted grains and nuts; a little like a sauna, actually, but in a good way.  Taste:  magnificent--rich and malty, sweet but not overpoweringly so; maple syrup and brown sugar; toasted brown bread; hint of hops at the end.  Finish:  lingering and dry, with a little caramel sweetness balanced by the light hops.  Notes:  Absolutely incredible.  Not as cloyingly sweet as some doppelbocks.  Rich and velvety in the mouth, with a nice hit of carbonation up front and light hops in the back to balance.  My new favorite beer--move over, Chimay Rouge!

33cl Bottle bought in Rome. Clear dark reddish brown colour, off white head. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, burnt sugar, liquorice (drop), a little alcohol. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel, fruity, light roasted malts, nice bittersweet finish with liquorice/drop in the aftertaste. Medium bodied. Really good indeed.

Pour into New Belgium Globe glass

Pours a thin light tan head, that fizzles down quickly. No lacing noted. Color is a dark dark ruby red (almost black).

The aroma has some what of a fruity smell to it. Almost like a banana and clove aroma. Taste is very smokey. Its a very hard flavor to distinguish, but it resembles some sort of grape that may have been roasted or something.

Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Leaves a very dry aftertaste in the mouth. Carbonation level is low.

Overall, this wasnt something that appealed to me very much. I had much higher expectations for this beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-14-2008 00:30:03
Strong, but smooth as well. Taste is caramel and roasted nuts. Pours a dark amber with a light brown creamy small head..

I can see why people like this one.  Thick dark syrupy vanilla and maple, great aroma, sweet, but not too thick mouthfeel.  Unfortunately, I like my beer bitter and this one want very.  Good, but not the style for me.
bottled pours almost black with a large tan head. aromas of chocolate, and caramel. it is yeasty, with a smooth chocolate flavor. lasting sweetness with a touch of sour. solid beer.

330mL Bottle -- Pours very dark reddish-brown, almost black, with a small light tan head.  Aromas of roast, caramel, molasses, raisins, milk and dark chocolate, wood, and some smoke.  Big malty front-end with a very smooth and silky mouth feel.  One of the best finishes on a beer I have tried.

Bottle. Aroma is brown sugar, dried figs, toffee and caramel. Appearance is a woody dark brown color with a thick layer of tan head. Excellent lacing around the glass. Taste starts off with strong roasted malt and fresh caramel flavors along with molasses, spiced bread, candied dates, cocoa and raisins. Mouthfeel is silky and creamy with medium carbonation and a dry finish. Its extremely smooth and rich with lots of complex dark sugar and dried fruit flavors. Without a doubt the most flavorful and delicious of all Doppelbocks.

Pours a very dark black-ruby.  Aroma is roasted malts, caramel and chocolate. Taste is sweet with some coffee like bitterness, the finish is sweet.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth and syrupy.  The alcohol is very well hidden.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Rich brown body. Dense looking. Khaki foam on top maintains nice levels and consistent lacing

S: Roasted malts. Black strap molasses. Rich fresh baked bread. Sweetness.

T: The black strap molasses character dominates with subtle undertones of caramel, bread, biscuits, roasted malts and a dash of cream. A tiny bit of alcohol as the beer warmed.

M: Smooth. Silky. Lower carbonation levels work well here. Nice finish. 

O: The overwhelming sweetness becomes a little cloying by the end of this glass.  But thats pretty much the style and this is the best in the bunch.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from the Leesburg Wegmans. 
It pours a ruddy brown color with a large, active, tan head.  The nose is sweet with dark brown sugar, a pinch of dark honey, and a hint of vanilla.  Very nice!   The flavor has notes of brown sugar, molasses, dark honey, and that vanilla again.  Light enough to be sessionable, but enough flavor to be satisfying.  A bit of nuttiness and a slight sour/bitter note emerges as the beer warms.  Medium in body with soft, smooth carbonation and a lingering sweetish yet dry finish.  I see why this brew is so highly rated!  Very tasty stuff indeed, especially for the malt lovers.

330 ml bottle from Jungle Jims.  Awesome-looking bottle, and I love the little goat ornament hanging from it.  Great design.  Anyway, pours a cloudy chestnut brown color with almost no head.  Notes of Bavarian malts and hops, nuts, smoked wood, roasted malts, caramel, toast, and a little spice that seems like rye.  These notes come together better in the flavor than in the nose.  This is definitely the best doppelbock Ive ever had; its just not a style that does a lot for me.

Bottle, 50cl. Pours a clear and dark mahogany beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, caramel and butter and/or butterscotch. The flavor is malt and caramel. The palate is sweet. Overall a good, but sweet, beer.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 Damn!! why did this take soo looong; have always loved bocks and this would be why;  wow!!  very complex aromas; beautiful dark brown pour w/minimal head.  perfect blend of alcohol roasted malts caramel smoke and slight hops

Enjoyed from 12 oz bottle.  Aroma is of plums and malts.  Appearance is pure black with a very dark amber around the sides of the glass, barely any head.  Taste is pretty good, definite dark fruit characteristics with a malt backing, not really getting any hops, a very complex bock beer, but Im not really a fan of bocks.  Im happy I tried once.
