Whatever i say about this great beer is not enought, just find it and taste it.
Aroma is spicy with some sweet notes. The beers is dark red with huge foam. The flavor is also spicy.

Aroma - Very pleasant and complex. Initially notes of cherry and red apples which developed into earthy, malty smells.

Appearance - Pours damn near black. Once held up to the light an interesting deep amber color becomes apparent.

Taste - The first wave is primarily malty with hints of cherries and alcohol. After a few seconds the taste of molasses becomes very apparent. After you swallow, it takes three or four seconds  for the after taste of grapes and earthy flavors to kick in.

Overall - Very good beer. Definitely something to have in celebration of something like the US qualifying for the round of 16.

Poured with dark brown color and a tan lacing head. Strong roasted malts,  lots of caramel, some licorice, coffee, hops and a hint of burnt wood in the aroma. Sweet taste, slightly smokey in a medium dense body. High carbonation makes this beer a lively one. Alcohol is present, but not bothering. Good!
Pours a dark brown/cola color.  Aroma of roasted grain and molasses.  Flavor of sweet molasses and toasted grain.

Draught.  Pours dark ruby red/brown with a small tan head.  Aromas of dark roasted malt, toffee, caramel, and a touch of cocoa.  Flavor is sweet milk chocolate and brown sugar.  Creamy and warming.  Pretty nice.

What a nice little feature with the plastic acessory on the  bottle neck . A nice little white buck. A 33 cl bottle from Ølbutikken, that lately has brought quite a few german beers in. This double bock pours a dark brown with a firm and thick head with a nice off white head. Very nice looking. The nose is first of all very malty. Next I sense some calm smokyness, resins and cloves. The taste has alot to offer. Complex malt tastes where again I believe that there must be some smoed malts added. Roasty flavours again with feelings of dried fruits like resins, dried plumps and dark apricots. A nice bitterness with a fine and tickeling palate with a roasty sweet finish
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is breaddy malt, roasted notes and light hop. Flavour is sweet breaddy malt, fruity notes and light hop.

Poured into a stemmed glass. Had a nice malty/chocolatey aroma to it. The color was much darker than I expected. It was nearly dark enough of a black that you could not see through it. The taste followed the same pattern of the aroma with the malty chocolatiness. The palate was left dazzled with a nice coffee taste that made the fact I had several of them at my disposal all that much better. This is definitely a beer worth having again.
Bottle. Very dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Aromas of chocolate malt and raisin. Strong dark malt backbone with pronounced dried fruit, chocolate, and smoke. Almost a chewy mouthfeel.

On draft in one of those Celebrator glasses from the picture.  Poured a red-brown with a thick off-white head.  Roasty malt, hints of coffee and cacao without being too bitter.  Nice and smooth in the mouth.

Poured a slightly reddish black with an off-white head.  Aroma of chocolate malts and coffee with a hint of vanilla.  Taste is mainly of chocolate malts with some dark fruit.  Smokey flavors combine with a creamy chocolate finish.  Some alcohol present.

Wow, fabulously complex.  Nose is strongly of molasses with hints of fig newtons, raisins, licorice and soy.  Soft tan head on dark ruby and brown beer.  Roasty with a stronger soy presence on sipping.  More bitterness than anticipated but not at all out of proportion to the malt.  Alcohol flavor is present but light.  Very warm, long finish.  A wonderful beer.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Dark brown pour with an amber hue off white creamy head ... sweet caramel and roasted malt aroma .... taste of dark fruits, caramel, chocolate and roasted malts with a light smoke in the finish does have a bit of alcohol in the flavor .... a big beer with a full mouthfeel but tons of creamy flavor

It pours dark brown with an inch tan head. Aroma of honey, toasted malt and toffee with note of flowers. The flavour is really complex for a dopplebock. You can feel sugar cane and honey as well as coffe and toasted flavour with a light hoppy background. The body is medium but not too strong or alcoholic.
A very balanced Dunkel Dopple Bock. Definitely a must-have beer.

Paired with a typical Italian dish "fagioli con le cotiche" ("fasoeu cui cudich" in Milanese dialect :-) ) stewed beans with pork rind.

(bottle, sampled 2/13/10). Clear dark brown color. Small off white head. Sweet caramel malt aroma and flavor. Short duration. Smooth finish, with light alcohol. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

Is there any barley left in bavaria or is it all in this beer? Pours an explosively foamy deep reddish brown.  Great lacing.  Just a spectacular beer.  Staggeringly complex - just when you think youve got a handle on the array of malt flavours in there, the wonderful fragrance of the hops hits you - and the well incorporated alcohol enlivens it and ties it all together.  An absolute joy to drink.

The beer pours a hazy dark brown color with a nice tan head. The aroma is toffee, chocolate malt and some bread. The flavor is more complex with some dark fruit and roasted malt early in the taste and then chocolate  and coffee later. Medium, slightly watery mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A truly world class beer.
Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head.  The scent is heavy in malts.  The taste is great with a nice sweetness to start followed by roasted malt and molasses to finish.

12oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours very dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of smoky, roasted malts.  Initially there is a sweetness in the mouth, followed by a crisp hops flavor, and then there is a finish of malt with a hint of alcohol.  A very good beer.  Probably the best/most complex doppelbock Ive had

Bottle at No5.
Red-brown with a light brown head, quickly gone. Aroma heavy malty (roasted, overripe fruit, coffee, chocolate). Flavor heavy sweet, moderate bitter, well balanced. Full body. Really a nice surprise from Jan B, Sofielyst.

Tap at Jimmys No. 43, during the Mike Lovullo Tasting Session. Poured deep, dark brown with ruby highlights and a large, strong beige head. Heavy malt aroma, some fruit and loads of sugar. More dark, sweet malt in the flavor, molasses, licorice, some maple syrup, and mild tartness. Hints of smoke in the finish. Full-bodied with smooth though crisp carbonation. Velvety, a bit syrupy. Certainly one of the the preeminent bocks out there. Delicious and well-rounded.

Deep brown/mohogany. Nose is a rich malty chocolate/licorice with sweet old fashioned caramel candy and smoked meats. Incredible. Nearly perfect mouthfeel, medium+ bodied and lingering. Taste is slightly darker than the nose would suggest, leading to some complexity. Chocolate, caramel and ripe plum. I think the aroma is the selling point, but a very nice beer.

From the 330 ml. bottle with a white plastic ram hanging off the neck of the bottle. That was different. It pours a nice looking brown with hints of red and a quarter inch tan head.  The aroma is nice and malty as well as a little nutty. The mouthfeel is bold and pleasant.  The taste is of bitter malts and a tad sour but in an inviting sort of way.  Smooth through and through and quite drinkable.

11.2oz bottle from total wine in norfolk. pours a dark, chestnut brown with a fizzy, half-inch, light tan head leacing a nice ring of lace. aroma is very nice with notes of toffee malts, light chocolate, and winter spices with hints of sugary, wheat cereal, toasted nuts, and dark, vinous fruits. flavor quite tasty as well with big, sweet, caramel malts, toffee, and dark fruit notes up front backed by light, bitter chocolate, coffee, and a hint of burnt wheat. palate is medium bodied but a bit watery with high carbonation and a lingering, malty finish. overall, a tasty dopple but im having a hard time seeing it as the #1 version.

33 cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a tight tan head. Rich aromas of toffee, dark fruit, and caramel, with some roastiness. Nice malty flavor, with hints of the dark fruit and nuttiness. The finish is smooth and slightly hoppy. Great beer!!!!
Pours a dark brown color. Aroma smells of coffee slightly. Smooth finish. Hint of sweetness to it
Aroma is dark fruit and malt.  Taste is sweet malt, dark fruit, maybe molasses, roasty.  Mouthfeel is fairly unique - sticky yet dry, creamy.  Not a huge bock fan but this is nice.

Ayinger Hotel Brauerei, Aying, Germany.  Stem glass.

Aroma: caramel, toast, earthy, smoke.  Appearance: dark brown, tan foam.  Taste:  light sweetness.  Palate: light carbonation, oily feel.  Overall - one of the best beers Ive had the privilege of drinking.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2014 Bottle 33cl. A copper-black ale with low carbonation. Deep ale with heavy caramel-roasted-malty flavour associated with a dry-bitter finish. Some notes of grapes, licorice, nuts, dried fruits and lightly vinous.Very special beer quite intresting, once we start to drink its impossible to stop ... Near to an eisbock.
Re-rated, extremely complex for this alcohol level, lot of chocolate and dark chocolate, smooth, excellent stuff

Pours almost black with no head or lacing. Smells smoky and earthy.  Tastes exactly like it smells except with a tinge of licorice.  If you like smoky beers then you may like this one, I didnt, but thats just me.

Pours black with a minimal mocha head. Aroma is malty and with a nice dark chocolate smell to it, there is also a licorice or sugar like aroma evident. The taste is filled with roasted malts and chocolate, it is also slightly bitter too. Full bodied and smooth, but the carbonation is kind of flat. Overall though an excellent beer, highly enjoyed.
Bottle at Pike Cafe poured into a tulip glass.  Beautiful reddish brown body with thick brown head.  Sweet and delicious with flavors of caramel, dark fruits, candied suger, and chocolate.

Bottle. Dark brown with ruby highlights. Beautiful laced head. Complex and rewarding character of chocolate, caramel, licorice, dark fruits - blackcurrants, raisins. Sticky mouthfeel. Superbly balanced. Dried fruit finish. Gorgeous beer. Cheers Matt for sharing.

A- Pours a translucent deep mahogany with a thin tan head. Head fades to a thin collar but there is some lacing left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is a mix of rich caramel, chocolate malt, and molasses.

T- Upfront is semisweet chocolate malt with some caramel and molasses. A touch of toasted bitterness is added to these characters for the finish and almost nothing lingers.

P-Medium carbonation and medium weight body, though somewhat chewy. Goes down smooth.

O- This is a wonderful beer. Best example I have had of this style. Its not too complex but very smooth and drinkable. Nothing is cloying or overpowering...on the other hand nothing is thin or underrepresented. Just a great example of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-06-2008 04:07:41

This is a full bodied doppelbock with a creamy half inch tan head.  Dark earthy body with tiny tight bubbles and a beautiful balance between hop and malt.  Sweet and grassy while yummy roasted hops shine through with a drawn out finish.  Well carbonated and elegant.

11.2 oz bottle- Pours dark brown to almost black much like the Taddy Porter just before it, aroma is very sweet and a strong  brown sugar presence. The flavor is the same, brown sugar with some caramel malt also, probably the best dopplebock Ive had.

330cl bottle. Gorgeous, huge frothy head. Very dark in color, almost stout-like. Nice fruity aroma with some hops and some caramel. Taste is pleasant and a little hoppy, with a little chocolate in the aftertaste. Overall an enjoyable beer.
This is a great beer with a nice smooth finish, one of the more enjoyable ones that I have tasted recently.

Small bottle. Pours a dark burgundy with a nice beige head. Aroma is very earthy and woodsy (reminds me of camp). The beer is sweet and chocolaty, a little thin, with a very nice and mellow oak flavor. Finishes a little bitter and dry. Awesome doppelbock.
330mL bottle, pours very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of rich roasted malts, nuts and coffee. Flavour is very malty, dark chocolate and some sweet notes. Fantastic doppel.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 0,33 l bottle, bought at Beer-Imperium, Vienna. BBF:02/10.
Deep ruby colored, oily liquid arrives in my snifter with a small delcious lacing tan-off white head. Aroma of the style with roasted malt, tons of caramel, dried fruits like plum and raisins, some coffee, minimal hop. The beer has an oily texture with a smooth mouthfeel, fine carbonation brings the well rounded feeling of roasted grains, liqueric malt, some alcohol with a fruity notes of plum, raisins again. Dry, roasted but sweet malty aftertaste with some hop lurking in the background. Classical one.
Bottle. Very nice malty example of a doppel, finishes very dry. Roasty and a bit sweet.

Has some similarities to other Doppelbock beers from Bavaria in terms of color, foam and taste. Its got a darkbrown-golden color and a malty, aromatic taste. Id say its one of the best Doppelbock beers out there even though theres quite a tight competition between this one and others from the same region of Germany.

Complex flavors of choc, dark fruits, tobacco, smoke layer in a malty darkness... Not any real discernable hops to speak of... Body is medium full and a touch creamy... Nice white head... sticky, lingering mouthfeel...

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 Pours a deep mahogany with creamy beige head.  Awesome aroma of roasted malt, coffee, molasses, caramel.  Flavorful and smooth to the end - alcohol hidden quite well.  Wish I had more of these!  Hard to beat anything put out by Ayinger - PROST!
Fantastic - I mean - really - maintains a heady feel throughout the entire experience.  So full bodied yet - smooth and light,   This is the DPL to compare all DPLs to.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 Bottle at Bishops Arms, Skövde. Dark amber beer, very nice lasting, beige head. Roasted toffee aroma, malty, chocolate, figs, raisins. Malty roasted flavor, toffee, caramel, figs, chocolate. Lovely body, roasted toffee finish.

Old rating: 7/4/8/4/14
Dark amber color, beige/brown head. Malty roasted, somewhat sweetish aroma. Sweet toffee and chocolate flavor, roasted and a little spicy.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a stange glass. The back label lists the abv at 6.7% however there is no freshness date. 

Appearance: The body has a very dark brown color in the glass and when held up to light it has nice garnet highlights. Some small bubbles of carbonation can be seen in the highlights and near the edges of the glass. On top sits a tight head of light brown foam which slowly settles down to small cap that hangs on till the last sip. Lacing is slick and slides right down the glass as I drink.

Smell: In the nose I get notes of sweet caramel, fresh sweet bread, ripe fruit and a kiss of German hops.

Taste/Palate: The flavor has a sweet overall character with moderate hoping that comes through in the end to finish things up without becoming too sweet or cloying. Up front are the caramel candy, brown sugar, light molasses and brown pear like fruit notes. Towards the finish bready notes become more toasted and mix with some light hop flavors to temper the overall sweetness. The finish is short and still on the sweet side but in a good way. Carbonation is lively enough to lift the palate of the solid, smooth, and full body and leave you wanting that next sip.

Notes: All I need to say here is outstanding!!! When I think about Doppelbock beer this is the beer I will think of and compare all others to.

500ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with a one finger deep tan head and sticky lacing.  Aroma of toasted grain, honey, raisins, brown sugar, and dark fruits.  Taste is sweet grain, bread and caramel with a nice touch of hop bitterness that fades without any lingering character. Light roasted malt and some dark fruit.  Full bodied with an excellent smooth mouthfeel. Nice beer.
pours a dark brown with lasting head and lacing. aroma is raisin and bacon which carries over into the flavor. smokey.

500 ml bottle, Winterbock. Dark red to brown body, beige head. Aroma has malt and sugars, some butter. Sweet malty flavour, some roasted malt, spices and a fruit, mainly plum. Quite bitter, but well balanced.

Dark reddish tint when it hit the glass. Did not leave much lacing like I thought it would being a thicker looking beer. Had a nice malty caramel flavor. Tasted some chocolate. Finished buttery with the alcohol lingering on the tongue.  Great bock.

one of Germanys finest.. this brew has a lovely mouthfeel, very smooth oily and creamy..malty aroma, taste of caramel, complex malts and some fruit notes..as a hophead I do miss the hops here, it could use a touch more but i guess thats not what this brews about...very enjoyable

12oz bottle.  Pours brown, medium body, with a two finger light brown head.  Maintains only a small cap and doesnt leave but a few spots of lacing.  Aroma is raisin and other dark fruits, malty, bready, toffee, caramel, a little chocolate and some alcohol.  Rich and fairly complex aroma.  Flavor is malty, chocolate, toffee, caramel, dark fruits, some alcohol.  Slightly sweet, but finishes rather dry.  Body felt thin, low carbonation.

Bottle.

Dark amber with a creamy tan head. Sweet aroma of malt, raisins, dried berries, coffee and some alcohol. Taste of syrup, brown bread, brown sugar, malt. Complex and interesting, a very good beer. Long aftertaste, the alcohol was well hidden. Earlier Rating: 1/29/2010 Total Score: 4Bottle.

Deep brown, almost black. Large brownish head that disappeared rather quickly. 

Nice aroma of malt, caramel, dark bread, brown sugar and some coffee. 

Sweet taste but not too sweet. Malt, raisin, dried fruit. Medium body with a rather stycky feeling. Very pleasant to drink. Aftertaste was dry with some nice bitterness.

Very dark brown, not much head. Aroma is huge malts, dark fruits and some breadiness. Flavor has big dark fruits up front, roasted malts. Some biscuitness, and then finishes slightly dry with a touch of smoke and chocolate. Really nice beer, good balance--alcohol is present but not too much. Very drinkable and really tasty.

Very rich dark brown on pour with an almost caramel colored head. The nose is filled with roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, and a heavily sweetened ice coffee. This is a big and rich doppelbock that has a smooth and balanced mouthfeel. It has a complex malt flavor with a surprisingly buttery finish that leaves your mouth watering for more.

Poured a very dark amber with a thin off-white/tan head. Aroma and taste: coffee, roasted malts and black berries. Nice enough body. This was my first Doppelbock; with that said, this beer has the character of a Porter in many ways. Overall: good, but not great. Glad I tried it once.

Pours deep dark amber with fluffy tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, alcohol, some skunk, spice, and black licorice.  Taste is spice, bread, dark fruit.  Extremely smooth profile, but was expecting a bit more flavor kick.  Alcohol warmth on the end.  Mouthfeel medium.  A good doppelbock, but certainly not the top of the ladder.
Jet black pour from bottle.  Coffee and grass on the nose.  Sweet malty taste finishes with a mild warming of alcohol.  Great doppelbock!

Pours dark brown with a thick whippy white head.  Aroma is of sweet malt, cereal and a pleasant milky smell.  Taste is of sweet malt, caramel, alcohol and cereal.  Very good.  The best Bock Ive ever had!

The label and name, both reeking of pompous Bavarian old-school grandeur lures me with promises of sweet delight. Fortunately, Im not disappointed. This cloud brown dobbelbock pours a finger-thick head of dense, long-lasting foam and looks good. Nose is toffee, booze and burnt toast. Its oily palate delivers the follow-up, with an original and complex blend of mellow caramel, dark malts and bread. The celebrator lives up to the name: theres definitely a party going on in my mouth! :-D This beer oozes and flows around in my mouth, giving me velvety caresses and subtle touches of malted goodness. Its delicious creamy palate making me drink this rather strong brew down way faster than I should. If someone could ever make a beer with more of all this, and yet as drinkable, Id be a True Believer. Right now, Im close as it is.

Dark brown with some hints of blue and black in there with a nice frothy white head. Aroma of dark fruits, light hops, caramel and dark malts, quite complex. Taste is pretty much the same, good carbonation and a nice bitter hop and barley finish. One of the most drinkable beers Ive ever had.

12oz bottle. Pours deep, dark chocolate with a creamy tan head. Very little lacing. Nose of cocoa, dates, toffee and malt. Mouthfeel of semi-flat soda. Taste of raisin, roasted malt, molasses, and licorice. A standard for the style.

beer  from allen     reddish brown beer with a slightly offwhite head.smells malty and of fresh breadcrust, hidden alcohol, bitterswetness, hidden fruits and hops. tasts of dried pears and plums, fresh bread, bittersweet, hops. aftertaste is bittersweet with a hidden alcoholic warmth. in aftertaste is some bitteralmond like taste too, who turns even cherry-like at the end. good beer , alcohol is not harsh, interessant flavors.

This was awesome. I dont like Doppelbocks all that much, but this made me a believer. Smooth and velvety with roasted malt undertones not too overpowering. Ever so slight hop tinge, but full in the mouth. Delicious and satisfying!

Pours slightly hazy brown color with a nice beige head. Aroma is sweet sugary and malty. Flavour is wonderfully of chocolate, coffee and nicely malty. Bit oily mouthfeel, ends slightly dry. Another wonderful beer from Ayinger that I got to try out.
Dark brown pour -off white head -lots of flavour caramel, friuty, roasty, nuts, spice . Finishes  dry and a bit sweet. good beer

Bottle. 

Deep brown color with a big off-white head. Some lacings. 

The aroma is nice and malty with big notes of bread, fudge, cola and earth. Some leafy hops and sweet fruity notes as well. 

The flavor is sweet, malty and spicy. Full-bodied and smooth with a decently dry finish. Notes of caramel, raisins, sweet cherries, fudge, cola. Ends somewhat bitter with notes of rye bread, leafy and spicy hops and well-integrated alcohol.

Nice one, complex for the style and very "German" in character. Can someone please pass me the sauerkraut?   Earlier Rating: 1/15/2010 Total Score: 3.5Bottle.

Deep reddish brown with a small tanned head that dissipates quickly and barely leaves any lacings.

The aroma is filled with layers of malts - sweet caramel, toffee, milk chocolate and rye bread - and a decently integrated layer of German style leafy and herbal hops. 

The smell makes me think "German Scotch Ale), but with the taste, were back in bock-country. Its stil very malty, but more bready and toasty rather than caramel-like. Not too sweet flavor actually. Some notes of toffee though. Some leafy hops that get accentuated in the finish which is mildly bitter with some herbal notes, gentle spicy hops and stale bread. 

The body is somewhere around medium, quite a lot of carbonation and actually semi-dry in the finish. 

A good beer. The flavor is not as complex and layered as the smell, which is a bit of a letdown.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Vinny. Pours a beautiful velvet, lush, deep mahogany with a one-finger, creamed out beige head. Aroma is pungent and sweet. Nose is figs, vanilla, cream, raisins, plums, chocolate, and traces of cinnamon. Body is full, heavily complex and soft on the tongue. Palate is sikly smooth with a nice warming in the throat. Excellent, unique dopplebock.

A: A 330 ml bottle poured into a mug. The beer is a dark, dark brown with some highlights of red. The head is small and light brown.

S: The smell is roasted malt, molasses, and a bit of caramel.

T: Now, I must say, that Ive never been a huge fan of doppelbocks. This one, however, has a flavor unlike any other that Ive had. A wonderful mix of roasted malt, caramel, and molasses to provide sweetness. The hops dont make themselves too known, but certain give some balance.

M: Moderate carbonation and rather on the full body side for a lager.

D: This beer is highly drinkable. Its still something I probably wouldnt sit down and drink four of in a sitting, but its got some great flavors and the alcohol is very moderate.
I love this beer. All the dark chocolatey vanilla flavor you want, with a medium body, no ashiness, and incredible ease of drinking. Not too sweet, either.

How the hell have I not rated this?  Anyway, what can you say about the best doppelbock available that hasnt already been said?  Pours a nice deep brown with thick tan head, lots of lacing and residual fluff.  Aromas deep of chocolate, molasses, coffee, and roasted malt.  Flavor matches well and puts tons of stouts, imperial stouts, and porters to shame.  This is the epitome of grand german craftsmanship.  When it is all said and done, they do more with less.
12 oz bottle, gift.  Deep brown pour with a big creamy tan head.  Sweet & roasted malty aroma and flavor with a sweet caramel finish.  Awesome beer.
Had at the Back Abbey.  served in official celebrator glass.  first is sweet then the malt kicks in.  pours a  dark brown/red.  excellent. hits all the right notes.  very smooth.
caramel, medium sweetness, medium body, for a delicious finish on the tongue...extremely drinkable...a go to on a cold North Eastern night...

[Bottle] Well I finally got around to sitting down and really rating this one. Pours a shade of brown with a slight haze. A nice cap of tan colored head as well. Heavy aroma of brown sugar, sweet malts and molasses. Tastes of hazelnut, vanilla, dark chocolate, coffee beans and burnt sugars. A very solid malt base to say the least. Chewy mouthfeel and syrupy texture coat the mouth, but not in a cloying way. This is definitely one of the cleanest and best tasting beers Ive had in the style.

ambrato carico quasi scura buona schiuma discreta persitenza naso maltato leggere tostaure caramello lieve caffe un tocco speziato in bocca maltata ma non stucchevole con note tostate un po di esteri abbastanza morbida Earlier Rating: 7/28/2007 Total Score: 3.8scura buona schima decisamente tostata ma non eccessivamente secca in finale quasi affumicata
(11.2 oz bottle). Pours brown liquid with reddish hue and nice head. Aroma is sweet of dried fruit/raisins. bitter/dry finish.
Pours dark brown with a manila head. Smooth chocolate, toffee, caramel and bread. Fantastic beer.

Pours a very deep reddish brown with a thin off-white head. Nice lacing around the glass. Aroma is of roasted malts, toffee, and dried fruits. Flavour is sweet with underlying fruit. All of those roasted notes are there once again in the flavour - bread, coffee, malt. Definitely will try this one again.
Bottle. Dark pour with some lacing tan head. Dark malts caramel, nutty, roasted, and toffee , light etoh warming, dark fruit notes. Great beer that isnt too hard to find, intro to craft for newbies!

Dark brown robe with an beige head that doesnt last. Great smells of roasted malt and toffey. Great bitterness. Caramel and malt taste completed by some toffey and spices touches. A great double bock.

Ive never been a big fan of German beers in general, and I usually find Doppelbocks too sweet and lacking in complexity. However, this example is an exception to what Ive tasted so far! The aroma was malty with toffee scents. It poured a deep dark brown with a light head out of the bottle. Flavors of carmel and coffee were apparent, but not overpowering. The most impressive thing about this beer to me was how well blended the flavors were. Not one and then another but all as once like a symphony in my mouth. It also had a nice crisp finish. This was one of the best features as many doppelbocks leave too much sweet aftertaste because they finish syrupy.  On a cold winter night like the one I had last night I would definitely crack one or two of these open again!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 On tap at Ayingers Speis und Trank - Munich. 
Clear red-brown body with off-white head. 
Aroma is malty, and a little burnt, with loads of caramel and rock candy. 
The flavour is sweet and malty with strong notes of caramel, rock candy, and hints of prunes and alcohol. 
Very drinkable. 
Earlier Rating: 7/17/2009 Total Score: 4.3
Bottle brought home from Milano. 
Pours brown with a dense long lasting tan head. 
Aroma is lots of light roasted malt, wheat, caramel, dark fruits, nuts, alcohol and weak notes of liquorice. 
Flavour is malty, with notes of caramel, wheat, dark fruits, nuts and alcohol.
An intense and very complex beer. Splendid!

Bottle.  I remember loving this beer 5 years ago when I first tried it.  Dark brown pour with some lighter brown head.  Aroma is oatmeal, vanilla, smoked malt.  Flavor is a nicely rich blend of sweet caramel, chocolate, and smoke.  I still love it.

Bottle,

has a dark brown pour with a light tan and tan colored head, Celebrator is a clear deep ruby with dark brown almost black hues when held to a light and I can see through part of the beer, 

aromas of dark bread, mild roasted malt, a mix of dark fruit and candy sweetness, earthy yeast, light caramel in the background, 

big malt flavor with toasted bread, there is a flavor that is near chocolate, hints of raisin and date, 
light to medium bitterness at the finish, some roasted malt and coffee after the finish, 

nice mouth feel, 

with the sweetness on the nose I was expecting a Doppelbock that was going to be really sweet like many I have tried but this beer is really good, great malt flavors, one of the better Doppelbocks I have had.

pours enticingly dark almost black and has an aroma of toffee caramel with raisins . fruity in the beginning but the hops come through in the finish with a lingering cocoa mouthfeel , nice and smooth this is the best dopplebock i have had with great drinkability

Such a wonderful beer.  Pours with little head, deep deep black.  Sweet malty aroma which continues to the flavor.  Deep, dark malt flavors, which mellows to an almost pumpkin pie, cinnamon flavor, very nice.  I aim to make a beer myself that is this good.

(Bottle into mug)  Poured a smooth dark brown with a half finger lighter brown head.  The sweet malts dominated the nose, with a nice aroma of a cooked caramel with another strong sweetness that I just couldnt quite place.  It is very rich in the mouth, as advertised, with a smooth carbonation that helped pull out some of the roast in the malt, enhancing the sweetness there.  Be wary, as the alcohol was not really there, but at almost 7% it could smack you after a few.  Finished with the same smoothness, carrying the sweet roast through the end.  Highly recommended!
Pours dark brown with huge white head. Good roasted malt character. Elegant and smooth.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and nice beige head.  The taste is dark malt, some slightly bitter coffee, with a hint of chocolate and smokey aftertaste.  Best Doppelbock I have had.

Pours a thick, almost charcoal black with a thin head. The aroma is chocolately and burnt fruit. When I had it, the first thing I noticed taste wise was that it seemed fruity with some raisins. The body is pretty thin. I realize this scores quite high but I am not a fan of the style.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2010 Bottle from Fresh Market. Pours a gorgeous deep reddish-brown with fluffy tan head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is superb; dry red apple, cherry, toffee, and raisin. Surprisingly, it doesnt smell too sweet. It doesnt taste too sweet either. The balance is dead on. The initial fruity sweetness from the malts gives way to a light, comforting, floral bitterness from the hops. Full bodied palate, but not so assertive that it completely dominates your mouth. I wish it were just a little less carbonated, but its hard to fault it for that. Ill definitely be coming back to this one often.

Black with a redish tint when heald up to light.  Thick tan head.  Sweet malty fruity aroma.  Dark rich roasted malt flavor with a fruity flavor of rasins.  Smooth. Sweet Christmas orniment comes with it.

Bottled:Pours deep ruby (almost black) with a thick head.  the aroma is sweet and malty with notes of dark berries and a little bit of smoke. Smooth mouth-feel. Flavour is sweet and malty with notes of dark currants and warming alcohol.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Tap. Red mahogany pour. Fluffy off-white head. Aroma and taste of roast, dark fruit, cherry. Really fantastic doppelbock.

Pours a reddish brown black, like cherry stained mahagony.  Two fingers of pillowy head.  Big aroma of malt and cherry.  Hint of banana.  Delicious.  Big mouthfeel, medium+ carbonation.  Malty.  Balanced.  Nice slightly bitter hop aftertaste.  Let it warm a bit.  Roasted coffee, chocolate, alcohol flavors emerge.  Structured and complex (if I can drop that in there without sounding like total tool.  It does seem there are three or four discrete layers of just the malt flavor.).  Trailing sticky lacing as it goes.  Really like this beer.

Flaske: Flot uklar mørkebrun øl med et lysebrunt skumhoved. Ekstrem maltet duft med en snert tørret frugt. Helt klart lagringspotentiale. Meget maltet smag med en diskret humlebitterhed der flot binder øllen sammen. Virkelig en lækkerbisken.Earlier Rating: 3/30/2008 Total Score: 3.9Flaske. Mørk øl, med en sød og let vinøs duft. Overraskende fyldig i betragtning af den knap så høje alkoholprocent. Sød som bare fanden men stadig lækker, kompleks og balanceret.

Terrific beer. Has a nice, smooth dark color with a very faint foam head. The aroma is malty, robust, and sweet. The color is dark almost like a porter. Flavor is just like the aroma, malty and sweet, but not too sweet.
Smells of sweet roasted malts with a small head that gave good lacing tasted of sweet lager with a funny after taste

Delicious, and I loved the little goat on it.
Dark brown in color with little head.
Complex aroma and taste.  Molasses, malt, and coffee, with spices as well. Felt like it coats your mouth a bit after each sip.
Overall, very nice.  Highly recommended.

Very dark brown color, large head disappearing quickly; aroma of roasted malt, raisins and also tart lingonberries; mouthfeel is quite carbonated, could be thicker; flavor of mild bitterness, but mostly sweet, roasted malt and coffee-like dryness; finish is also rather dry and slightly bitter.

Ayinger Celebrator Dopplebock 12oz
Pours dark brown with a small creamy head that dissipates quickly. Slight reddish hue to it when it is in the light. Little to no lacing on the glass. Sweet aroma of molasses, malt, vanilla, dark caramel, and cereal grains. Smells yummy. Tastes delicious. Oily mouthfeel with a flavor of malty caramel, with slight hop bitterness on the finish. Very well balanced with subtle fruit, herbs.  Very approachable for a darker beer. Would recommend to anyone.

[bottle]
Nice cerealy aroma with some sweet pumpernickel and bread crust. Almost clear dark brown under a beige foam. Flavour is sweet with cereal grains/pumpernickel/bread crust, but there is balancing bitterness and even a hint of hops character. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, slightly warming, sweet finish.

Pours a dark ruby red with a dark tan head.Got the aroma of sweet caramel, dark chocolate, and brown sugar.The flavor is great.It taste of toffee, sweet caramel, and chocolate.The finnish is a lingering sweet caramel.Overall a must for maltheads.

Bottle at home.  Pours a rich mahogany with a deep tan tight head.  Smells of caramel and dark chocolate.  For a darker beer, it is surprisingly light on the tongue.  Chocolate-coated hazelnut and sweet caramel finishing with pecans that linger for a while.
Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Malty, sweet, caramel, rye bread, herbal hops, toffee, bitter almonds, lightly fruity, lightly roasted. Nice one.

Truly a delight. This is possibly the best beer Ive ever had. Its certainly the best dopplebock Ive had. The downside is that its expensive. Spaten Optimator is a close cousin but just cant live up to this.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 500 ml bottle. Deep dark ruby brown colour, thin light brown head. Sweetish roasted malty aroma, with some liquorice and dark fruits. The flavour is also roasted, malty, bread-like, with a hint of coffee and a warm bitter finish. Full-bodied, smooth carbonation.

Aroma is major dark grape. Sweet brown sugar. Raisins. MAJOR toffee and molasses -- a taffy pull. Practically brewers wort.

Appears glassy red-brown with foamy light brown head. Not bad.

Tastes seriously sweet, heavy toffee and molasses. Not much else really. Lots of sweet malts. Just tons of malts. Aftertaste is better than the taste.

Feels milky, oily, smooth. I wasnt ready for this one. The sweetest beer of all time. A slow sipper. I would have liked some more balances.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Dark brown with a creamy beige head.
Dried fruits and some nuts in the aroma.
Vinous fruits in the flavour. Medium bitterness with some chocolate.Earlier Rating: 8/2/2003 Total Score: 3.5Bottled.
A dark body with a brown frothy head.
Almost porter-ish.
Sweet aroma from prune and a smoky quiet fresh flavour.
Aroma is of sweet malt with dark fruit, Taste is similar with a distinct caramel taste at points.  Nice brew

33cl bottle: Pours a dark ruby red with a small, off-white head. The aroma is vinous, with toffee-chocolatey malts and dark fruits, sometimes even flowery but not aggressive and very inviting. Clean, bittersweet flavours of dark chocolate, obscure herbs and caramel with just a hint of roastiness. Thick and creamy mouthfeel, but not overly sweet, balanced by a pretty strong bitterness. The carbonation is a slight bit too fizzy and affects the smoothness of the beer. Really nice and drinkable Doppelbock.

Very dark ruby, almost black beer. Medium beige head. The aroma is strong and malty. Bready sweetness and salty licorice are well balanced. Dates and raisins in the finisih, also some ripe bananas. Mellow roastedness develop towards delicious chocolate in the finish. Some herbal hops in the finish too. The flavor is sweet, and it has lots of bready malty. Light bitterness and sourness of chocolate beans in the finish. Full bodied, low carbonated and oily palate.   Earlier Rating: 5/6/2008 Total Score: 4.1330 ml bottle. Head is beige, medium sized and thick but not very long lasting. Liquid is very dark brown, almost black and has some red shades. Very deep, roasted malty aroma is almost like rye bread. Alcohol is well hidden. Long and dry bitter finish. Full bodied, thich and oily texture. Very enjoyable and warming doppebock.

500ml bottle. Light brown head. Deep dark brown colour, almost opaque. Aromas of roasted caramel malts, banana, raisins, toffee. Somewhat oily palate, medium carbonation. Flavor is sweet banana, wheat, roasted malts, sourish end. A little bit too sweet for my liking.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 (br-btl wt-lbl ram tied to neck, "finest bavarian double bock beer", 6.7%)

lct-mhgy, dense head, chunky lace, §co2, full-syrupy-bod.

complex crml mlss malt (a bit of everything) aroma.

malt bock T1, fleeting-bock T2, sweet warm returning-bock T3, §bitter Tf, ^warm for ABV, a bit cloying / sweet-malt-heavy on the palate.
Amber brew with a short antique white head, wonderful balance of malty sweetness and mild hops.  Real nice representative of this style.

a great one from the dopplebock selection but not my favorite.  its red/brow, definitely malty and smooth but a bit too much flavor.  It has plenty of fruit in the aftertaste, just not my style.  I like the Optimator.
Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, toffee and some chocolate. The flavor is mostly roasted malts with some caramel.  A good beer to drink on a cold day.

Deep copper colour, thick creamy beige head.
Aroma is malty and sweet, dark bread, dark fruit and spices.
Flavour is full of bread, ending in a nice bitterness, unfortunately a metallic aftertaste lingers in the background.
Mouthfeel is smooth but a bit flat.
Good but not living up to the hype.

Aroma, aroma, aroma. Nothing gets me more amped up for a beer than a rich malty aroma coming from the glass and celebrator has it. I think celebrators strongest point however is its balance. The malt, hops, and alcohol are all very evenly blended with the resulting beer being very delightful.

Dark with nice ruby highlights when held up to the light.  Tan head.  Coffee, toffee nose and a hint of alcohol.  Toffee, caramel, toasty flavor.  Slightly roasty.  Well balanced, rich and flavorful.  A classic example of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 (bottle) pours the darkest ruby-black with a bubbly, creamy brown head. aroma of chocolate and hazelnut, dark fruits, most notably cherries, roasted malts, coffee and a light herbal hoppy note. well-rounded flavour of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee, with hints of dark fruit and herbal hops. medium bodied, with smooth carbonation and a dry roasted-bitter finish. an extremely well-balanced doppelbock!

(Bottle) Pours dark mahogany with a pale nougat coloured head. The aroma is medium to heavily malty with tones of dark, juicy bread, burned sugar, nuts, hay and syrup alongside some dried fruitiness. Earthy and herbal hops. Maybe a whisper of chocolate/coffee and liquorice. Typical Ayinger malt profile. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of dark bread, dried fruits, nuts, Coca Cola, coffee, anise and herbal hops. The mouthfeel is creamy and round with lively carbonation. The finish is quite empty with a slight metallic, coffee twist.  Medium bodied. Earlier Rating: 2/12/2007 Total Score: 3.4(Bottle) Pours dark with red hints. Dried fruits, caramel aroma with grainy/nutty bread and spices. Undertones of hops, allmond paste and maybe a tiny bit of grass. Sweet, caramelly flavour with grain/malt, hints of alcohol, smoke and some chocolate A bit spicy, light hoppy and light sourish. Good, smooth mouthfeel. Full body.

Tried at Stubbies on draft in Gainesville, FL. This is what a a Doppelbock is supposed to be! Light brown head, dark body. Tastes like applejuice and caramel. Finishes with a faint alcohol taste. Would drink again.

0.5 L botttle from Systembolaget, Charlottenberg  as  Ayinger Winter Bock. Fully diminishing mediumsized, dense, light brown head. Brilliant, dark ruby body.  Strong, nutty, almost cheesy malt aroma. Dark caramelly, with a whiff of tinned dark fruits.  Full malt body. Sweet. A refined malty and fruity sweetness. Toasted, light bready, with suggestions of mild spices and dried, dark fruits.  Some faint spicy hops underneth.  Thick, yet soft mouthfeel.  Big, lingering malt finish, with fruity and roasted notes.  A malt bomb, very nice indeed.

Dark reddish brown with a small greyish head. Aroma is fat malty and fruity with notes of nuts, bread and minerals. Body is full and very smooth. Flavour is rich malty with notes of raisins, dark bread and refreshing minerals. It ends on a dry fruity note with some warming alcohol.Earlier Rating: 11/23/2009 Total Score: 3.9Dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma is invitingly nutty with notes of minerals, dark bread and toffe. Mouthfeel is fairly big and very smooth. Flavour is big, very fat maly and rich with notes of dark fruit, dark bread, refreshing minerals and nuts. Finishes slightly grassy and dry with a lingering malty breadyness. Warming and exellent.

Pours very dark clear ruby brown with small tan head.  Aromas of toast, pear, berries, licorice, and spice.  Sweet with lightly toasted chocolatey malt followed by fruit and finishing very gently with a subtle bitterness.  Full bodied with a thick creamy texture and fairly gentle carbonation.  Wonderfully balanced and delicious.

33cl bottle at Flatbread Burlington. Pours very dark amber with a small head. Head retention is rather short. Not much lacing. Nose is raisins, dark ripe fruits and earthy/mineral hops. Very rich and sweet. Taste is dark fruits, raisin and roasted malt. Quite sweet and rich. Finish is dry and sweet with hints of roasted malt.

12oz bottle: 
Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a tan head with only some lace left in the glass. 
Aroma: Slightly roasted with caramel malts 
Taste: Sweet roasted malts with some coffee and chocolate flavors, finishes with a spice hop. 
This is a really good beer that I could easily drink a few pints.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2012 Bottle that I picked up in Ölrepublikens fridge ;) 2012-07-10 
New rating 3,9 - new average: 3,9

Bottle 2009 edition. Christmas tasting 2009-11-27 Bottled as Winter Bock
AR: Fudge
AP: Dark amber body , heavy head
F: vanilla pod , maltyness, fudge. I was  very surprised - I was expecting a boring single bock, but this one had many nice flavors

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a dark brown color with a nice beigewhite head. Aroma is malty with dark bread, light chocolate, toffee and minerals. Flavour is very malty, with lotes of dark bread, toffee sweetness, and some light chocolate. Fullbodied, rather sticky, with a lively carbonation which tickles the tounge at first, than becomes softer and very nice. A very tasty bock.

330 mL bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake.  Dark cola-like pour with an off-white head.  Sweet malty aroma that really overwhelms anything else.  Sweet flavor with mostly apple, pear, and raisin but also some nuttiness and a hint of chocolate.  Medium bodied.  Probably as good as a dopplebock gets in my opinion.

30cl on tap at restaurant. Pours a semi-translucent dark amber color with minimal head. Aroma is well balanced between spices, malt, and hops in that order. Taste is very spicy but like the aroma is well balanced with nothing too overpowering. Body is full and is active while on the palate- you can feel the carbonation. Really nice complex beer, good to combine with food.

Bottles as Winter Bock. 
Fairly standard bock, nice edge of sour cherries, but nothing adventourous here. A bit short finish.
By no means bad. But it doesnt tingle down your spine, either!

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 It poured a very dark liquid with some red notes, medium light brown foam that left some lacing.

It had a malty smell with some caramell, round milk chocolate and dark malts.



The mouthfeel was smooth and it had a medium body and low bitterness. It tasted of chocolate, malt, caramell and also sweet with some sugar, raisin and grapes. This was very very nice, I can definitely imagine drinking several of these soon again.

Dopplebocks in general are not my fav, way too sweet for my taste, but I knew that this was good when I first tasted it. I kind of consider this to be more of a desert beer, i can have only one at a time, great malty sweetness but not overbearing, toasted hazlenut flavor and goes down so smooth.

Bottled. Pours out in a dark brown colour with a rich creamy pale brown head. Solid malt aroma of dark chocolate, dark bread, fudge, nuts and crackers. Medium-bodied with rock solid malty flavours of dark chocolate, caramel, roasted nuts and crackers. Long aftertaste of dark chocolate, grass, nuts and fudge.Earlier Rating: 5/9/2004 Total Score: 4.3Dark mahogny colour with a hints of ruby. Small beige creamy long-lasting head. Wondeful malty aroma. Can find toffee, dark dried fruit, sweetened cherries and nuts with a slightly vinous note. Smooth and complex flavours of chocolate, dried plums, coffee and spices. Smooth and thick texture. Wonderful balance. Coffee, caramel and alcohol in finish. Delicous!

The beer pours a deep dark red with a foamy tan head. The nose is inviting with bits of roasted caramel and burnt toast? . I love the flavour complex and it changes as the beer warms. At first the roasted flavour dominates, then it moves to carmel sweet maltiness with hints of spices and dark fruits. Nice touch of bitterness on the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 I saved this one for my 100th rating :)
Dark brown with red. beige smallest head.
I wouldnt set this beer above all the others as number one yet.
Has to be taken quite warm to get more out of it.
Aroma excellent Liquorice, sweet grapefruit with its acidic aftertaste. slightly watery.
mouth drying hops, but brings water to my mouth. a bit sour also.
I smell cappuccino when blowing straight to my own nose.
Good mouth filling body.
damn its good! great for celebrating the 100th rate

weichnact bock: 11/2009: salty liquorice,  medium body. a bit sour. sweet and strong. wood.
a bit bitter end with coffee. reminds me of Kahlua -liquor.

Conspicuously devoid of a head but maybe I missed something as my girlfriend poured it. Mild aroma with meaty smoke and... is that asphalt?

Medium feeling body but still full feeling malts. Slightly sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2013 Bottle. Very smooth and well balanced beer with an elegant and complex malty taste.Earlier Rating: 7/18/2009 Total Score: 3.9Bottle. Pours red-brown with a cramy white head. Smells raisin and chocolate. Creamy taste of vanilla, dark chocolate and coffee. Chocolate in aftertaste. Small fruitiness. This was almost a little bit too enjoyable...

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Pours very dark burgundy, but clear, with a light brown head.

Lots of flavour, licorice, chcolate and dark fruits.
Smooth and well balanced.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2011 Bottle from systembolaget. Small thin lace over a nice brown red ale. Malty aroma with a flowery first aroma that quickly dissapears. Malty taste with a sharp alcohole tart taste and a sweet maltyness that isnt balances and gives this beer a small drinkability.
Rating 2 2011-03-13
High brown fluffy head that is rather short. Having a litle cold I dont get much aroma. The taste is nice with a full body and sweet maltiness. I dont get any alcohole this time. Small to medium bitterness.

One of those beers that I enjoy but dont quite understand people losing their head over.  Its a very good Doppelbock that tastes fuller and richer than its abv might indicate.  Its a transparent ruby brown beer with good lacing.  Aroma is brown sugar, toasted bread, raisins and malt.  Flavor kicks in some nice bitter notes, so the malt doesnt run away with it.  Relatively thick on the palate.  A world classic but not one of my all-time favorites.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 Pours a light molasses brown with a thin tan head into... a Celebrator stem glass!  Oddly, the head seemed to stay continuously (just a tiny bit) the whole time I drank this brew.  Aroma of raisins, dates, slight molasses.  Initial tastes of dates (predominant), raisins, plumbs, viscous molasses, ever so slight chocolate.  Fantastic creamy mouthfeel.  Lovely malty backbone which keeps nicely from start to finish.  The sweetness develops as you drink.  Edit on 2/14/10: After having this quite a few times, as well as a few doppelbocks I have found superior, I feel I must bring the rating down.  While I still like this quite a bit, I find it lacking in the richness of both aroma and flavor as compared to others of the style.
dense, dark brown pour with a reddish tint and large, fizzy tan head. Malty, roasty, alcoholic (but not offputtingly so) aroma. Malty flavor with brown sugar and, seemingly, rye bread.

Aroma of sweet cherries and malt possibly some other sugars in there too. There was little head to mine which may be the way that I poured the bottle into the glass but left a light foam on top and the color of the head/remnant foam was an amber color. Color of the beer was a dark amber or red but definitely on the darker side then the picture assumes. It had a sweet and bitter cherry taste slightly with a mix of chocolate (probably Munich malt coming through) and was light on the palate and a little dry but not to bad. Overall, it is one of the best bottles Ive had and on tap it was equally if not more impressive. Enjoy sparingly like a nice treat that you dont want to ruin though.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2009 Bottle (50 cl) from Systembolaget. Clear reddish brown with medium beige head. Nutty and caramelly aroma with earthy and spicy hops. Medium bodied and smooth. Dry and well balanced.Earlier Rating: 4/5/2007 Total Score: 3.4Bottle. Pours deep redish brown with a medium beige head. Deep roasted -almost smoked - malt aroma, but not very complex or interesting. Smooth mouthfeel. A bit sweet in the flavour, with low bitterness. A disappointment.

A clear dark red/brown colored beer, with a dark beige head. The aroma of fruits like cherrie and malts. A little rusty (The bottle was 2 years out of date). The taste of fruit, like chierries, caramel and dry. The aftertaste is bitter and dry. Not bad at all, but Ill hope to get a fresh bottle.

Boy oh boy this was most delicious.  Heavy malty aroma with a matching taste.  Poured into a stem glass  and it was a dark ruby color (could only tell ruby when put up to the light).  Flavors included malts, caramel, toffee, and other deliciousness.  Great palate.  Excellent beer

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aromas of dark fruits, toffee, caramel, roasted malts,chocolate. Great, complex nose. Flavours of licorice, chocolate, some smoke. Nice, sweet gentle mouthfeel. Finishes malty, smokey and slightly bitter.

(330cl bottle) pours very black with creamy tan head. Nose is dark dried fruits, toasted brown sugar, raisins. Taste is roasted brown sugar, molasses, and semi-sweet chocolate. Finishes creamy with nice roasty finish and perfect body/carbonation. This is great.
A strong doppelbock, but very drinkable.  Slightly sweet, full-bodied, and very smooth - alcohol is not very noticeable.  If all doppelbocks tasted like this, I would not stop drinking them.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 14/11/2009 Score: 5/4/7/4/14 3.4 Bottle. Dark brown with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma is roasted malt. Malty, roasted, some coffee and sweetness. Medium to full-bodied, dry and some alcohol in the finish. Quite tasty, but I was expecting a bit more from this.Earlier Rating: 9/9/2008 Total Score: 3.9Bottle. Dark brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Sweet roasted malt flavour with hints of alcohol and fruits. Some bitterness in the finish. Medium to full-bodied and well-balanced brew. Very tasty Doppelbock. Average of ratings 3.65.

33 cl Bottle. Very dark dopplebock (tasted side by side with weltenberger kloster, augistiner maximator and trois mousquetaire DB, thanks TheJester) This one stood out from the lot by its especially fruity aroma, plums and cherries abound with lots of caramelized sugars. Rather cherry taste with some good sweetness. Mouthfeel is okay creamy with very fine carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 Appearance is very dark brown, you can see some red shades against the light. The head is beige, it lasts quite long and leaves a little lacing also. Aroma is, in my opinion, surprisingly mild with bready malts and sweet liquorice. Flavor is also very bready and malty, slightly roasted with hints of coffee and brown sugar. Also a bit bitter and dry in the end. Palate is quite full and sticky. A nice doppelbock.

bottle- pours black with small, light brown head. Aroma is of liquorice, leather, caramel. It is lightly smoky with a hint of yeast coming through giving off the faintest note of marmite, no trace of alcohol. 
The texture is creamy and the flavor is liquorice, yeast, and sweet malt, just bitter enough to even it all out, I love the balance ofthis beer. Again no alcohol present in the taste.....Good stuff!!!! Too bad the bottle was only a 33cl

Looks totally black in the glass. Holding up to the light reveals ruby highlights throughout. Slight head which dissapates quickly.

Smells of nice, sweet malts. Almost like toffee or caramel. No hops or alcohol appear in the nose. This is good.

Sweet malts hit the taste sensors first. Mmmm. There follows a light smokey/roasted flavor. Just ever so light hops flavor on the back end with a touch of almost saltiness.

The feel is very nice, but with all the build-up of color and smell I expected it to be a bit fuller and richer. Would have rated higher with more body. Just a tad too light for my tastes.

Overall this is an exceptionally drinkable beer. I have enjoyed many of these over the years and shall continue to do so.
In bottle; great dark beer. Full bodied, slight coffee notes with hints of chocolate. The 6.7% alc. is not noticeable by flavor.I really enjoyed this beer alot

330 ml bottle that comes with its own plastic goat charm.
Appearance is black, but admits some light.  Coca-cola-like head that disappears immediately and leaves no lacing.
Smell is very subtle, like cream soda.
Taste begins with dark roast coffee then sweet malt, then finishes with bitter cocoa and a hint of chocolate. Nicely complex.
Mouthfeel is almost chewy.
Very drinkable, alcohol is apparent but not overpowering, definitely to be sought out.

500 ml bottle, named Winter-Bock. Dark brown colour with small, tan head. Malt, some chocolate and dark fruits in the aroma. Quite similar notes in the flavour too. Aftertaste of bitter hops and roasted malt.Earlier Rating: 11/4/2009 Total Score: 4.1330 ml bottle at Kaisla. Pours dark brown with a hint of red and a beige head. A sweetish, malty aroma with notes of raisins, toffee and some vanilla. A malty flavour with the dark fruits and some chocolate. Quite sweet finish. Includes a small plastic buck that hangs on the bottle neck.

Poured a beautiful black with red trying to peek through. Creamy 2 finger caramel head that fades slowly to a light cover that spans the entire glass. Lacing is thin and sporadic.

Aroma is very malty sweet. Raisins, dates and slight chocolate. Very faint citrus pulls through.

Taste is near perfect for a doppelbock. Sweet chocolate and slightly bitter coffee malts followed by a weak piny spice. Again, raisins and dates. Gets better as it warms up.

Mouthfeel is a bit weak. Carbonation is low. I would have like a bit more carbonation.

Drinkability is good for this style. Not going to get much more drinkable in a dark, nearly 7% bock.

Overall a great beer. Something I definitely keep around and get in the mood for.

dark pour almost like a stout or a porter. same type of tan head...and lots of it. sweet maltiness with a little bit of bitter on the nose. Tastes of hay and barnyard with a little bit of malty sweetness. very rich. great sipping beer.

Pours dark brown from the 12oz. beer into a pint glass: Flavors of caramel, toffee, raisins, vanilla, and milk chocolate. Spiced finish. Drinkability: Oily, medium bodied, sweet, and mult-dimensional. Rebuy: Yes. #181 on 02112009, DG.
Brown coloured beer with medium off-white head and no carbonation. Malty aroma. Full creamy and sparkling palate. Finish is roasted malty with a sweet touch ending bitter. Good one.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2009 Poured dark brown with a moderate beige head.  Aroma is brown sugar, fruity, roasted, chocolate, and vanilla notes coming together to make me think of a fresh baked cookie.  Flavor is rich, sweet roasted malt, with coffee and dark fruit.  One of the most complex lagers Ive ever had.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 In bottle; great dark beer. Full bodied, slight coffee notes with hints of chocolate and plum. The 6.7% alc. is not noticeable by flavor.I really enjoyed this beer alot, its one of my favorites for sure

Nice smooth malty aroma with notes of dates and fig.  Pours out an almost black brown with a light toffee head.  Flavor is a roasted malt with notes of coffee and a slightly hoppy long lasting finish.

Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes très complexes de malt (fruits rouges, pruneaux, chocolat, caramel brûlé). Robe rousse très foncée, effervescence assez faible, peu de mousse. En bouche, la bière est moyennement ronde et soyeuse et présente un malt très complexe, avec des notes fruitées (cerises, pruneaux), de caramel foncé, de fumée et de chocolat. Devient plus chocolatée en réchauffant. Finale pas trop sucrée et légèrement amère. Un classique qui mérite bien sa réputation.

330ml bottle.  Pours balck in colour, with persistent cappucino coloured head.  Stong aroma of roasted malt.  Flavour is slightly sweet, hint of chocolate.  Mouthfeel is a bit flat, with fine carbonation.

Everyones favorite doppelbock wasnt a big hit for me. Very complex and dark in flavor. Roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate. Reminds me a little too much of a stout. Guess I prefer a simpler bock. No denying that its a supremely well made beer though.
Very good beer. Malts, fruits, plums and raisins but not to sweet and very well balanced. Lots of stuff going on here. Finish is very smooth and very good.

A dark, rich amber color with a slight reddish hue in the light, topped with a thick, creamy tan head.  Uniquely well-articulated bubbles topped with a foamy crest.  Ripe fruit and roasted malt in the nose.  Such incredible balance - all of the great flavors are there; chocolate, caramel, coffee, with a smoky dryness at the end.  The twinge of alcohol completes the experience without overpowering.  Such a creamy mouthfeel - earthy, bready.  Rather than beer, this is more of a deliciously burnt cinnamon roll in liquid form.  Exquisite.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2011 At a tasting thanks DSG, Pours clear red to brown with a nice beige head, aroma of roast, wax, nuts, marmalade, molasses, chocolate and cherries sourness, flavor of chocolate, wax, vanilla, cherries, cinnamon, burnt butter, toffee, almost full bodied, nice
Pours hazy brown with an off-white medium head, aroma of nuts, caramel, toffee, grapes and vanilla, flavors of caramel, toffee, raisins and chocolate, bitter licurice spiced finish, balanced and complex. Great

this beer is beautifully balanced and easy to drink. this bottle pours a deep, dark, rich brown with a thick and puffy, cream colored head. smells of smokey goodness and prunes and raisins!! the taste is wonderful, it is a fruity start (plums?) then proceeds to be malty and strong while it finishes with some toffee, brown sugar and clove. the final go down is smooth and addicting, love this stuff.

Pours dark brown, almost black, with a thick creamy head. Aromas of banana and ginger bread. Flavor is very mello and nutty. Some banana and spice flavors in there as well, and a nice bit of acidity comes though in the finish. Creamy mouthfeel. This is a darn good beer, and I cant believe I havent tried it before.

Poured from 11 oz bottle, a very nice dark brown, an inch layer of light tannish head, caramely and malty nose. Notes of caramel and damp earth, vanilla. Moderately sweet in the start with some nice malty notes of toffee and the faintest hardwood smoke.  Overall flavour is complex. It starts with a brown sugary presence with a little raisin, hazelnut, and caramel. Then ends with a burnt malt. Very clean, rich, malty, and well balanced.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Deep amber-brown pour with a nice tan head.  Dark fruits in the aroma with some coffee in there but it is all pretty light.  Yeasty flavor with an undertone of coffee throughout.  Almost like a yeasty raisin bread.  Bit of a tangy finish.

A complex Doppelbock that pours nearly black and is dominated with a rich malt taste. It is not nearly as sweet as other Doppelbocks, but offers a subtle hop tone that lends to a brilliant balance of flavors.

Pour is dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is dry with a little bit of coffee scents. Flavor is a malty and dry. A bit of hoppiness but nothing overpowering. Plum and blackcurrant notes. Pretty good, but I think that 100 percentile rating is a little high.
Great aroma, coffee flavors, aftertaste is thick and roasty.  Every bottle comes with a plastic goat!
Nose is a toasty grain, sweet malt, hints of chocolate and brown sugar. Flavor is rich roasty malt, bread, raisin, brown sugar, slight smoke.

A strong sweet aroma, candied raisins, caramel, burnt sugar, creme brulee and prunes.  Pours dark brown with nice lacing.  Mouthfeel is very thin, almost watery, with alot of carbonation, ample for this style of beer.  Tastes of apricot, brown sugar and raisins.

bottle, pours dark brown, nearing black with a tall frothy tan head., nice lacing shoots down the glass as its consumed.  Aroma is very nice with notes of green raisin, cinnamon, a robust and full bread malt, and candy sugar.  Wow, this is without a doubt one of the best and most complex German brews I have had.  Its hard to believe this is brewed under the purity law.  Tons of beady malt, yeast esters and a spicy nutmeg and cinnamon finish that scream to be tried again.  Ill gladly re-attack this all night.  Aweome dopplebock.

Bottle, thanks to hobbersr.Shared with hobbersr and Macadem. Pours cola brown, with a scant head and good lacing. Nose is spicy hops, plus raisins, figs, root beer, leaves and earth. Flavors of fruit, spice, earth, smoke, very nice, but a 4.1 overall? I just dont get it.

I won a friendly poker game last night so this beer seemed like a good choice for a nightcap due to the name. I poured it into an over-sized Arrogant Bastard glass and realized the glass was just like the Celebrator glass, only huge. It was a serious dark brown, with ruby edges and a frothy tan head. The smell was roasty, toasty, and malty. The taste was toasty and I swear I detected licorice in there. This was a good beer but I think it tastes better on tap. It is also a little pricey at $3 for 11oz. Still, one of the best German beers I have tried.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-28-2007 16:44:05
Very dark brown/black pour with a large foamy head. Smells of dark chocolate and licorice. Nice roasted malt taste with a hint of licorice. Good Beer.

A dark brown to black beer with a nice 3 finger head. Aroma was malty, chocolate, coffee, & roasted. The taste was nutty, malty, chocolate, roasty, Cokeish, & had a slight creamy mouthfeel. The alcohol is tucked in real nicely.

Finally got hold of a bottle of this and was not disappointed. Reddish brown with a lovely fine, tall head. Big malt aroma of chocolate, caramel, cookies and cake, liqourice; slightly minty. Sweet chocolate and caramel flavor, woth a touch of smoke and a surprisingly bitter roasted finish. Has a perfectly smooth, soft mouth. A very unique and interesting bock! Earlier Rating: 12/24/2008 Total Score: 4.1Bottle in Strasbourg, 2006. 
Pours an almost opaque black with a tall tan head. Very tasty-looking. Aroma of roasted malt. Smells rather burnt, cookieish and thick. A bit sweet, with caramel and a touch of chocolate. 
Very roasted flavor comes with a rush of sweetness, which then gives way to a strong dryness coming from roasted malt and good hopping. 
Medium to heavy in the mouth, rather full of body. The balance is superb.The finish is dry and bitter, roasted, and lasts a long time.  A great beer, much less sweet overall than other dark bocks I have had from the area.
Raisin caramel notes smoothed out over and into the darker flavors.  Sweet but not cloyingly so.  The elevated alcohol is invisible

I wasnt expecting much when I saw this one at the store.  $2.15 per bottle didnt raise my expectations any either. I thought the little ornament on the bottle was pretty sweet and If I were dirt poor I would probably hang it on my christmas tree.  You know that feeling you get when you put on an old jacket and find a $20 bill in the pocket?  Thats how I felt when I drank this.  Pours a nice brown with a quickly diminishing tan head.  Caramel with slight coffee in the aroma.  Great caramel bock taste with a nice warm finish.  Top freaking shelf!!!

Colore marrone, gran schiuma cremosa,tipo stout.Aroma di malto tostato, caramello.in bocca è piena, buon corpo, sapore di malto, molto ben equilibrata, caramello, nel finale un accenno di liquirizia. Lungo il finale e ben bilanciato.

Bottle at the Headkeeper. Pours a reddish-black, tan head that sticks around for awhile. Aroma is a mix of coffee, bakers chocolate, malt and some vague ripe fruit notes. Flavor is an impressive blend of malt, ripe fruit, caramel and very light smoke notes. Finish is slightly dry.
One of the definitive doppelbocks out there - absolutely delicious and perfectly balanced.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with retentive tan head. Aromas of molasses, grass and earthiness. Flavors of caramel, molasses, cereal grain, and a fruity note, perhaps raisin. Nice mouthfeel. This beer is all about the balance. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Bottle.  Pours a beautiful dark brown with a nice thick beige head.  Aroma is of lots of sweet malt, fruit (raisins and cherries/almonds), some smoke.  Flavor is that and more, balanced with just enough hoppiness.  The flavor reminds me somewhat of a smoky scotch.  Really subtle, well incorporated flavors.  Feels creamy, maybe a bit oily on the tongue.  This is a damn fine Doppelbock, best Ive ever had.  It has the sweetness and alcohol youd expect in a Doppelbock, but its so nicely balanced that I could drink this all night -- probably couldnt walk then!  Love the goat hanging around the bottle neck.

12 oz bottle served in a clear pint glass.  Pour was a deep, cola like brown with about three fingers of thick tan head.  Nose is malt, caramel, barley, cellar, bread, and earth.  Taste is exactly the same, with perhaps some light chocolate notes.  This is a very tasty brew.  Everything about it is delicious, and is quite sessionable.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Plutôt cuivré, mais très foncée, elle dégage des arômes et des saveurs de caramel et de chocolat, style toffe. Pratiquement opaque, elle est très bien maltée et riche. Complexe et délicieux elle dégage des notes de noisettes et de boisé. Le boisé apparait de plus en plus alors que la biere prend la temperature de la piece.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark brown or black with a brown head.

The smell is of malt and butterscotch, and a bit of a molasis flavor.

The taste is of roasted malts, caramel, and molasis.

This beer is a bit on the heavy side but does not put to hard over the edge. It is very flavorful and perfect for the beer drinker thats into that smoked dark taste.

Bottle. Great beer to mark my 300th rating. Pours deep brown with tan head. Lovely aroma of sweet malt, raisins. Taste is sweet malt, more rasins, nutty and light smoke. Well balanced and very smooth. Love it.

Bottle.  Cola like pour.  Large, foamy, brown head with a deep, ruby-brown body.  Clear.  Aroma of dark fruit - plum and dark cherry dominate.  Chocolate and molasses also come through.  Big, malty caramel and dark fruit flavor with a hint of some roast. Smooth palate - fairly soft carbonation, balanced body.  Sweet, but with appropriate, balancing bitterness.  Leaves a pleasant stickiness in the mouth followed by slight, warming alcohol.  Overall this beer is not as big, outrageous and complex as I had anticipated, but I think it is the better for it.  A great example of how a great beer doesnt have to blow your face off with aroma and flavor.  Sometimes subtleness works the best.  Overall ultra smooth and very enjoyable.

330 ML bottle in USA, I had to come all the way to the US to try this but I understand not why it is the best rated Germany beer. A great one but it does not belong in the number one position. Great black brown color with a very deep dark brown head. Strong malt aroma that hides but is good. Very smooth. A great DoppleBock.

Bottle served in a dimpled mug. Dense dark brown in color with 1/3 of the mug billowing with a beautiful tan froth, as depicted on the bottle art. Caramel malt, prunes, bread, and a slight woody aroma. Terrific nose. Decent carbonation followed closely by a roasty, creamy texture. Medium body. Long, roasty, oily finish. Rich, complex, and complete. There isnt a better Doppel.

Pours deep brown with a tall light brown head. Looks fucking epic.Has a sweet malty aroma with notes of dark fruits and bread. Flavour is rich and malty with notes of bread, plumbs, very full flavoured. Excellent palate from bigging to end, hand down the best lager I have EVER had.  Just plain wicked.

Great bottle design for this classic beer. Pours a rusty ruby red. Dark cherries, bourbon, slight smoke, licorice, bacon...wonderful flavour highlights. This beer is smooth, rounded and complex with a semisweet syrupy finish. One of the best.

The true question here is if it gets an extra appearance point for the freaking awesome goat hangin on the bottle? This has to be within the top ten beers I cant believe I havent rated yet. Well I found one chillin out in my fridge and its time has come.  Pours with a big full head, fizzy but lasting. The color is a deep brownish amber. Aroma is nutty with some sweet malt character and some coffee, not too sweet though fairly well balanced.  Flavor is basically perfect for the style, very rich, nutty, balanced but on the sweeter side, brown sugar, some mild noble hops, some very clear raisin and dark fruit notes, some molasses and coffee. Complex and delicious.

Bottle thanks to HogTownHarry. Dark brown with a creamy head and some lacing. Very sweet with prominent caramel and brown sugar in the both the nose and flavour. The alcohol wasnt hidden too well, but it certainly did not offend. Touch of spice in the finish. Altogether a great beer.

33cl bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with big and persistent beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, alcohol, coffee, caramel. Flavor is roasted malt, dried fruits, alcohol and a bit of coffee. Full-bodied with medium carbonation. Soft finish with some bitterness. My first doppelbock was an amazing experience!
bottle... going off of memory from a sample i had years ago.....heavy and malty very good with my chocolate cake as i recal

This beer pours a nice dark brown with a frothy light tan head that remains. Aroma is molasses and roast malt, also plum and raisin with a milkyness. Flavor is deep roast with a light sweetness, almost tastes smoked. Nice body with smooth carbonation. Finishes with a pleasant lingering roast and is perfectly balanced.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Malty malty malty!  Thats the word for the aroma and more.  Notes of molasses, chocolate, nuts, & faint traces of fruits.  Lovely DARK brown color with compact light tan head.  Wonderful malty, lightly roasted, chocolate, and nut flavors with again a hint of dark fruits.  Finishes dry for such a malty bier, very drinkable.  Perfectly bittered for balance.  Wonderful viscosity, not too thick or thin, again aids in the drinkability.  Overall an enjoyable bier, easy to see why its the top rated Doppelbock.  Very drinkable, reminiscent of a good scotch ale without the smokey notes.

Poured nice brown and nice cream colored head, smelled of chocolate and dark fruit with a roasted complex note.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, with a little hop backing that was rich and velvety on the tongue.  Overall an excellent doppelbock ruined a bit by the alcohol taste.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 Bottle. Poured a rich dark brown almost black in color it had a nice light brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. 

The aroma was moderate of roasted malts, a light resin hop and nice dose of doughy yeast with notes of molasses and coffee. 

It tasted mildly sweet with a hint of molasses in the beginning and finished slightly bitter-sweet with a rich coffee note at the end that left the flavor lingering around for a nice long while. 

Mouthfeel was surprisingly medium in body and very creamy in texture with a flat carbonation. 

Overall one of the best brews I have ever tasted. I sampled this years ago and have to say it still tastes as good as I remember. Definitely in my top 10...

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2010 Bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet, juicy, liquor like malt, dark fruits (mostly prunes), with some light hoppy notes in the background. Flavor is very rich, sweet malt and dark fruits with floral hops in the long finish. Simply Great!
Pours dark brown.  Complex and interesting taste, but palate ends too sweet.  Ends up tasting more like an extreme nut brown.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2009 Pours a dark chocolate brown with a small tan head that doesnt last very long. Aroma is sweet, with a lot of roasted malt, chocolate, and, dark fruit. The flavor is light and less sweet compared to the aroma, but just as complex and well balanced. Has a light but creamy palate, with a subtle sweetness and a dry finish. Wonderful brew.

330 ml. Bottle. Pours a deep, dark brown with red hues and a thin tan head that dissipates quickly but lasts throughout. Fair lacing. Huge bisquity malt aroma with lots of caramel and raisins.  Flavor is complex with a rich malty sweetness, some toastiness, dark fruits and honey. A hop bitterness in the finish, almost peppery. Beautifully balanced. Not cloying at all. Medium body. Slightly warming.

Purchased "on a whim" in Astoria, Oregon.  At first I thought $3.30 was a bit steep for such a small bottle, but afterwards, this was indeed a bargain!  It poured a terrific dark and thick glassful, along with a surprisingly small head, what there was being thin and tan.  Aroma was rife and rich with malts and spices, and it tasted just that, too.  Utterly delicious to drink, along with a "solid" mouthfeel and a (slightly) sweet finish.
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2009 This was a rich and flavorfull beer. Fantastic taste, deep rich flavor! Every bit as great a beer as most here claim it to be!

Rating #1200. Courtesy of Anker. Bottle. Poured dark brown with a long lasting tan head. The nose is heavy malty, bit roasty, lots of fruit, caramel, nuts and very complex. Flavour is bready malts with some rye, light roasted, caramel and sweet tobacco. Creamy texture. This is super quality. The best bock Ive ever had by far.

Original review date 2/9/2008...

Poured from bottle into pint glass. Pours like a Diet Coke - dark and carbontated with frothy pale head that dissipates quickly. Looks like powerful syrupy stiff.

German chocolate aroma - a little soft, a sour, sorta metal. After about 15 minutes it reveals a toasted nut texture - almost like pecan pie. Strong, smoked malt taste - a little too puckering at first but develops slowly. Still slightly sour. Alcohol and malt are there in force - could be a little better blended but still well-balanced. Short-to-medium finish. Carbonation is long gone a few minutes after pour - first sip is a little clammy; a few minutes later its very soothing. This needs a little while to breathe, sort of like wine. Most likely best enjoyed in a dark, warm setting - bar, ski lodge, German brew haus, etc. - powerful, well-made stuff.

330mL bottle courtesy of matt7215 for my 600th rating! Thanks Matt! This gem pours a dark brownish amber with a small tan head. Perfect aroma of Munich, Caramalts, chrystal malts, toffee, bready-biscuity caramel, and awesomeness (which is a real smell you know). Flavour is just delicious, so complex, yet so drinkable. Sweet malty complexities upfront are balanced by a dry bite in the finish, subtle hop aspects and some smoke. Biscuity as I would expect, something I love about dark lagers.
