On the doppelbock front, only bettered by Curator, IMHO.Earlier Rating: 3/13/2007 Total Score: 3.8Rerate: bottle 500ml (Alko) (6-4+-7-4-14=3.5)
BLack, brief tan head. Plummy aroma. Smooth palate, gentle tingle of
carbonation. Sticky roasty malty retronasals, a touch marmitey. Decent
full roasty body. slightly spikey thin hopping. Good but not as good
as the best keg.
Rerate of Keg (One Pint, Helsinki)
Black, thick head. Sour aroma. Feels great in the mouth. Rich, dark,
and sweet. Excellent beer.
Rerate of 500ml bottle  (5-5-6-2-12=3.0)
No appreciable aroma at first, but a smooth but somewhat
nondescript aroma does come through eventually. Taste ranges from
creamy to bitter to metallic. The keg version is better than this
sample.

50cl bottle at the Oak Barrel, Helsinki Airport. Dark tawny colour with a ring of tan head; intense earthy malt aroma; silky, thick, tracle-like consistency, not over sweet with a slightly spicy taste and a long bitter finish. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2010 This is perhaps one of my favorite beers. Excellent color, aroma, taste, good head retention. Very malty and excellent use of hops. Alcohol pleasently
noticable. Drinks easy. I even purchased a speacial glass to drink this.
I will attempt to brew this some day.

Served cold from bottle. Pours a dark brown with an off-white head. Definite aroma of malts and maybe some fruit or cocoa. Taste is rather smooth at first, giving way to a nice, strong fruity flavor. Quite a good beer.

Pours a good head and is dark and inviting. Smells good, like a malty sweet beer . It has a strong coffee flavor thats combined with a nice hoppy after taste. Its a smooth beer and is drinkable. Its flavor is strong, but that doesnt deter you from drinking it down. It holds a good lacing till the end and warms you nicely.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a khaki-colored head. Malts are apparent and so is the alcohol. While noble, this is probably not my doppelbock of choice.

Pours a deep copper into the glass with minimum head.  The aroma is toasty and burnt.  This beer is rich in flavor with a ton of maltiness and spiciness on the tongue.  There is a small alcoholic taste that adds to the warming of this doppelbock.

Ah .. Celebrator with the little goat on the top.  Surprisingly enough, my tasting compatriots fought over the goats ... the ladies thought they were cute.  As to the beer, a rich warming malty backbone with added dark fruit and roasted malt.  A bit sweeter than I generally like, but this worked well since it was so delicately balanced.

Bottle.  Excellent beer.  Pours to a nice cola color with a fluffy light tan head. Malty aroma with a medium body.  Little to no fizz.  Appears it would be sryupy but was actually watery.  Short medium begging with the middle being long & full body with a quick mild end.  Malty after taste.  Reminds me of an Irish Stout (Guiness) but not as heavy.  Outstanding beer.

bottle.  an excellent doppelbock.  pours a brown color with a 1/4" head.  slight malty aroma... medium body, and a great overall palate.  the roasted malts stand out the most in this, but other flavors such as molasses, caramel and a nutty finish come through.  Doppelbocks are not even close to my favorite styles, but this one delivers.  Highly recommended.

Bottle at ØLbaren. Dark brown - brown head. Raisins, ryebread, chokolate, high honey, dark dried fruits, caramel, malty sweetness. Very tasty !!Earlier Rating: 10/11/2007 Total Score: 3.4Bottle at Sunes. Black - tan head. Burned, dry burned, watery body & mouthfeeling, light coffee, bitter schwartzbrot, bruwn sugar raisins, plums. Not at all interesting complex and powerfull enough.
bottle. brown with nice white head. Malt, caramel, toffee, fruit.  Excellent balance and length.  Quite an impressive beer. Complex and deep.

Bottle. Finished brown color. Thick white head. Not much carbonation. Lots of aroma here. Chocolate, roasted malts, toffee, Raisin, and more that i couldnt nail. Flavors similar to aroma. Strong roasted malt, chocolate notes. Raisin and thickness. Full strong alcoholic body. Ends thick and sweet. $17 a 4 pack

A: This beer shines a nice mahogany ruby color when held to the light but doesnt have quite as much head as Id like. There was a thin light mocha colored head that fell very quickly leaving only a rim around the glass.

S: There is a surprisingly strong roasted aroma with a good raisin scent and some chocolate in the background. The strong malt flavor, which I expected to be very bold, was hidden in between the raisin and the chocolate.

T: The malt that was missing in the aroma was very prevalent in the flavor. There is a strong raisin flavor and some caramel notes. Some bitterness is hidden in there but is overwhelmed by the sweetness

M: This is a good medium bodied beer that is incredibly smooth.

D: Although its perhaps a bit sweet for drinking a bunch of them, it is an excellent example of a doppelbock.

Bottle into pilsener glass.  This is the one that started it all.  I should be saving this rating for a milestone, but Im impatient.  My appreciation for good beer began in the University of Chicago Pub under Ida Noyes Hall during my fourth year there, when Chris Quiroga handed me a bottle of this and told me to try it.  He had just recently discovered it, and wanted to share the experience; Im glad he did.  I remember that on that occasion in 2002, my only comment was that there were layers to the flavor, three distinct ones that I could not describe but could definitely taste.  Ill try to be more descriptive this time.  Pours with an oatmeal head that is creamy and filmy, over a dark but clear ruby brown beer.  Very musty bready smell, with a buttery sweetness and some fruity alcohol notes.  Luxuriously full, the malty sweetness coats the whole mouth; then, the flavor gives way to dark grains, prunes/raisins, and twiggy earthiness (still juicy, though, not dusty); the third layer gets almost bitter and dry, intensifying the earthy qualities in a mild roastiness and a cracker malt character over the top.  The first layer also belies the fruitiness, like malted grapes (if such a thing makes sense; Im thinking like malted milk, not malted barley), before it really takes center stage on the second level.  This is still a world-class beer, even after all these years, and will forever be a sentimental favorite.

Draft from The Box Bar in Plymouth, MI.  Deep brown to black in color.  Short head.  Sweet taste of molasses and licorice, with some smoke.  Nicely carbonated.  Medium-thick mouth feel.  An exceptional beer.

A black color tuns dark red when held up to a lamp. Thick tan head. Burnt chocolate, chicory smoke smell. Lightly carbonated with a medium body. Very smooth chocolate malt and roasted nut flavor. The smoothness is nicely balanced by a tangy alcohol bite on the tongue. dec 1996
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: The highest rated doppelbock eh?  Not nearly as sweet/malty as I was expecting.  Begins medium to full bodied, slightly sweet and ends in what was the highlight for me:  the smoky, roasty, dry lingering finish - with a touch of rye bread.  Stout like perhaps?  Teeming with complexity and a great beer to put down or sip on.  Nice!

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2013 Dark brown with a lasting, creamy, off white head. Big bready aroma, some grain, some caramel and a hint of sourness. Bready, malty flavour rather dry for the style, some roast malt in the finish. 6-4-7-3-15=3.5
On tap at Mikkeller Bar, June 2010: Clean dark malts, with a touch of smoke. Big malty flavour with a fruity touch, some roast and smokey notes, and a long complex malty aftertaste. Clearly in better shape than the bottle I rated ack in 2007. 8-4-8-4-16

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of tbone_. Pours a clear, dark, orangey brown with a beige head. Fat, sweetish aroma of roasted malt and overripe fruit. Very full-bodied with sweet notes of caramel and overripe fruit. A slightly oxidized edge without being faulty as such. Solid German bittering hops in the finish. 201107Earlier Rating: 6/9/2005 Total Score: 3.4(Bottle 33 cl) Dark - almost black - beer with a reddish tint and an impressive, tall and sturdy head with a light brown color. Spicy, smoked with notes of caramel but actually quite dry. Not nearly as sweet as a typical Doppelbock. Actually quite stout-like - but a lot more potent. 050703

Finally I get the chance to taste this. Saw it so many times in the U.S. but never bought it. Bottle @ thewolf tasting. Pours clear dark brown with a good beige head though rather short lived. Aroma of sweet dark bread, softly roasted malt and caramel. Stickish mouthfeel. The flavour is quite sweet with roasted caramel, roasted malt, dark bread, alcohol and grains. Sweet roasty finish. Too sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Pours a nice dark brown color with a thick creamy head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and caramel.  Very well balanced beer with a nice amount of hops to counterbalance the roasted maltiness and dark chocolate.  On a side note this beers accompanying glassware is really cool.

Bottle @ Tasting at my place. 
Bought through Gul&Gratis.
Pours a beautiful clear, deep red-brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is rye bread, light caramel. Lots of malty sweetness. Sticky mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, but still rather dry. Some roasted oakiness, but generally way too sweet.
Dark brown.  Creamy oaky aroma.  Creamy oaky taste.  Smooth but lingers on the taste buds.  Good medium body. Oakiness can hang around too long keeping it from great.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel, straw, and malt, as well as hints of alcohol. The flavor is very sweet with notes of caramel and alcohol, which burns slightly in the throat, leading to a dry bitter and alcoholic finish.Earlier Rating: 4/3/2004 Total Score: 4.4The aroma is strong, sweet with notes of prunes, brown sugar, citrus, coffee, malt, and bitter chocolate. The color is deep red-brown and it has a beutiful lasting light brown head. The flavor is sweet malty with very strong roasted notes; coffee, roasted bread, combined with caramel, alcohol, citrus, and more - great complexity. The alcohol runs prickling over the tongue and gives it a good palate.
One of my personal favorites. Has a nice hoppy taste mixed with a decent malt taste. Pretty expensive (3 dollars a bottle) but well worth it.

Bottle as Ayinger Winter Bock.
Clear red brown coloured with an off white head.
Malty aroma of caramel and rye bread with notes of dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of caramel, rye bread and dried fruits.
Nice.Earlier Rating: 5/13/2006 Total Score: 3.7Bottle.
Clear red brown coloured with a lasting off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel, grain and rye bread.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and rye bread.

Bottled. Deep brown coloured. Chocolate, caramel and malts in the aroma. Sweet chocolate and caramel flavour with plenty of sweet bready notes. Slightly metallic finish. Medium to full bodied.Earlier Rating: 11/6/2002 Total Score: 4.3Beutiful dark brown with a tasty light brown head. Standard doppelbock aroma: coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, earth. A very good flavour. Even though its not as strong and powerful as many other doppelbocks, it has a rather smooth and velvety mouthfeel, but the dark flavours are not lacking. Some interesting smokyness in the finish. A fine brew.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 black pour with no head.  smells thick and malty with hardly any hops at all with some toffee notes.  very nice on the palate, it was thick but a good thickness.
A most excellent beer. Pours very dark with a chocolate looking nice head. From start to finish this beer is very well balanced and finishes nicely.

I was anxious to try this one.  Ive had it put back for a while and Im thanking myself now.  Poured a beautiful dark brown, almost too beautiful to drink.  But I digress.  Served a bit chilled and allowed to warm some.  Wonderful dark malty aroma and a taste to match.  Very complex, I note chocolate, caramel, and almost a coffee smell to this fine beer.  Im being careful to only  sip this because I want this to last.  Finishes with a wonderful aftertaste that keeps me wanting to have more.  Cant detect very much alcohol at all, they do a good job of hiding it.  To this point in my life, my favorite beer had been the Paulaner Oktoberfest.  Thats all changed now.  This is without a doubt the finest beer that Ive ever had the privelege to drink.  I hate to say it, but this makes everything else, including the Paulaner, pale in comparison.  The only down side is that this beer is $16.00 a 4 pack!!!  Thats ok, I will definitely splurge and have this again.  The rest of the Paulaner that I have sadly just wont be the same.
Very dark in color almost no light passes through.   Smokey roasted coffee and chocolate aroma.  think head.   This is what I judge all other beers against.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 old rating: 7/4/8/5/18-4.2
pours dark, almost black with ruby tint, fizzy upon pour, thin khaki head that dissipates quickly.
smell of malts, dark pitted fruits, caramel, bit musty in the background, hint of cocoa.
tastes of roasted nuts, sour up front, cocoa, prune and raisin, bitter on the back-end, faint smoky dry finish.

WOW! What an incredibly good beer! Drink was chilled. Very dark in color that allows almost no light to pass through. A very complex flavor that you must drink slowly and savor each sip. Everything is perfectly balanced. Highly recommended.

12 oz bottle. Perfect pour, dark brown with slight deep red highlights and a huge dense creamy light beige head. Aroma has a slight mustiness about it that contains dark fruit, figs, raisins, and caramel. Thick bodied yet velvety smooth. Big roasty flavor that lingers nicely long after you put the glass down. One smooth beer.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2009 At first I had this confused with the Optimator but then after a side by side, the Celebrator is much more roasty and coffee-like. 

Brilliant dark amber-brown with light brown head. A true dopplebock. 

Malty sweet "goats breath" nose on this beer, with some light roasted coffee aromas too. Some chocolatey toasty notes too. 

Medium to full bodied. Big Malt warmth, chocolate sweetness, slight hop tang but mostly a nice, earnest malt flavor profile. 

Finish is very coffee like to me. Bravo!

Bottle: Poured a deep dark black/brown with a thin light brown jello head. The aroma is roasted malt, caramel, but also has a veggie like hint to it not the common German beer. The taste is a rich dark malt with roasted smokey dry finish. After almost a year searching for this treasure I found it in New Mexico, thats crazy since I live in Germany!

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown almost black with a medium light tan head. The aroma is a strong roasted malt. Good lacing on this one. The taste is a sweet malt and licorice with a clean finish, drinks like a stout. This was a superb Doppelbock.

12oz bottle poured into a large snifter. A strong sweet aroma of roasted malts and other unique autumn smells. A dark choclatly brown hue that lets no light pass. The head poured small and frothy. A most excellent taste of roasted malts and carmels with a velvety smooth feel, but not syrupy. An excellent dark brew.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2008 Deep dark brown with a creamy, yet bubbly head. Nose is darkly roasted malts with subtle hints of caramel, cocoa, and dried fruits: mostly fig and prunes . Medium in body and smooth on the tongue with a clean finish. An excellent fall beer. Very close to perfect. Excellent bang for the buck.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 Another Excellant Beer!!!! Pours a very dark opaque chocolate brown. Has a malty fragrance. Has a smooth and full taste with a malty flavor. This is very comparable to Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 I would give this a perfect score but I know it could be better in  a few minute ways. Either way, its dark, complex, and drinks like a classy stout.

Celebrator has a creamy head of tight bubbles contrasting beautifully with its profound dark robe. It is full-bodied and velvety from half a years aging. Although it is strong, it is not overpowering. There is a wonderful and complex balance between the various malts, the alcohol and the subtle hops. A complex fruitiness of roasted malt and whole hop flowers make Celebrator great as a party drink with friends and family at celebrations. Despite its richness, it has a faintly smoky dryness in the finish.

33 cl- bottle- Chef Pauls.  Not quite black, but nearly so.  Creamy head and lacing.  Sweet smoke aroma- Scottish ale in disguise.  Smoke and raisin up-front.  Like a German Quad, without the candi sugar.  A lot going on, quite complex.  Nice.
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2007 Pours almost black, not like the picture. Nice color. Nice lacing. Soy in the nose and taste. Raisins, smokey, starnge. Not really a fan.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 Pours a cola brown with little head. Nose is teryaki and soy, flavor is subtly the same, but with some oak. Pretty smooth, yet complex.
   This is the 2nd time trying this. I liked it less the first time, so I didnt rate it then in case I had a bad bottle. Im just not feelin this one.

color is very dark brown/red, almost black with a medium creamy caramel head that leaves an attractive lace. Pleasing aroma of light hops and roasted coffee and malts. Complex but well balanced flavors of coffee, roasted malts and raisin/prunes. Dry, Oaky, medium bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 This supreme dopplebock is dark amber in color (nearly black) and pours with a rich, complex body.  The moderate initial head leaves a nice lace throughout.  The powerful, robust flavors have a oak-aged foundation to them and include chocolate, coffee and a hint of raisens/cherries.  The mouthfeel is perfectly smooth and thick while the finish is firm and satisifying.  An almost perfectly blended beer that I appreciate more and more as I try other - inferior - brews.

Pours a dark ruby with a dense dark tan head. Fruity nose (maybe a slight boiled vegetable edge to the nose) has a smooth tiramisu flavour coupled with an intense fruitiness. Finishes quite dry with a hint of heather and pepperyness.

Pors very dark brown with really lnice big head. Aroma has hints of spice, smoke, chocolate. Taste has caramel, malt and hints of alcohol. Really nicely balanced with a full body and great aftertaste. Really is a world class beer.

11.2 oz bottle 4pack.  pretty expensive, but worth the money.  nice dark red color, tan head that dissipated pretty quickly.  just the right amount of bitterness.  it overpowered the food i was eating so i had to finish the beer first.  very good doppelbock in general.

Cellared this for a year.  Pours dark like a soda with a thin cream head.  Aromas of nuts, toffee, sorghum, and vanilla with no appreciable hop bouquet.  Mellow flavors of molasses, soil, and hickory smoke (this would be a great bbq sauce ingredient).  Full bodied.  Long, crisp finish.

(bottle): Pours a dark brown red color, some head tannish color. Belgian aroma, dark fruit, sugary, malty. Dark roasted flavor, wood, litlle dark fruit. Roasted aftertaste. Some alcohol, portorish. Okay for a porter-like taste.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a nearly black ruby.  1.5 cm tan head, mostly diminishing.  Aroma of malt and hint of coffee.  Sweet initial taste, coffee finish and aftertaste.  Medium to full body, light carbonation.  Alcohol is hidden well, shows up a little on the back end.  Very drinkable and well worth the money spent.
Enjoyed from Bottle.  Pours with a nice head.  Full bodied.  Flavors of Malt and Espresso - very complex.  Perfect dyness to the finish.  One of the best Doppelbocks around.

Bottle - 330ml. Dark brown body with good carbonation and a thick brown foamy head. Very nice malty/hoppy aroma with roasty, fruity, brown sugar and chocolate hints. Taste is very well balanced. It carries vineous and plummy notes, and ends with a very long, warming bittersweet finish. Excellent example of Doppelbock.

Liquorloft Tallahassee, bottle. wish i would have poured the stuff but didnt have a decent glass around. first thoughts on the smell were deep roasted malt and sweetness. the taste was straight up sweet robust malt. no alcohol detectable just a whole lot of thick delicious sweet malt. the body was something else that really adds to this beer, thick and creamy in consistency. glad a got another 3 bottles to drink on.

Bottle in Northfield, MA. Dark brown colour with hazelnut foam. Hoppy, skunky nose. Coffee, Malt, Roast flavours. Also sweet-brown sugar. Smooth and creamy and silky. Surprised this is considered the best German beer.

Pungent aroma of deep roasted malt, some deep fruits, some sourness in the aroma as well.  Great.  Lots of complexity.  Very dark orangy brown.  Nice tan head that lasts.  Great beer.  Lots of roasted malt, dominates the flavor.  Not much hops until the very finish with some bitterness.  Tons of roast really, even til the very finish.  No alcohol detectable, some sweetness.  Mouthfeel is full, not too carbonated, nice.  Really great beer, would most certainly drink this again.  Wish it had a little more alcohol to it.
Poured dark amber with white head. Aroma of sweet malt and some fruit. Good sweet flavor with some fruit. Finished kind of rough.
What can be said about this beer that hasnt already been stated. Its dark, smooth, and tastes damn good. Not overwhelming, but not weak, its just right, feels great and fishes even better.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2007 WOW! I usually dislike doppelbocks but this changed my mind. I absolutely loved this. I recommend you enjoy this with your best friend, a Cuban/Italian girl, her boyfriend and his mom . It enhances the flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 The best doublebock that Ive ever had.  I tried it after the paulaner and, even though the paulaner was still very good, this beer was better.  It even come with some ram keychain thing.  It has a dark amber colour, almost black, with a somewhat light tan head.  It has a moderately fruity taste to it with practically no hop taste.  I drank this out of a Tankard.
It had a very dark brown body, but not very much head.  It had a strong aroma and flavor of toasted malts which really made this beer stand out.

Pours a clear, almost black with an off-white dimminishing head. Very sweet with heavy malt aromas of molasses and roasted malts. Also some plums, raisins and brown sugar. Medium bodied. Fizzy carbonation. Medium to short duration dry finish. I like the toasted malt aromas together with the sweetness.

Bottle. Aroma is dark, slightly smoky, malt. Color is opaque brown with a beige head that quickly filmed. Thin to medium bodied, with a mild carbonation. Sweet darkly roasted malt flavor, suggestions of coffee, arguably a little smoke. Could be floral hop, as theres a certain fruitiness. The finish is dryer than might be expected, there is a small bitter note, and a faint smokiness, as advertised. Really quite delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2011 Re-rate: this is a great beer. About time I revisit it. Very rich dark fruits, dark malts, very smooth. A drinkable brew but very hefty. The roasted malts dont come out as heavy roast or metal but just more dark fruit. Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a good head that goes down fast. A complex taste of fruit, malt, hops, alcohol and a flowery taste. Really nice and well made.
UPDATED: SEP 29, 2007 12 oz bottle purchased at Big C liquor in Orlando, FL. One of favorite beers.

Bottled, Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Poured black with dark cream/beige head. Malty, fruity aroma with a slightly hoppy finish. This is by far my favourite Doppelbock and its worth buying for the little souvineir goat too :)

12oz bottle - Poured black with a hint of red at the edges. A large foaming head that stuck around for 1/2 the drink. Aroma was fruity like wine. Taste was excellent with so many flavors. I could taste the roasted malt along with a slight hop taste. It left a warm feeling in my belly, almost felt like I was drinking a fine wine. A great beer for sipping but not for guzzling. This beer has to be one of my favorites so far.

Dark brown nearly black color with a creamy head and ruby highlights.  Aroma is strongly toasty maltiness.  Taste of rich roasted maltiness is complimented nicely with a slight hoppiness in the back of the throat.
This beer will kick your ass.  It is enjoyable.  Plus you get a souvenir.  But if i drank this regular id  be in trouble.  Damn good beer.  Best double bock l have had.
I will never tire of this wonderful Doppelbock.  On draft or in botttles this is quite refreshing anytime of the year.

Pint bottle from Bevmo. Poured a dark brown that only a trace of light will shine thru. Head was tan and faded to about 1/4 inch and held. Aroma is strong with coffee, chocolate, anise and burnt toast. Flavor mirrored the aroma. Mouthfeel was smooth and creamy with light by effective carbonation. Hops were well integrated and hardly noticeable. Finish is long and smooth with some additional burnt cedar wood. Overall this is one great beer, my only complaint is that the bottle is too small, this should be served in a bomber.
Bottle, Dark creamy head, strong aroma nuts coffee and choclolate. Smooth tasting doppelbock. not my style.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2011 Re-rate 11/7/11: Bottle shared at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Shachar for this bottle! Brown color with a medium beige head. Aroma of lots of malt, some roastiness, caramel, a bit of fruitiness and hints of chocolate. Sweet malty caramelly flavor with some roastiness, nutty notes and notes of chocolate. Medium to full-bodied. A good Doppelbock, but not nearly as good as I remembered it. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Bottle from a great trade with Koelschtrinker (thanks!). Dark brown, almost black, with a big light brown head. Outstanding malty aroma with roastiness, dark chocolate, caramel and some dark fruits. Sweet, rich, malty flavor, with chocolate, some coffee, some roast and prunes. A caramelly sweet finish with mild notes of hoppy bitterness and some alcohol. Full-bodied. Really great. 9/5/8/4/18=4.4

Bottle: I thought about saying that I agree with what Taktik_MTL said, but then I realized that I dont speak French.  Nevertheless, good dark pour with thick head.  Sweet molasses flavor and good finish.  Best (and only) doppelbock that I have ever had.

Bouteille de 330 ml achetée chez Beverage Warehouse (Winooski, VT). Arôme: Odeur de caramel foncé et de petits fruits. Apparence: La couleur est brune foncée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de malt avec une pointe chocolaté. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #1227)

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2007 Bottle. Pours dark brown/ruby with thin tan head. Aromas of malty molasses and dark fruit. Flavor is the same, sweet molasses and raisin, but balanced by very subtle hops on the finish. The finish is just right, with only mild lingering sweetness and bitter. The palate is smooth and slightly viscous, with minimal carbonation. Nice sipping beer, but not a daily drinker for me...just a bit overwhelming on the malty sweetness.
33 cl bottle, Fargo. Deep brown opaque with a purplish hue, thin creamy head. Spicy malt and alcohol aroma, Very pleasing mix of spice/bitter and sweet. Long spicy finish, very nice.

this is the finest beer I have ever had.
nice full flavor will always return to this Dopplebock.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2007 12 oz bottle poured black thin head to slight lace. Sweet caramel malt aroma with some coffee notes. Medium creamy mouth feel Sweet toasted malty flavor some raisin fruitiness .The best doppelbock I have ever had and Garrett Oliver was right this paired great with venison

Pours black as night with a little thin caramel head that doesnt last long at all.  Smells of coffee, chocolate and maybe a bit of toffee like a Heath bar.  Great mouthfeel with a subtle but perfectly carbonated liquid swirl around my tongue.  The taste is much like the aroma yet slightly sweeter.  The alcohol is hidden fairly well to boot.

I drank the Celebrator (bottle) at the Grill in Tucson. It was pretty steep at five bucks, but was probably worth it. Im not too familiar with the doppelbock style, so I didnt know what to expect. The aroma and taste were a bit subtler than what I wouldve guessed, not as chocolatey or roasted. Neither the alcohol nor the hops were all in-your-face. Anyways, the Celebrator was fantastic! and I got a cool little Christmas ornament on the bottle.

jet black pour with a porter-esque head straight from the bottle.  the head recedes to just a faint hint of silk and richness around the edges.  aromas of a milky way bar blend with gooey toffee and mildly roasted espresso beans.  dark raisins are the predominant fruit i get, as well as ripe plum.  also, there is an element of homemade deep-south molasses.  the taste matches it completely, and the finish lingers with that dark fruit concoction and a mild fizziness.  theres also a chocolate element here that is just an undertone, but i cant place it.  best doppelbock ive had.

My first 100th percentile beer Ive tried, my first of this style, and my 100th Ive rated.  Not bad!  Bottle.  Has hints of caramel in the smell.  A bit heavier on the palate than I usually like.  Smells and feels (on the palate) like molasses.  Creamy, but not overly rich.  Bitterness is a little underplayed for my liking.  Can feel the warmness of the bit more alcohol.  Has hints of earthiness in the flavor.
UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 11.2 oz. bottle. Nice dark ruby color with ample, creamy head. Tastes great with a meal or stand-alone. My favorite doppelbock.
Good balance of hop and caramel on the nose, only lacking in strength. Deep garnet tinged brown color. Thick tan head. Horehound taste. Weak woody finish.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 
Name: Celebrator Doppelbock
Date: August 25, 1996
Mode: Bottle
Source: The Baker, Omaha, NE
Appearance: very dark amber, headless
Aroma: rich malt aroma with just a touch of esters and toastiness
Flavor: rich eastery malt flavor with just a bit of underlying balancing hops

Name: Celebrator Doppelbock
Date: February 23, 2005
sweet malty aroma, 

Name: Celebrator Doppelbock
Date: April 13, 2006
Source: Wild Wing, Marietta
such a wonderful rich and sweet aroma and flavor with a great creamy body, the benchmark dopplebock that puts all others to shame

Name: Celebrator Doppelbock
Date: March 08, 2007
Mode: bottle
Source: Blind Tasting
Score: 3.2
Appearance: very dark ruby red, fine tan head, streaks of lace
Aroma: big sweet dark caramel malt aroma with a touch of roasted
Body: big body
Flavor: rich malt flavor, a touch of the roasted comes through in the flavor, earthy bitterness, a thread of caramel sweetness runs through it

Name: Celebrator Doppelbock
Date: November 17, 2009
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
picking up a nice earthy smokeyness in both the aroma and flavor, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.9/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Bottle, with goat. I noticed that after all these years I hadnt rated this one, nor any of the Ayinger beers. Not an oversight on my part but pure laziness. We used to drink this one quite often at the Old Chicago in Tempe, Arizona. I could have built up a mountain of goats 6-7 years ago. In an effort to be true to my ratings Ive gone back and bought them again......a 4 pack of this one to be precise and Im on the second. It pours dark with a disapearing tan head. Aroma is quite rich, full of malt, espresso, brown sugar, dark chocolate, and light soy. Smooth and lightly carbonated on the tongue. Flavors are malty and grainy and lightly sweet, with some light chocolatey bitterness, maybe a hint of dark caramel, and good wholesome roastiness. Finish is fairly dry which compliments the sweet middle. Overall, a very nice beer and its no wonder we bought so many of these goat encrusted mofos at Old Chicago back in the day.

dark, dark ruby brown color with a medium sized tan head. roasted and smoky sweet malt aroma with some raisin and spice. medium thick body and soft carbonation. strong maple syrup flavor with some soy sauce and plum. there is a light undertone of grass. rich and complex beer.

Draught. Will have to try this again as my pint MAY have been compromised. A distinct soy sauce aroma and taste was evident, A characteristic I consider a flaw. Full bodied. Smoke notes. A touch too bitter and somewhat acrid. Not a very memorable brew.
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2007 Warm toffee notes, poured a respectable head, slightly tinted brown. Strong full bodied flavor, intense roast, yet some spice and raisin that I wasnt expecting.  Superb.
this is a wonderful Doppelbock rivalling my all time favorite Spaten Optimator. and you get a free toy with every bottle!

Bottle at Delerium, Brussel. Brown of color with a brown head. A grainy aroma with notes of chocolate, coffee, prunes and sweet fruits. A flavor of spice, prunes, dark fruits, low carbonated and bitter finish.

(Bottle, Delirium Café, Gothenburg, 31 July 2007) Black colour with ruby notes, frothy brown head. Malty nose with roasted malt, dark rye bread, wort and a hint of brewing-house. Malty taste with dark rye bread, wort, chocolate and notes of coffee towards the finish. Dryish, grassy bitterness in the finish. Chewy mouthfeel, medium to full body. Great doppelbock in perfect balance.

Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black, with a creamy tan head. Malt-forward aromas of roasted grain, chocolate, coffee, tangy dough, and some faint dark fruit. Flavor is smooth sweet and sour dark malt, with a chewy graininess throughout. Sweet finish lingers on the tongue, but is not overbearing. Quite tasty, I could drink this stuff forever.

i got it as "ayinger winter-bock" which seems to be the actual name. dark red-brown colour, solid head. quite dry start. with roasted-malty aromes of toffee but primarly dry. later taste of caramel, ends with spicy aromes of herbs, cinnamon, cardamom, coffee. rich and full arome.Earlier Rating: 8/21/2007 Total Score: 4.2deep copper colour with foamy and solid head. smell of roasted malts. taste starts sweet, gets aromes of hops in the middle. chocolade and coffee. good balance. bottle comes with gimmick: a plastic bock is hanging  around the neck. should be two gimmicks because it is a doppelbock, but...

12 oz bottle from west lakeview liquors in Chicago.  Dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt, prune, fruit, some dough, very nice.  Flavor is malt upfront with a dark fruit finish, some red apple, tar, chocolate, very pleasant.  Med body with mild carb.  A very sweet but enjoyable brew, a classic.

Pours rich, brown, almost black. Wonderful, chocolate head, that dissapates into a beautiful lace.

Solid smell of roasted malt. Decent hop taste, mixed with a great feel of hops. 

A gentle alcohol bite finishes the taste. Glad I picked this up in a 4-banger!

Pours a dark brown with red highlights.  Thin tan head.  Very malty aroma and taste with some hop bitterness and astringent alcohol to balance it out.  Some roasted malt character too which I didnt anticipate.  Finishes a little sweet and lightly smoky.  Nice but not as good as Salvator.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 The pour is delightful, and the head is thick and creamy. Its dark but when held to the light there is a ruby tint.  A "liquid bread" experience starts with the intense malty aroma. Healthy and nourishing, evidenced by the thick creamy mouthfeel. Has a purity few other beers can even hope to have. Sweet malts end in a delightfully dry and smoky finish. This DB celebrates the essence of brewing and its always going to epitomize what I look for in any style of beer.

A big huge frothy dark beige head with suds like sea foam hang on this beer when its poured. I was first hit with coffee, then toffee and liqourice aroma. The color is dark brown with some pidgeon blood ruby and quite clear. Tastes warm and has a very deep caramel liqour flavor. 6.7% abv but tastes stronger. The nutty toffee flavor and malts hangs in your mouth nicely.  Thick and heavy in the mouth and a little slick.

Pours brown with ruby highlights, medium beige head. Aroma is vinious, some bitter coffee scents, sour/sweet malt scents and stale basement smells. Flavor is textured grainy malt, caramel, a little alcohol flavor and a touch of bitterness in the finish. Great rich and full palate. Easy drinking but also quite complex.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2010 Bottled as "Ayinger Winter Bock". A dark red near to black beer  with a nice creamy light brown head. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel. Sweetish taste with malt, caramel, nuts and toffeee. Medium bodied,  quite long bittersweet aftertaste. Not as good as the "Celebrator" but this is a very good warming beer.Earlier Rating: 10/29/2006 Total Score: 4.4Dark brown beer, with reddish reflections. The head is small and disappears fast. Great nose, roasted, with coffee and roasted notes and more herbal hoppy notes than expected. Very intense flavour. The beer is rich , very malty, sweet and complex, but more drinkable than many other doppelbocks. Very good palate: the body is full and the afterstaste is very long and pleasant. Great beer. Maybe the best German beer and surely the better doppelbock I have ever tried.
WOW! Excellent aroma, very malty. Nice raisin/plumb finish. If affordable, I would have a keg in my fridge year round.

Know as the "Goat" to my friends and I this beer is sweet, dark aroma comprised of roast malts, touch of chocolate, touch of coffee, and just a hint of molasses. Head was kinda thin but could have been the pour.

8/8/07 from the bottle.  Aroma is caramel and strong malt forward followed by dried fruit, peppermint! and light alcohol.  Appearance is dark brown with a medium light tan head.  Flavor is sweet, round malt with dried fruit and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, warm, with low carb texture.  Overall, nice complexity with delicious bread.
Very nice beer, from the nice head to the complex fruity taste. Very sweet, but not overly so. Thick mouthfeel. Id definitely have this again. I can understand why this is so highly rated!
Very nice.  Clean caramel and molasses aroma and flavor.  Nice clean finish.
One of my favorites.  Great  malty caramel aroma with a nice bite of carbonation.

The doppelbock that all other dopplebocks are judged by and for a good reason, this is a very good beer (and I DO NOT like anything that calls itself a bock).  It tastes like a mix of carmel and dark mollasses but finishes nice and clean.  Try it, its worth the time and money.  Hats off to Ayinger, the finest brewer in Germany.
Dark brown color, almost no head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of raisins, and figs. Very nice flavor, clean. The aftertaste is short lasting and pleasant. An awesome dopplebock. Have a few!

Hmmm....I just enjoyed Celebrator with a large belgian dark chocolate bar...

I picked up Celebrator in Calgary at Calgary Coop in North Calgary during stampede...

I was looking for a good doppelbock - I think I found it...unfortunately...I havent seen it in Kamloops...I hope it surfaces soon! There were only 4 bottles in the carton!

Its become my favourite caramel center to dark chocolate...
12 oz bottle purchased in Utah. Excellent little gem to my surprise. Very good. My friend says that he believes that this is the measurment of a good Doppelbock. No argument here.

12 oz bottle. Poured a dark brown with hints of ruby red. Small white/tan head. Nose is caramel, brown sugar, roasted malts. Taste is a complex mix of brown sugar, toffee,  and malts. The alcohol is well hidden. This is a rich, smooth wonderful brew. I loved it.
[Bottle] Pours dark red with a large tan head.  Aroma was chocolate, malty and brown sugar.  Taste was malty with a little bit of alcohol and low bitterness.  Was a little thin.  Decent finish.

Poured a really dark brown with a thin white head. Smells of dark fruits, caramel, some chocolate, and sweet malts. The taste is big of dark fruits, chocolate, caramel, and hint of smoke. Fully bodied with a nice silky texture on the tongue. The finish was real nice and dry with a hint of the smoke and some light hops. It got better as it warmed up with more of the flavors coming through. Pretty complex blend of flavors that was really well done. Really good beer.

Pours a deep brown with tons of ruby red highlights and a medium bubbly tan head that left some lacing.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, nuts, dark fruits, toasted sweet malts .  Flavor of sweet toasted malts, dark fruits, vanilla, some earthieness, nuts, veyr light hop bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Smells of sweet fig, molasses, and toasty caramel malt. Pours a deep auburn color with tall head that dissipates quickly. Tastes of caramel, dates, molasses, toasty malts, and bitter florals, - all in a medium-thin body that dances around the tongue for a bit. Very tasty, and well balanced.

A rich brown color with fluffy light brown head.  Chocolate malt mix (think Ovaltine and similar products) on the nose with a faint touch of caramel.  Smooth body with a thick caramel flavor that eventually yields to a light Ovaltine flavor.

Bottle. Has a very deep red color with a thin tan head. The aromas are working well together. There is this amazing milk chocolate aroma that combines well with notes of plums, caramel and a touch of sourness. Taste is of predominantly roasted coffee and malt throughout with some chocolate but starts and ends with sweet caramel and finally a bitter finish. Very good - I even like the little plastic goat that comes with the bottle.

4 pack bottles - Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Smells malty, roasted coffee, nutty, and a little sour.  Taste is dense, layers of subtle chocolate, coffee, malt, smoke, surprisingly medium light bodied for how thick it looks.  Slightly dry finish, this is a good beer, but a little too expensive for me to be a regular drinker.

Bottle... Poured a pretty murky, dark brown (almost stout or porter like) with a light brown head.  Sort of a sourness on the nose.  Beer had flavors of chocolate, barley-malt, with a dash of hops for some kick.  Overall pretty robust and complex but very drinkable.  Thats what I love about this style.  I had it with some fresh blueberries and they made a great pair.

Rated 7/19/07.  Deep dark brown pour.  Almost black.  Small off-white film that leaves behind minimal lacing.  The aroma is really nice.  I picked up mostly chocolate malts with a bit of coffee and perhaps the faintest hint of smoke.  The flavor is a rich blend of bitter and sweet chocolate, with a smokey, hoppy, dry finish.  Medium body makes this an easy drinking beer.  Very nicely done.  Similar to a smooth chocolate porter.  Great beer.
Bottle and tap.  Pours dark brown with beige head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of prunes and brown sugar.  Flavor is of sweet malts and caramel.  Well balanced and smooth.

Bottle from pat. Pours beautifully, amazing dark brown colour and lasting head. Aroma is sweet and malty, however balanced by what seems to be a roasty chocolate flavour. Taste is amazing an explsion thats super complex but never over powering and very balanced. Win Win Win with this fellow.

Poured a deep brown hue with a tan head, carbonation was minimal.  Aroma was slightly smoky and a little sweet, flavor was similar.  Overall the beer was great on draw back was the body was rather thin.
Bottle shared with fordest.  Pours surprisingly dark, brownish with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt and candied fruit.  Flavors of malt and dark fruit.

bottle: pours a dark brown with a quick fading cocoa head.  aroma is sweet, dark sugary fruit, malt, and just a small amount of chocolate and coffee. flavour is full and sweet with much more chocolate thatn the nose let on. it finishes very nicely with some coffee, smoke and dry with just a touch of bitter.
this is so smooth it is almost not beer. a fantastic beer for the palate. i like the way all the flavours blend and nothing really stands out on its own.

Bottle - Pours dark red / brown with creamy long-lasting head.  I like the way this beer looks.  Sweet but strong aroma of fermented fruit, brown sugar, coffee.  Complex flavors: roasted nuts, coffee, caramel, raisins, - sweet alcohol.  Good full-bodied mouth feel.  Very rich, but yet well balanced..... good hops end.  Goes well with seafood... smothered chicken, or even chicken fricassee.

500ml vom fass served in a special and very appealing Celebrator glass. Inviting appearance with its brownish foam over an almost black body with some rusty highlights. Nice "kirchenfenster" on the glass. Malty vapour including notes of prunes and plums. Deep and well bodied taste of chocolate and dark malts with the support of dried fruits. Smooth alcohol in the finish. Medium to full palate, but still easy to drink. A superb drink. No wonder it has been saluted among the very best beers in Germany. I guess my score has been a bit influenced by the atmosphere when drinking this doppelbock; it was used as a dessert at the end of a delicious dinner in the biergarten of the Brauereigasthof in Aying on a dark, but warm late evening in June - under flaming moonshine. Happy and satisfied we left Aying with four six-packs of assorted bottles from the brewery (17.06.2007).
the first time i drank this beer was in Bayside Miami FL at a little bar that was full of imports my bartender recommended this and now i wish i could find it somewhere near me in Missouri

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2007 On tap at the Brauereigasthof, Aying 17 Jun 07. A tanned head. Dark brown coloured - almost black. Sweet fruity and malty aroma. Complex roasted and malty flavor with hints of caramel.   No distict aftertaste, but a well balanced beer.
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 Bottle... perfect beer for me.  Everything I want in a beer and more. PERFECT, PERFECT, PERFECT!

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2007 Rich Mahogany pour with a light brown short lived head.  Looks nice, and smells even better.  Smells of Gingerbread cookies, mollasses, with some smokey, earthy tones.  Taste is malty, molasses, and some smokey earthiness  again.  It also has a tart, sourish twinge to the finish and a nice needed bitterish note to it.  Alcohol is hidden well, and this an awesome beer overall.  Still good, but I didnt like it as much the 2nd time around.
delicious roasted malt flavor balanced perfectly with the sweetness, amazing doppelbock, i love it.

05 bottle, over flowed on opening.  Intense roasted malt aroma, rich burnt caramel.  Pours dark brown almost black, light barely penetrates.  Smooth, smokey, roasted caramelly malt, hints of spicy hallertau hops, raisons, dark fruits.  Very rich and roasty, like a german porter.  Very nice.

dark copper brown with a tan head. raisin studded nut bread and toffee aroma. sweet toffee tart raisin flavor with some nut bread. tart raisin lightly spiced nut bread finish. medium dry. medium almost full body with moderate carbonation. warm alcohol throughout. very nice.

12 ouncer. Poured black with 2cm of tan head that held firm. Tight and foamy lacing with smells of stone ground coffee, subtle teriyaki, chocolate malt and soy sauce. Strong tastes of coffee bean, cocao, some wheat, and more chocolate toward the end. Firm carbonation with a supremely balanced body. Its a-nice.

Bottle. Pours beautiful deep, rich brown with dark amber highlights. Nice aroma: coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, charred oak and I think that theres just a hint of smoke lingering in the back. Creamy yet lively carbonation on the palate. Dry with some sweet malt hiding. Almost tastes like alcoholic coffee. I do find it a tad watery on the back of the palate. Finishes with some yeasty dryness.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 12 oz. bottle.  Aroma is of moderate-heavy roasted malt.  Notes of molasses and raisin. Average sized foamy light brown head that left fair lacing and mostly diminished.  Body is normally clear but dark reddish/brown. Flavor is lightly sweet and bitter with an average finish.  Palate is medium bodied with a very light oily texture and flat carbonation.  Lightly alcoholic finish.  A really good malty molasses brew.  Very drinkable.

Very deep ruby/brown and has a brown head with some longevity to it.  Powerful aroma -- chocolate, caramel, toffee, coffee.  Terrific sweet/roasty balance on the tongue.  Surely plenty for the palate to work with; plenty strong, but not overpowering.  A wonderful, wonderful beer.

Sweet roasted malt with a slight hint of leather and strawberries. Dark brown pour with ruby edges.  Great tan creamy head with lace.  Flavors evenly fill the palate with hints of sweet malt, and subtle hops with minimal bitterness.  Finish is clean and dry.  This beer is very diverse and would go great with a hearty meal, or as a stand alone.  Very good.

Pours a wonderful red color, with a nice sweet, malty aroma.  The flavor is wonderful, complex, and just first-class.  I dont think I can add anything new to this debate or to say anything further about such an incredible beer.  This is a winner through and through.

I found this dusty bottle, no idea how old, of Celebrator at a very old party store that was going out of business in my hometown.  I brought it to the register, and with no price on it, the guy charged me an arbitrary $2.  I laughed all the way home.  Ill leave the descriptions to those whove come before me.  Great beer.
Your nose cant help but go wild as you begin to pour. Has a deep, complex flavor that is overflowing with roasted malt. An overall lovely and robust beer.
Pours a brown caramel-like colour with a creamy top, noticed various malts, dry finish, pleasent aroma, and full palate

Poured dark brown with a little khaki head.  Had an awesome aroma of roasted malts.  When it first hits your palate you pick up some fruit of some kind and a little bit of spice.  The finish was very smooth and dry.  This beer was excellent and you even get a charm to keep like a toy after finishing a box of cracker jacks

Small filmy head on top of dark brown body.  Great aroma --  malty and coffee like.  Exceptionally smooth with significant carbonation.  Very drinkable for 7% ABV.  This would be very difficult for any beer drinker not to like.  I wished I had purchased this one before now.

color is cola black only showing slight hints of brown when held to the light. a 1 finger eggshell head forms after the pour  but quickly fades into a tight ring around the edge of the glass. nose has strong raisin and plum notes with a powerful robust aroma. strong raisin and prune notes are well matched by a winning combination of spicy hops and deep roasted malt. palate is full and the finish is smooth and dry. excellent.

Pours a perfect dark color.  Splendid aroma of roasted malt.  Amazing blend of malt sweetness and hoppy flavors roll across your tongue and cover your palate with the full spectrum of flavors that you want in a quality beer.  I had no idea that Ayingers Doppelbock was this highly rated until after I drank one.  Will definitely buy again.  Wonderful to experiment with food pairings.

Pours a nice dark reddish color with a small light tan head.  The scent was of malts, caramel and raisins.  The taste was nicely balanced with the level of sweetness and dryness working in harmony.  A very nice doppelbock.

Pours very dark with a reddish hue.  The aroma is very complex of sugar, roasted coffee, and malt.  It tastes of chocolate and malt with hints of rasin and toffee.  Not overly sweet and extremely well balanced.  Great example of a double bock.
Dark pour with a creamy head. Excellent balance. Just right. Not too sweet or dry. Mouthfeel is creamy. Wonderful stuff.

Creamy but not too thick, sweet but not cloyingly so, opaque but held up to the light its actually red in hue, this is a multi-dimensional brew. Flavors of toast and coffee. I havent had many doppelbocks but I will definitely be looking for some more, and would compare them up to this.
Pours dark ruby with milky head.  This is one great beer!  On the nose it has a light citrusy oak smell.  Tastes like wheaty, yeast with subtle hints of roasted malts, almost smoky.

Bottle.  Poured a ruby read with a medium but attractive tan head and good lacing. Nose is fantastic, with fruits, citrus, and chocolate, and just a little coffee.  Very smooth mouthfeel and a flavor of chocolate, coffee, and toast. But not burnt toast.  A remarkable brew. Slightly dry finish with a nice touch of hops.    Best dopplebock ever for me.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with some ruby highlights.  Lots of bubbles; mostly diminishing creamy tan head.  Nose is sweet with chocolate, roasted malt, and light hops.  Taste is caramel, chocolate, and liqorice.  Medium body, finishes slightly smokey and dry.  This ones a treat.  Very balanced, not too sweet & not too bitter.  So smooth, its like pajamas for your tongue!

THOUGHTS: A great doppel bock. Ive had several over the past couple months and this is probably the best. All malty goodness. Chocolate and coffee flavors and also some smokiness. A little less alcohol in the finish than I would prefer in a doppel, but still a great beer. I gave them a bonus point for the cool little goat ornament that comes around the bottles neck.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that looked black in the glass with re highlights with a average to large off-white head that mostly diminished but left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate to heavy milk chocolate and mild coffee, smoke, just a tad bit of alcohol and some dark fruit. The initial flavor was moderate sweetness, while the finish was heavy sweetness, light bitterness and sourness with a short to average finish. The body was medium to full and both dry and slightly syrupy with fizzy carbonation and a slightly chalky and lightly alcoholic finish.

Sweet malty aroma with some yeast and spices. Dark brown/purple color with a large tan head. Flavor is mildy sweet, not as sweet as other doppelbocks Ive had. Mild yeast taste on the finish. Creamy palate
This has become my favorite beer. Very smooth taste. Consistent, thick, and creamy head. Clean aftertaste. Great balance between hops and malt. Medium bitter flavor.

12 oz bottle.... black in color, no head.  Smells fantastic... some roasted malts, cherry, chocolate, coffee, caramel.  Tastes great too... so smooth, well-balanced flavor, perfect sweetness.  Slightly dry finish.  This is a great beer.

Pours a deep, dark brown with garnet highlights and a rocky tan head that diminishes to a ring clinging to the edge of the glass. The nose is of heavy, sweet, caramel malts. The mouthfeel is medium/full-bodied, creamy and soft; like liquid velvet. The flavor is a rich, malty caramel that is lightly effervescent with a warm mocha finish. This is an amazingly smooth and tasty beer. It is no wonder that this is the benchmark for the style.

Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock
12 oz bottle
Moderate pour in a tulip glass
Recent brewing, butted into 06/07

Poured a clear mahogony with a medium light frown fizzy somewhat diminishing head.

Smelt of strong raisins, roasted malt, dark caramel, almost molasses, some coffee black licorice and bananas.

Taste was upfront strong bittersweet raisin, black licorice, and roasted grain followed by a strong bitter yeasty and sweet dark sherry chocolate on a long finish.

Palate was medium bodied, creamy, softly carbonated and moderately astringent and slightly alcoholic.

Overall, this is a soft tasty doppelbock.    The flavors are layered and overwhelming, and I can see why this is the most appreciated doppelbock out there. Its hard to describe, but put simply it leaves a happy feeling in my mouth.
Black.Off-white head.The aroma is a nice blend of coffee,chocolate,roasted malt, and some molasses.Good balance between sweet and bitter.Very smooth mouthfeel.Dry finish.Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2007 Bottle at the Dellirium Cafe Goteborg.
Black colour and a nice brown head. Flavor is malty,dark chcoclate, coffee, and a nice alc biter finish. Medium body,medium finish.
Greate beer.Earlier Rating: 5/2/2007 Total Score: 4Bottle: February 2006. Thanks to Rickgordon:
Deep red colour, with a nice head.
Aroma of dark Chocolate, and a nice bitter/Alc end.
Flavor is Dark chocolate,tar,burned coffee beans.Nice medium body, nice medium finish.

Bottle.  Poured with a very thick, mousse-like head.  Color is comparable to Coca-Cola without all the bubbles.  Dark chocolate and coffee notes to the aroma, and the flavor. Slighty roasted taste.  Sweet, but not too sweet, with a bitterness at the end.  I can see why this is considered a good choice for a winter beer - it does have a warming effect.  A very good beer - I would like to have another!
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 12oz bottle. dark brown/black with a beautiful tan head. nice body. amazing roasted taste. good carbonation. really impressed

Bottle. Pours ruby-tinged dark brown/black with a pillowy tan head. Aroma is malt, dark fruits, a bit of port character, some roast, and floral hints. Flavor is robust and complex, with dark fruits and semi-sweet roasted malt dominating, an earthy middle with a little alcohol warmth, and a lingering finish. Velvety mouthfeel. This beer is excellent and well deserving of its reputation.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2007 (12 oz bottle) transluscent dark brown/black with tan head.  burnt carmel flavor, some coffee like dimensions.  the beauty of this one is in the palate.  tight carbonation and light malt accents the flavor extremely well and makes for a crisp but dynamic taste. its got all the depth of a stout or porter but remains refreshing and drinkable.

The Blackest Ruby Color... Dark, Frothy, Carmel Colored Head slowly melted into the glass.  After the first taste, the Palate is what impressed me... velvety is the right word.  Very easy and light on the palate.  Drink this beer warm.  Great Roasted Malt Taste.  Light overtones of citris.  Ummmmmm...  Ill have another very enjoyable.  Another Great Victory For Volgon and NuggetL.

Dark brown beer with creamy hat of mousse. Roasted malt aromas of epresso and dark chocolate, with more of the same in the flavor. Im most struck by the incredible balance in this beer, just marvelling at how neither the sweetness nor bitterness ever wins out over the other, both eneveloped in that malty haze. Slightly dry finish. Superb.

Dark and quite malty. Medium head on pouring that soon disipated. Slightly sweet but not overpoweringly so. From other raters reviews I expected slightly better but nevertheless this was definitely above average.Earlier Rating: 10/9/2006 Total Score: 3.5Dark and initially quite dry.This soon leads to a sweet nutty maltiness. Very well rounded and pleasant without being outstanding.

Bottle.  Solid ruby-black in color.  Limited carbonation and head.  Smoky, roasted malty aroma and taste.  Two-part  body - smooth and sweet on the tongue that dries off quickly leaving a coffee/roasted malt residual.  Ive avoided picking up beers from Ayinger in the past . . . now I cant figure out for the life of me why.
Had it on draft in San Diego, The best beer i drunk over there. Was in San Diego for 3 days. Just was not feeling ok
Very dark amber with a big tan head. Caramel malt aroma. Sweet malt, caramel, and nutty flavors. Sweet syrupy finish.

Cold 11.2oz bottle:  Pours a dark reddish copper color with a big persistent creamy tan head.  Aroma is of dark roasted malts, coffee, earth with notes of smoke, chocolate and alcohol.  Taste is of well blended roasted malts and earthy hops that is creamy and smooth going down.   Ending is clean with light chocolate notes.   Has a nice malty, smoky aftertaste.  *Comes with a toy prize!

11.2oz. Bottle
$2.99
Binnys Orland

Celebrator poured a crystal clear scarlet red with mahogany highlights shining throughout into my pilsner glass. A 1+ finger tan head formed on thepour that ended up fading to a cap of frothiness. The body looks great. Leaves patchy lacing that slowly slides back into the body. 

Smell are deep of lightly roasted malts and fresh baked bread. Theres a brown sugar sweetness that comes through as well. A slight boozy quality reminds me of rum soaked raisins.

Flavor is much the same as the aroma. Starts with a solid dose of lightly roasted malts. Sweet banana bread hits mid-palate, seems doughy. Finishes with a touch of sweetness, mild nuttiness, the roasted grains, banana bread and mild alcohol fumes. Very nice.

Body has a somewhat chewy texture and nice medium, smooth body. Again, mild alcohol fumes show up occasionally.

Good cool weather hearty brew. Easy drinker and very enjoyable.

Celebrator is a truly well made doppelbock that deserves the praise it gets. I will continue to revisit this winter favorite often.

2/22/07

Rated 10/25/06:  Great aroma roasty, bitter, and sweet not as dominant as the flavor but it holds its own. Deep ruby pour with a dark brown center, medium tan head and solid lacing. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth, unbelievabley smooth with a rich full finish. Flavor is strong and hearty. Roasted burnt maltiness with some light coffee and dark bitter chocolate and fruits. Easy to drink and very enjoyable, wish this werent so expensive or Id keep a few around more often.

On tap at Ayinger Speis und Trank am Platzl, Munich.  A lovely dark red-brown with a 3-finger tan/nearly brown head of dense foam.  Aroma of dark candied fruits, molasses, loads of caramel character and a slight chocolate and roastiness as well.  Taste is amazing.   Chocolate, prunes, and plums are predominant with a slight alcohol kick as well.  A slightly malty aftertaste and a very faint, pleasing bitterness.  There is an overarching non-cloying sweetness that pervades, with an innumerable amount of complex flavors layered on top.  Creamy, velvety smooth texture. Spent 3 nights in Munich, had about 6 glasses of this - no better testament to how much I enjoyed this superb beer.

Bottle.  Pour is deep brown with a nice ruby twinge to it.  Nice fluffy khaki head.  Aroma is malty, chocolaty and a nice roast smell.  Taste is creamy, with a nice chocolate sweetness to it.  The body is wonderful, big without being overpowering.  Finish has a nice clean dryness to it.  Overall, a very nice beer.
This is one of the best beers I have ever tasted.  Big, dark flavor guaranteed to please.  Rich and darker sweet flavors balance out a naturally classic flavor.  Highly recommended!

UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 On draught.  This is one of the top rated beers and I can understand why.  Pours a very dark mahogany with little head (perhaps we didnt get a great pour).  Very strong roasted malt and chocolate characters are present in the aroma and the flavor.  Silky smooth texture which made it go down way too fast.  A world class beer.

Draft - big aroma - full of sweet malt and dark fruits.  A beautiful color - deep garnet with a beige head.  It nearly looks like grape juice.  Big, thick mouthfeel.  The flavor matches the aroma, but with more subtlety.  An excellent brew!

Pours a deep mahogany with a nice frothy head that dissipates slowly.

Molasses, caramel and toasted malt nose.

Taste is exquisite. Perfectly balanced malt, molasses, and hops. Truly a joy. Its even better than Korbinian.

Mouthfeel is outstanding. Perfect carbonation, just fantastic.

Extremely drinkable, I need more of this.

As soon as you smell this, youll know its a great beer. Fruity, brown sugar smell, maybe a slight rootbeer smell. Coca-cola dark color. Sweet smokey chocalate malt taste, very nice. You may be able to taste the alcohol, but in a good way.  I am impressed overall and am looking forward to drinking this again.

The celebrator I liked as a double bock a bit more than the others. I do taste the breadish flavor. All in all pretty good beer for sipping on and with a meal. Holding it up to the light its a red/brown tint with a strong flavor.

Bottle from Wilburs poured into Celebrator-esque glass - Pours a DEEP brown with a 2 finger light brown head that left spotty lacing; Milk and dark chocolates, caramel, toffee, powdered milk on a wonderfully sweet and inviting aroma; Coffee, caramel, roasted barley, bread pudding with hints of dried fruits and chocolate on the initial taste; Roast, vanilla, whipped cream, doughy sugar cookies and an alcoholic kick on the aftertaste; Smooth medium-full body; Pleasant carbonation; Definitely a new favorite! Minimal bitterness and a very complex taste. Left me feeling relaxed and wanting more!

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2008 Pours amber/brown, medium off-white head.  Amazing huge fig aroma - very sweet and pleasant.  They should make aftershave smell like this.  Flavor is sweet and caramely with some lovely fruity overtones.  This punches the Spaten Optimator in the figurative vagina, but personally I am missing the esters of the amazing Aventinus.

11.2 oz bottle. Poured a very dark color with a dark brown roasty head. Smells distinguished with roasted malt. Didnt taste the sweet in the beer and was actually fairly simple tasting for a double bock. No distinctive  taste really, but a very drinkable bock which to me isnt easy to come by.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2007 $2.99 from Tip Top, a great San Deigo North County german grocery, butcher, and restaurant.  A great price for a top 50 beer.  Very thin head with thin lacing.  Deep black color.  A hint of skunkiness at first smell.  After a few minutes a nice mild smoky nose appears.  First sip is mild, slightly dry.  Nicely subdued roasted grains and chocolate flavor.  I definitely dont taste the sweetness that others taste.  Nice drinkable palate.  Probably best with some cheese, but by itself, hmmm.  Good beer.
Rich dark beer with an aroma of roasted malts and anise. Flavor is sweet and balanced, feels syrupy in the mouth, finishing with a mild liquorice flavor.

Nice freaking beer. Foamy off white head and a rich dark brown body color. Super smooth to drink and tastes like a more refreshing stout. Smoky finish is very easy to spot and the alcohol content is well hidden. A truly great beer.

There is a reason this is the bets Dopplebock - because its the best!  I have tasted many doppels (far more than I have rated) and this always comes back as my favorite.  Full palate of flavors - fruits, malts, caramel, everything you expect from a quality doppel.  The other that always tops out my list is Aventinus, but this one always seems to edge it out.  Superb.

Pours a very dark brown with a thin light white head.  Smells of big dark fruits, banana, berries, sweet malts.  Taste is sliky smooth, big dark fruit, a touch of some smoke, caramel, and banana.  Actually tastes a little bigger than the 6.7% alcohol would suggest.  Just a great representation of this style.  This and the Aventinus battle it out for my favorite dopplebock.  Mouthfeel is quite full with a nice sweet aftertaste.  Great brew.

Dark beige lacing head, dark dark brown in colour.  Smells slightly metallic, caramel, sweet malts.  Tastes similar, sweet roasted malts, smoky.  Thin body.  Plain aftertaste.  I think Im missing what all the hubbub is about on this one.
Bottle. Beautiful, rich, brown color with ruby tint in the light. Aroma of sweet, dark, roasted malt. Taste of dark malt and raisin and a hint of smoke. Excellent

Aroma of sweet dark malts, chocolate, fig, and smoke - a really wonderful combination.  Satin palate.  Taste like dark roasted smokey coffee and chocolate with hints of fig and a remarkable caramel taste to round it out.

Very dark brown colour, small dark brown head. Aroma has roasted malt, coffee and some liqorice. The flavor is malty and roasted, with some bitter coffee. Sweet syrupy aftertaste. Smooth and full palate, a little dry. A good doppelbock. Ill get another one of this.
(500 ml bottle) Malty, spicy and bit smoky aroma. Dark brown, almost black appearance. Bit dry, spicy flavor, brisk palate. Great winter beer with warming character.

A deep, dark brown brew with average head retention. Even though it is a completely different style, it reminded me of the Bells Kalamazoo Stout in its flavor profile. A quality brew that is frankly not very complex and a little too boring for my taste buds.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 What can I say that hasnt already been said about this world-class beer? For me the taste and the mouthfeel really held my attention. I have never before experienced such an amazing, dry, malt sweetness that is present in the finish of this beer. I actually loved the fact that I could taste virtually no hops. There was zero bitterness. The sweetness is the furthest thing from cloying, its amazing. Re-Rate: This is a fantastic beer that is near perfect in every way, however, now that I have had it several more times I wanted to adjust my rating. I had it at a 5. This is one of the best beers that Ive ever had, and its amazing how easy it is to find.
Dark brown color. Sweet carmel and roasted malt flavor, with no hops. Quality brew---but too sweet for me.

From tap (Bruuveri, Helsinki). Roastiness, liqourice, chocolate, coffee. Very dense and pleasant. No bitterness. Alc doesnt push thru. Very very nice bock.Earlier Rating: 11/22/2006 Total Score: 4.2Bottle 0.33 l. Re-rate (original 4.3): Dark brown, darker than the picture. Small disappearing beige head. Slightly burnt, caramel, but not too sweet. Smooth all the way, nothing feels wrong here. A bit on the easy side, but mostly flawless.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2008 Pours a dark brown color with a nice dark brown head.  Taste is big malt with roastiness as well.  Not too sweet.  Nice example of a dopplebock.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a beautiful dark-cola color with a thick light-brown head of micro bubbles that fades slowly and leaves great lacing.  The aroma is of sweet honey with a slight hint of rye bread. The taste hits with a sharp alcohol and hop combination that fades into a  tobacco and earthy finish.  There is a slight hint of malt, but the dry aspects of this brew dominate the endtaste and the mouthfeel.  This is a rollercoaster of flavors and feel.  As it warms, the chocolate and dark roast aroma and taste come through much stronger.
Nice complex roasted flavor with a very slight head. Excellent doppelbock beer, very drinkable.
On tap at Ayingers, Munich. Pours dark brown with a creamy brown head. Aroma is brown sugar and malty. Full body, sweet and malty. Notes of roasted malt, coffe and caramel. Very nice doppelbock.

11.2 oz Bottle-Pours a ruby red/copper color w/a very slight tan head & good lacing which lasted throughout the beer. Sweet malt aroma. Heavy malt flavor w/traces of nuts, roasted malt, & caramel. Rich full malt flavor. Good mouthfeel, full finish. Good sample of this style.

If you like malty, this is a great beer. Easy to drink, surprisingly smooth with a nice finish. There are still others out there, such as Optimator, but I like this better. I shared it with a few friends that are "beer rookies" and they were begging for more.

Draught at Panimoravintola Bruuveri, Helsinki (as Ayinger Winter-Bock). Very dark red-brown in colour with a creamy, fluffy pale beige head. Lots of caramel in the aroma. Some doughy malt and hints of liquorice. On the palate, it has fruit cake and treacle malt, tempered by a subtle tart bite  The mouthfeel is smooth and clean but not too sweet. Not a lot of body for the style. Perhaps a bit light, but quite tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 smells good, tastes really good. malty, chocolatey and smokey. rich and complex. wish i had more...8/4/7/3/17/3.9
brown, malt, chocolate, earth, delicious, brown sugar/piloncilla, coffee, vanilla, sweet with a dry finish, toasted nuts...mmm. rich yet highly drinkable mouth feel.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 [Rerate 3/25/08] Pours deep murky brown with a small fine film of head.  Intoxicating chocolate, sweet raisin aroma.  Delicious chocolate, very sweet raisin and dark fruit flavors, but mostly raisin.  A little bit woody, but the flavors are somewhat light, as is the body/palate.   Nice velvety carbonation though, and not incredibly sticky compared to other doppelbocks.  An excellent easy drinking doppelbock, but I prefer those with more substance to match the rich flavor.
12oz bottle, very nice carbonation with a malty taste, very nice to drink with outstanding finish. a new beer to judge others.

sweet medium bodied hard candy taste that is somewhat satisfying for a hophead (who always wants lagunitas). outgrew my interest in bock long ago. it is complex but you have to sip at it. thought the hop flowers would of course be more pronounced. the various malts seem a little muddled to me. a little fruity but that is not complex as i can tell .
Dark reddish-brown in color... thick tan head.  Full bodied but goes down too quickly.  An extremely easy to drink yet excellent brew.  Could be a great session beer.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2007 This is called "Celebrator"...but unlike some other ratings here...I didnt want to jump up and shout. Ill go ahead and save 2 bottles out of the 4 pack for a semi-special occasion though...lol

The standard by which all other doppelbocks are judged.  Im shocked by the level of darkness and body.  Almost as rich as a sweet stout.  So much malt but with the doppelbock kick.  A hint of dark fruits too.  This one is to be savored.  Optimator is better if your looking to drink in quantity.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 Maybe the 2nd best dopplebock out there-- I like Welt. Kloster Asam Bock a little better.  Have only had in bottles.  Would love to try on tap sometime.  This is the dopplebock that invented the style, and all others copy.  Big, malty, sweet without being too cloying.  A meal in itself.

11-9-2007:  On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  Didnt detect much difference on tap, but I had a slight cold.  Will hopefully try again this weekend.  Still think I like Asam Bock better.

03-02-08:  On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  Palate was pretty tired from beers at Piece.  But was great on tap-- nice and malty and sweet.  Very enjoyable.  And only $4 for 12 oz.-- beer of the month!

Bottled. Poured with a one finger head but that faded very quickly. Aroma has some fig, some prune. Flavor is nice and full. There are darker fruit flavors as well as a tad of vanilla. Good beer, I imagine this would be simply delicious on tap.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2014 re-rated 10/2014; from Bier-Bienne - hazy dark brown beer with a little beige foam; pretty toasted and very malty aroma, notes of caramel; full-bodied; quite sweet and without bitterness; a bit earthy and long malty caramelish and nutty finish

courtesy of oh6gdx - clear dark reddish-brown colour, elusive foam; aroma of caramel, wort and candi sugar; sweet and quite full-bodied, no real bitterness and a moderate caramelish finish - looks like a "caramalz"; a deception (3/5/5/3/9)Earlier Rating: 12/26/2002 Total Score: 4.2dark brown colour, nice head and a beautiful lace, strong malty aroma, toasted, buttery with notes of caramel, sweet, full-bodied, robust dry malty finish to balance the sweetness - a very beautiful brew

Pours with a thick light brown head. Strong bouquet of malt and bread. Creamy texture. Some metallic aftertaste, but not grimy. Sweet, but not as sweet as many doppelbocks. Flavor has some chocolate in it, faint vanilla. Lots of malt, has a smokey, roasted taste to it. All around, a great beer.

Bottle in Chicago.  What a great brew.  Balance is the word as malt blends well with fruity hops.  Alcohol is not over done.  Pleasant because it doesnt leave that syrupy aftertaste.  I can have few of these and never get sick of it.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Light and creamy with good carbonation and malty notes on the palate. Pretty damn sweet and sugary for a doppel. A little roasty at the finish, with the alcohol coming through, maybe even a little cinnamon in there.  Bocks aren’t necessarily my favorites, but this bock rocks!;

Should have let this warm up a little before I had my first taste. Very dark and sweet with heavy malt tones. Taste is a little on the alcoholy side for a beer that has a middling ABV. Not a session beer by any stretch. Great on this cold and rainy spring night. Havent had this in a while and will come back to this one when the weather gets cold again.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 15, 2014 Draft at the Ayinger brauhaus. Simply put this is my absolute favorite doppel bock.  Pours dark brown, with medium head.  Taste is sweet and malt and the flavor is almost candyish but in a good way.  Clean finish, just a great all around beer.

Aroma quite sweet, with a hint of alcohol stinging the nose.  Initial taste is sweet, with a molasses quality to it.  Finish is a more bittersweet subdued taste that lightly lingers. It seems that every sip brings out something different.  Not the easiest of beers to drink, but very good.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe, march 07. Opaque black with ruby hues and a big, dense, creamy light beige head. Aroma is chocolate, prunes and a slight smokey touch too. Full bitter chocolate flavor with some rasins and a biscuity end. Medium to full MF with intens maltiness but not cloying. Pleasant but short aftertaste. Excellent, solid doppelbock.

Aroma: herbs, thyme, mint??, flour, barley, sweetish malt, not that powerful, old-time, vaguely vinous, burnt sugar. 
Appearance: deep red-brown, beige head that shreds nicely. 
Flavour: mm...very good. Sweetish, very nutty, malty, lovely bitter and smoky, vanilla, mint. Fantasticly earthy. 
Palate: nicey soft and sprakling, fantastic. 
I love it! Very special.
I really enjoyed this brew.  Nice deep color with very little head.  Rich flavors, very enjoyable.

bottle.  dark plum color with lasting thin creamy tan head.  dark fruits, musky, sour malt aroma.  smooth fruity body with building moderate tartness.  rich roasted malts, figs.  clean tasting.  nice doppelbock.

Pours a beautiful dark brown color with a decent sized tan head, which quickly dissipates after a minute or so.  The aroma is pretty malty and the taste is as well.  I like this beer, as it seems to carry qualities of a good stout.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Dark brown with red hue when held up to a light....minimal tan head.  One word: SMOOTH.  Roasted malt, brief carbonated feel, then carbonation settles and beer is at its most enjoyable point.  Still learning about differentiating flavors, but one thing for sure...this beer is great!!!  Will make sure I have in stock for friends.  I agree with DragonStout..."very easy to drink."

Pours dark brown with a creamy looking tan head.  Aroma has that "meaty" German funk to it.  Wheat cloves, sausage, toast, maybe a light citrus but thats stretching it.  Everything about tasting this beer is incredibly smooth.  Flavor has a bit of caramel, toast, coffee, butterscotch.  Finishes on the roasty side and fairly dry.  Mouthfeel is pretty much perfect, but I think its actually better when this beer is cold.  Anyway, this is good, I can see why it has the rating it does.

Bottle. 12 OZ. Dark brown with a hint of red in there.  Frothy, tan head that never completely diminishes. Lucious, malty aroma makes my mouth water.  Flawless palate with near-perfect carbonation. Flavor starts out sweet and finishes with a smooth dry finish.  Gets better with every sip.
