330mL bottle. Deep brown with a thick tan head. Nice aroma with notes of cocoa powder, fruit and coffee. Deep malty flavor with chocolate, toffee and a little bit of hops. long lasting malt finish. complex, well balanced and enjoyable.

Pours dark brown with red hues. Thick and foamy beige head. Aroma is full of roasted malts, dried fruits and molasses. Full flavored beer here. Rich roasted malts up front, caramel, cocoa and figs. Finishes with a dry hop bitterness and good carbonation. Rich, smooth and satisfying. This beer has got it all!

Ruddy reddish brown body, oily looking. Ample carbonation sustains a dense light brown head. Fair lacing. Aroma is rich with molasses, sweet malts that are moderately roasty, lightly smoky/nutty and very complex and alluring. Also noted are subtle fruit flavors that include plums and peaches. Stunning array of aromas, yet altogether too light and buried somewhat underneath alcohol and bready malt. Flavor rectifies that with ample roast and sweetness, more interplay and expression of fruit character and nuttiness. A benchmark for good malty taste for good reason. Finishes moderately dry and lingering with molasses and fruitiness, smoke in minute amounts. Carbonation is adequate and pleasing. Palate is velvety, medium bodied, lively and has a distinct resemblance to toffee candy. Very rich and satisfying, while remaining soft and secretive. Ayinger is a world class brewing machine.
Like everyone says...great beer.  However, it arguably the best looking beer Ive ever seen.  An incredibly subtle red hue.  And a VERY cool bottle.
Pours a nice copper color with a frothy head.Easy to drink.FLavors of the hops and malts.Other flavors are too hard to pull out.The finish had some smoke and bitter.

This beer has a great smell to it. Smells like butter, and honey. It keeps me guessing is what I like about it. Also, the beer pours a black color, with little - to no head. In fact, the heads fades away rather quickly. Very creamy, but still not as thick as I would like to see it. I can taste a sweet caramel, but I am also tasting honey. I am impressed with the flavor, but the palate could be a bit thicker, and a tad creamier. It is in fact a little too carbonated for me. Cool design though. I am disappointed that the Ayinger Brand does not make, on average, better beers.

Pours a coca-cola color into glass with no head. No lacing left behind. Aroma is chocolate at first and then roasted malts. Taste is dark fruits and sugar up front. Carmel malts give way to roasted flavor and slight alcohol burn as it goes down. Aftertaste is primarily roastiness and alcohol. Good beer, not great. I do not have enough experience in the style to say how it stacks up to the competiton.

pours brown dark brown, almost black with a light beige head. Has a very earthy aroma. wheat, some roasted malts, and a light buttery smell, tastes like smoked wood earth, some hints of fruit some nice bitterness at the end as well finishes a bit dry. a quality beer.
This is a great beer, have tasted twice, and cannot wait to savor again. Sweet, no metallic taste, perfectly banded malt.  very mild hoppines, complex.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: Bottle. Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a small long lasting head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is full of sweet and roasted malt with a caramel aftertaste and mild hop bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel with a slightly dry finish. A great beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a red tint and small creamy head. Fruity aroma with a sweet malt backbone.  Taste is complex; chocolate, raisin, smokey malts, and dark fruit.  A bit thin mouthfeel, but a nice dry finish with a lingering bitterness on the back of the tongue.  Good beer!
From bottle, poured flat and dark brown in color with a large, frothy, light brown head.  I was coming off a cold so I didnt get much from aroma.   A very good beer with somewhat sweet taste.
Dark reddish-brown pour, medium tan head, scents of coffee and caramel. An excellent beer perhaps in my top 5. Sweet bottle too!

Bottle. Dark borwn pour with reddish tinges on the edges...yellowed tan head. For one reason or another Ive been putting off this beer for ages, perhaps because its always been around...perhaps goats scare me...I really cant pinpoint the reason. At any rate, some nice aroma of light chocolate come through over some booze soaked dark fruits, some bready caramel malt pulls it all together for a nice consistent aroma. Flavors of light roasted malt, a bit of smoke, vinous fruits, and light chocolate elements all seem to peer through...all fairly restrained to where one is not overpowering the other...this balance of flavor much like Westy 8/12 or Pannepot or Rochefort 10 has that balance that really shows the care that went into the beer itself. This element is why I think they stay so highly rated...because really its not a common trait. Rich body yet with a soft but present carbonation...boucing back and forth between sweet and dry and finishing both roasty and dry.  Overall a really well made brew, balanced but rich and full of dense flavors...a terrific malty offering.

On tap at Lionheart,Albany, ny $5 /pint.  Somewhat of a slight let down,only because it was slightly thinner than I remember it tasting from the bottle. On the otherhand, very drinkable and more suited to having more than one, than say Sam Adams 8.5 DB

Pours a dark brown with hints of red. The head is a tan small head that disapers quickly. Tastes of dark fruits, chocolate and caramel fill your mouth.  Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. This is a very well balanced beer.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Mediumed bodied, with a rich chocolate flavor. Hints of carmel, and raisins. Finishes with a malty barley kind of bitter taste. Very impressed with this beer.
chocolaty caramel aftertaste.  not so much head.  Thin dark beer.  Quite happy and maltlicious!

This had a nice frothy head.Color was a deep brown to black.It had an aroma of fruit liquor.It tasted of raisins,malt and some caramel.Finish slightly bitter.Palate was not to sticky.Just about right.It is well-balanced and worth a try.I think Ill go and buy another!

pours a rdeep rich slighty see through brown.  smell doesnt strike me much. has the taste of a stout.  very complex and rich.  roasted coffee throughout.  my area has been out of this for a longtime and im glad its back.
Near black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and dark fruit.  Full, sweet malty body with notes of chocolate.  Long smooth finish.  Very nice.

beer 58  of Summer 2006 Trip to Europe.  Consumed on 7/10/06.  On Tap at the Source, at the Brew Pub at Ayinger.  Ive always liked this beer, and in some ways its why my brother and I took a tour of a German brewery in German without understanding a word, in my opinion Beer is Universal, so words are just like foam that gets pushed off the top of the glass.  Anyway.  This beer is dark (in the context of germany) and has a nice bite.  Will re-rate next time I grab a bottle.
i have to say, considering the rating around here, im dissapointed.  Its tastes too much like an eku.  alcohol flavor and smell overpowers it.  still very drinkable.
I It was good, but not great.  Poured nice, aroma was pleasant, very malty (I like that) the taste was strong but not too strong.  Aged a bottle for another 6 months and this one was better.

Nice opaque black with quickly fading off-white head. Aroma is strictly malt, and not super-strong at that. Flavor is roasty and fairly dry and not particularly strong either.  Beyond being nothing special, this product is hugely overrated. $3

Bottle. Clear medium red / brown color with a average frothy fair lacing off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, burnt, chocolate dark, coffe strong, light yeasty, licorice. Flavor is moderato to heavy sweet and mderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. Very nice ;o))Earlier Rating: 1/20/2007 Total Score: 4.2Bottle. Clear dark brown / red color with a huge fizzy excellent lacing light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roated / burnt, brown sugar, alcohol. Flavor is heavy sweet, moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbunation is sift finish is ligth alcoholic.

Bottle. Very dark brown with a thick off-white head. Smells like coca and roasted malt. Head disappears pretty quickly. Very smooth, chocolate malt flavor. Seriously, like drinking a chocolate malt with alcohol added. Also, somewhat nutty. Short finish. Its good, but a bit bland after youve been drinking it for a period of time. Sorry, but I think its a bit overrated (100?).

Nice chocolate colored pour with bubbly tan head.  Very intriguing aroma...peculiar sweetness that has hints of raisins and chocolate malts.  Sweet chocolate-like flavor combined caramel malts lead to a hoppy aftertaste.  Very, very pleasant on the palate with some bubbly accents...a nice drink that goes down good and smooth

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2008 Bottle. Nose is sweet and sour, with some citrusy hop notes and light caramel hints. Pours a dark cola-esque brown with amber hues. Strong, steady brown head with thick heavy lacing. Extremely smooth palate, zero carbonation even though bubbles are visible in the glass. Flavor is malty sweet, chocolate and caramel, well-balanced and delicious.

Pours clear dark red-brown.  Aroma is cookies and carmel, leather and plum.  Flavor starts on the sweet side, malty, carmel, roasted malts and finishes the same.  Light to medium, watery creamy, softly carbonated clean finish.

Bottle poured.  Very dark caramel color with a large frothy head, tan in color.  Chocolate and coffe aroma.  Sweeter flavor,  Good but not great.
Cheers.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 I sampled this beauty poured from the bottle.  It had a smooth black color with a small foamy tan head, that clings to the glass around the edges.  The aroma was excellent, an impressive mixture of chocolate, coffee, and some caramel malt, all with a roasty edge.  Their were also some grainy hops, and I noted a powerful apple scent as well.  The texture was good too, with a bubbly, full mouthfeel that had average carbonation.  It had a sweet taste with a bitter, fruity undertone and a dry finish.  I had tried it a few years ago, and had some trouble drinking it, but this time I thoroughly enjoyed it.  It was a good benchmark to see how much my beer knowledge and appreciation has grown!  Perfect for any Celebrator!

12oz bottle (with the little goat dangler on the neck.)  rich darkest brown, tan head.  heavy rich malty flavor.  a great lagered version of a porter.  malty, roasty flavor. sweet finish and very balanced. full bodied.

Poured a dark dark ruby. Very clear. Slight head that did not last. WOW...This is a great great beer! Aroma reminded me of a red wine. Very dry fruit smell with slight hints of cider. Taste was beautifuly blended...The Hops and Malts work so well together. I tasted caramel, apples, raisins, grapes and even a slight coffee/chocolate taste...This one is a keeper for sure and worthy of the praise! OH, and how can you not like the little plastic ram that comes along for the ride???

Poured from an 11.2 ounce bottle into a pint glass, dark with a big tan head. The aroma was of malt and smoke. The taste was of hickory smoke, roasted malts with an earthy nose. Very smooth and creamy.

11.2 oz. bottle. Tart, lemony, dunkel-like aroma that is disappointing for its lack of strength and complexity. Pours a deep, dark brunette with an amber hue and a moderate amount of thick, tan head. Good, roasted, dark, German malt taste. Slight coffee-like bitterness. The flavors are subtle and improve upon multiple sips. Roasted coffee bean aftertaste. Medium body. Crisp, lively, drinkable, and refreshing in the palate. Ayinger Celebrator certainly is a good beer. It certainly is not even close to the best beer brewed in Germany, as it is rated by the users of this site. Heck, it isnt even close to the best beer brewed by Ayinger; Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel is a signficantly superior beer. Celebrator aint all its cracked up to be, but its worth a try nonetheless, and it does stand up well to multiple tastings.

One of my favorites of all time, which is a long time being that Im 19. Not much can be said that hasnt been said a thousand times. This is how a maltly beer should tatse. Its so drinkable. Clings to glass with 3-dimentional lacing. Worthy of its title.
This is a great brew.  Great foamy head, maple and nuts in the aroma.  Very clean flavor.  Lots of malts and some fruit notes.  I could drink a ton of this.

An excellent brew. Pours dark dark brown. Has a nice head, that is shaded dark. It is so dark you cant see through it. Has a very smooth flavor and a dark hoppy spice filled flavor. It is not quite a top level beer but a great non-abbey brew.

Bottle, pours like a warm coke, with same color and noisy foamy head, that dissipates down to thin covering, no lacing.  Scent is maple, honey, raisin and nuts; excellent aroma profile.  Taste is smooth and malty, with a clean dry finish.  Just all around good stuff!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 330 ml bottle, no date stamp. Opaque black liquid with 3 finger tan head. Aroma is at first metallic hop, not real pleasant, but changes to chocolate maple. Taste is ridiculously smooth, and palate is smoothest ever! Some chocolate and smoke in the finish as described. Nice little raisin taste; alcohol not evident at all. Man this is highly drinkable stuff.

Pours a dark deep brown amber that almost resembles coca-cola in appearance (a good thing!)  Has a ver large tan head that slowly descends into a 1/4 inch thick head that leaves ample lacing.  The aroma really struck me.  It is incredibly malty smelling, almost to the point of triggering an appatite in me.  This might sound really absured, but it almost has a hash (as in the food) smell.  Very different and very appealing.  Mouthfeel is slightly viscous, but not sticky at all.  Taste is excellent.  Dark fruits and maple nut upfront, with a maltyness that lighty wraps the whole flavor and lingers in what is a very gentle aftertaste.  This beer is complex, balanced, and not overpowering a all.  You can tell a lot of thought went into this one, and it is thouroughly drinkable and enjoyable.  Excellent.
UPDATED: OCT 13, 2013 Almost like some imperial stouts in the United States - very heavy (especially for the ABV) and with strong accents of dried plum.
Mahogany with large brown head. Smokey vinous malty aroma. Slightly viscous. Smokey malty taste. Not as clean as Paulaner Salvator.
pours brown with nice creamy brown head. has nice chocolate aroma with alchohol present. very complex flavor, chocolate, maple. velvety on the palate. very nice. will have again

Good bit of roasted coffee aroma to begin with.  Pretty serious dark brown color (poured in stein).  Smells a little bit like charcuterie, which isnt a bad thing.  Good hoppiness on the finish to keep it from being too malty.

Pours a deerp dark brown witha very nice tan foamy head. Aroma of coffee, must be the roasted hops. Very flavorful with many tastes....malt, fruit, coffee,sweet, not to carbinated, very balanced and creamy.

12bottle, pours very dark not like in the picture, with off-white head. nose is maple syrupy, toasty, and alcohol. ive never been a fan of the nose of this. flavor notes is slightly syrupy, maple syrup, nuts, toasted oats, and caramel. mild smokeyness in the finish. mouthfeel is full and rich. alcohol is well hidden. this isnt my favorite doppelbock and imo isnt worthy of top 50 status, its too syrupy and sweet, and isnt complex enough. however, i do enjoy the brew but wish it had a bigger hop notes and more alcohol drying out the sweetness a tad.
Seen this numerous times and finally snagged it. Pours prety awesome, dark amber with a solid  medium tan had.  Smell is very good. Very good taste and an overall great brew.

Bottled sample via my friend Trevor. Deep brown in colour with medium carbonation. Strong malty aromas with notes of caramel, red berries, toffee, and a bit of smoke. Flavor wise, the malt presence is huge, along with some roasted notes of coffee and chocolate. Theres a subtle note of herbal hops in there as well, which makes a nice contribution. It has an amazing body which starts off milkshake thick, but dries out nicely. Great stuff. I wish it was available here in Manitoba.

(heavy bottle)  Pours a tan head over an extreamly dark brown.  Aroma is of malt and sweet toffee.  Smooth water flavor dominates over roasted malt, smoke meat, and coffee notes.  Complex and smooth.  Good DB, but its no Optimator.

Pours a dark browned amber.  Nice sweet nose with hints of ripe fruit, caramel, and a slight somiky nuttiness.  Flavor is a wonderful balance of sweet caramel, toffee, raisens, and more earthy sweet tones blended in to a nice creamy mouthfeel.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: (33cl bottle) Clear, mahogany colour with a medium-sized beige foamy head. Sweet, roast-malty aroma with caramel, coffee and liquorice. Sweet flavour, full bodied with a smooth carbonation and mellow mouthfeel. Chewy malty, bready and moderately roasted taste with a complex spectrum of flavours (caramel, toffee, liquorice, coffee); almost dry, malty and slightly bitter finish with a lasting aftertaste. Very good, not too fat, not too sweet, well-balanced and complex Doppeelbock.
Thank you Walleye for suggesting this beer.  poured a brown hue with a light brown head.  Great flavor with no aftertaste.  Wil drink this one again.

Bottle.  Poured the color of a Coke, but only darker and thicker.  Head is small, tan, and fizzy, but settled quickly.  Aroma of caramel weet malt and vanilla hints.  Roasted malts are present in the flavor with some smokiness in the finish.  Very well-balanced and easy drinking beer.

0.5 l bottle. Dark reddish brown color with creamy tan head. Malty and sweetish aroma with licorice and toffee. Soft roasted flavor with distinctive licorice character and some toffee. Finishes malty with licorice and tar. Soft palate. Very malty and very clean.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 Draft in the proper Celebrator glass. Nice dark red color with small white head that laced the whole way down. Awesome malt aroma with a nutty/roasted whiff. Great body with some faint piney hop remnants. It got more complex as it warmed up as I savored each taste. (I was driving, could only have one) Best Dopple I ever had, for sure.

The color was a deep ruby/ brown.  The head was thin, light beige, and fizzy.  The flavor had a nice roasted element to it.  it wasbitter/sweet.  The palate was med bodied and carbonated.  The finish was bitter and raosty.

Full, heavy, heady malt flavor. Stays with you. 
Great for a cold afternoon.

Bottle at Stanlees in Guam.  Great find on this island.  Pours fairly thick with a dark body and a fizzy dissapating head that leaves a thin lacing on the glass.  Only a faint but rich aroma with honey, oatmeal, and vanilla.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Flavors of pine, nut, oats, nut, and an extremely vibrant aftertaste.  A thick yet watery palate makes for a great finish.  This brew is well-balanced with a great flavor and should be seeked out.

Pours dark, dark brown with a low dense dark beige head. Smells of molasses and roasted malt...also black licorice. Medium carbonation with a thick mouthfeel...smoky start, some malt sweetness (not much) and black bread....more smoke on the finish.

Bottle. Very dark brown with light brown head. Nice aroma of dark roasted malts, some chocolate and fruitiness. There is enough bitterness to balance out the complex and sweet malt flavor. Nice on the palate too.
This beer even though its not the first tastes like the catalyst to a true doppelbock.
bottle. dark brown color. large head. aroma of dark fruits. deep and malty. sweet with dark fruits.

It pours out dark brown, has a thick brown head that disappears quickly. It smells nutty and a bit sweet. The initial taste is somewhat sweet but finishes slightly bitter. Goes down smooth on the palate and tastes quite good. I can see why this beer is so highly rated. The only downside is the price.

This was a good beer, that I didnt realize when I bought it that it was so high on the list. It poured a dark brown with a light tan head. The ram that comes around the neck of the bottle make excellent christmas ornaments.
An amazing beer.  Dark brown with a caramel head.  Has a great fruity, smoky taste.

This is one great beer.  If only it werent so expensive.  I put this up wtih aventinus and optimator.  I go back and forth between which one I like the best.  Optimator is much cheaper where I buy cases, so that has become the favorite in my group of friends.  Celebrator is not so heavy as optimator and not as syrupy as aventinus, so I can see why it is rated most highly.  I think this is a little more fruity than the others too.  Anyway, try all three!

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2007 poured a very nice dark brown, an inch layer of light tannish head, caramely and malty nose, lightly carbonated and exhibits characteristics of a good porter...medium level of carbonation...goes down well.
pours aclear dark brown with a nice creamy head aroma of sweet malt cherries and honey flavor was sweet with dark fruit malts & raisin notes amazing taste very drinkable
Robe brune très foncée surmontée dune mousse beige en dentelle qui sestompe. Arômes de pain, de caramel et de malt torréfié. Saveurs de chocolat, de malt torréfié, dalcool, de pain et de houblon.

Pours red-brown with a small, off-white, mostly diminishing head.  The aroma is a very strong, dark malt.  It almost smells like molasses.  There may be a hint of herbal hops lingering in the back.  It has a medium body and a smooth mouth feel.  While the aroma provided malt, the flavor provides hops.  This is what was lurking beneath this malty veneer!  The bitterness is all that remains in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2007 Poured a dark brown, reddish hints; medium to large light brown head.  Aroma was malty, sweet, caramel, and fruit.  Smooth flavor with caramel malt, nuttiness, dark fruit; a mild smokiness.  A little hop presence.  (Rerated to 3.9)
Fantastic example of a dopplebock.  Very fruity and complex with a caramel smokiness.  One of my favorites.

Nice brown color topped by a huge head of rocky sudsy tan foam. Good head retention but spotty lacing. Delicious malty bready aroma – I smell fruitcake fig Newton, and maple syrup.

Sweet and malty, and dry and earthy at the same time. Flavors include plum, brown sugar, fresh dough and yeast, a bit of chocolate, and dry toasted malt. Medium to full body, good carbonation. I really like this beer, but the little plastic goats are now all over the house and my desk at work.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Very dark brown with a brown foamy head. Great roasted aroma.  Amazingly complex taste with sweetness and fruit.  Roasty, malty, nutty.  Just all around a great beer.

This looks wicked when you pour it, but thats all forgotten when you taste it. This brew goes down very easily. The taste is smooth and rich without overwhelming the senses. Definitely one of my favorite beers.

11.2 oz bottle.  It looks like Coca-Cola... with a small perimeter off-white head.  The aroma is dominated by sweet caramel.  You can taste bitter coffee and roasted nuts through a noticeable carbonation.  My fathers favorite beer.

Sample poured from a bottle at the Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio on 1/23/2007...

I remember this being very good, but I really need to get a bottle to enjoy by myself so that I can really enjoy and appreciate this world class beer...

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 Dark mahogany body with red highlights and a small tan head.  Some rubber on the nose.  Attack is a lot of figs and dates rolled in molasses.  Then a little sourness reminiscent of black cherries.  Sticky body with medium carbonation.  Gets a bit vinous as it warms up.  No hops presence.  This famous beer is considered the reference of a style that Im not very found of.  The name may come with fame, I hope that one day if become famous theyll call me a celebrator too, so much classier than party animal.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2007 Poured a dark brown with ruby and copper highlights.  The head was one finger of tight off-white bubbles.  Some lacing.  The aroma was sweet caramel with some dried fruit.  The flavor was sweet caramel rolling quickly into dried fruit (apricot?) and bitter nuts (almond?) with a finish that lingered and wasnt hoppy.  I found the mouthfeel a bit on the watery side.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Dark reddish-brown with medium head.  Aroma is very roasty with sweet caramel/nut essence.  Taste is very full bodied with roasted dark malts.  Bits of dark fruit and some hop tingle detectable.  Overall, a pretty damn good D-bock.
Thick frothy head. Strong nutty flavor.  Smooth and easy to drink.  Very nice aroma.  It definately smells better than it tastes.

Small creamy beige head. Dark red translucent body. Mild caramelly aroma with milky and wild berry notes. Extremely soft and smooth mouthfeel. Taste is deep licorice and caramel with wild berry notes. Faintly dry, milky caramel aftertaste. Very nice. Could drink any amount of this. (0.5l bottle.)Earlier Rating: 9/6/2005 Total Score: 4.4Small nice-looking dark-beige creamy head. Nearly opaque red-black body. Lovely deep sweet malty, earthy aroma. Huge, sweet taste with lots of chocolate and licorice; complex, yet harmonic. Fades into a simple, rounded finish. A beautiful beer; drinkable, yet too sweet and powerful to be drunk in any great quantity. Grows more dense as you drink it. (This rating sucks. I have to rerate this one.)

Pours a very dark brown with some really nice ruby highlights around the edges. Theres a one inch head that fades to a thick cap, and leaves behind quite a bit of lacing.

Smell; a little bit os sweet caramel with lots of dark roasted malts and a somewhat bitter coffee aroma.

Taste; just as the aroma implies, nice and malty. Theres some coffee, a light presence of anise, with a little chocolate with hints of caramel, and a just touch of some hop bitterness. Im more of a hop head, but when Im in the mood for malts this is a great one. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, and very easy to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Smells like red licorice, which is not a very good smell for a beer.  Very dark red with amber head.  Overpowering molasses taste, it smells a lot better than it tastes.  Tastes very little of alcohol, and has a long-lasting molasses aftertaste.
Pours dark with a big white head. Malty bread aroma with some dark dried fruity undertones. Taste follows aroma but is a bit salty. Salty? Hmm... Dry finish. Kind of an odd beer.

Nice Robust malty aroma, very heavy on the nostrals. Dark amber pour with white head. There was a bit of a roasted flavor with some hints of fruit (maybe blackberry??) and a dry sweetness going on in the aftertaste. All in all, quite delicious

From Bottle.  Dark pour with highlights.  Thick frothy white head.  Aroma was malty and bready.  Flavor was the same bready, roasty nutty notes, slightly sweet in the end.  Nice full body.  Smooth, easy to drink.  Very balanced.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 A dark black pour with a red hue when viewed wiith a lighted background. Taste of prunes and caromel. Very satisfying.
Medium brown in color with thick frothy head. Smooth and smoky but not overwhelming. Nice flavor thats well balanced and still unique.

Deceptively light mouthfeel, really more similar to a lager.  Of course the similarities to a lager end there.  Mine poured much darker than the stock pic, but the head is about the same.  You can taste the smokiness of the roast in its coffee notes, its also sweet, but not syrupy sweet, the notes of caramel and molasses arent as prevalant as a stout.  Its really suprising a beer so light to the touch can have a lot going on underneath.

Bottled: Aroma is intensiv malty with notes of nut, molasses and roasted malt. Dark brown color, big, brownish fluffy head. Flavor with a velvety, light thickly texture and a light sourly, tannin feeling. Flavor is although nutty, malty, sugary and light roasty. Fruity alcohol notes. Quite astringent end with a light roasty bitterness. Coffe notes in the end. A very fine brew, complex, well balanced.
Great doppelbock. Amber in color, and head that goes away somewhat quickly. Nutty malt flavor.

Bottle (330ml): Deep amber to mahagony coloured, rather quickly diminishing medium-sized fluffy off-white head; nutty, caramelly nose with a touch of roasted malt and a tinge of molasses with some dark fruit in the background; (malty-)bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied; dry fruity (with a touch of canterelles) finish with lingering coffeeish-bitter aftertaste. A very pleasant, because unusually dry, and well balanced Doppelbock..........

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 Let me count the goats.This is an outstanding dopplebock and I have saved the goat off every bottle . Page 32 MJs Classic beer guide and 486 to go. Glad I can buy this in Calgary now.

Pours a dark, almost purple color with a foamy tan head.   Aroma is banana, prune, and raisin with a rich, roasted undertone.  The flavor is very sweet and very strong, with more roastiness than in the aroma.  Flavors of raisin predominate at the beginning, while the finish turns roastier.  For all the flavor this beer has, its really easy to drink.  This is one tasty brew.  Definitely one to do again.

[Bottle from oh6gdx, cheers!] Rich mahogany appearance with a thick tan head. Deep, complex malt character, waves of roasted notes, chocolate, caramel, dried fruit, alcohol, berry fruit. Sweet upfront, big, smooth body leads to a dry finish.

From bottle, also had on tap.  Pours a dark reddish brown with large bubbles, that quickly settles down.  Nose is lovely brown sugar, molasses, and dark fruits.  Flavor follows with a nice smooth body.  Finish has just enough bitterness to compliment the sweet.  Rating weighted towards the tap version, at this is awesome on tap.
I picked this up on recommendation, and was not let down.  I especially appreciated the chocolate/coffee notes, and the overall smoothness of the finish.  This is my new go-to dark beer, by far!

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 Even when I was drinking Schaefer and Strohs there was the unmistakable quality of this brew.  Chumly and I first had this at Porters pub in Easton. He made a chess set with his little goats we collected. I have attempted to copy this benchmark bock with varried success over the years. The commercial description describes my experience.
10/22/07:  The maltiness of this brew is all encompassing.  Sweet and big on all angles.  The alcohol coupled with all the big mouthfeel and body make this medium sized brew seem like a godzill of a brew. Watch out folks this one hits like a freight train.
Served at Ayinger Brew Pub in the city of Aying. Not as trong in the taste as Id expected for a Dobbelbock but though it was a very complex and a bit fruity

A very good beer, but I question the full enjoyability.  Im no expert on bocks, but I think this one is sort of a ruler of them all.  Gorgeous look, reddish orange brown.  Highly malty sweet syrupy taste.  It makes me realize how much I like sweeter wheat beers or fruit(y) beers.  Top choice with meals.  ...hah

Pours a dark brown with reddish hues. The head is medium and light tan. The aroma is yeasty, sweet malt, and maybe some ripe fruit. The flavor is acidic, vinuous, yeasty, bread. I was wondering how a dopplebock would wow me and this did it well.

This beer pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is nice a bit sweet like toffee with a roasted element. Taste is more of the same with less roasted taste than the aroma would have you to believe and more subtle dark fruit comming into play. Little to no hops present but still a good beer
12oz bottle. Graet brew from ayinger. Deep Dark color with roasty coffee taste. notes of nuts, chocolate in this delicious doppelbock
Woody burnt caramel smell.  Tastes like coffee beans.  Very nice burnt coffebean aftertaste.  Very good for a dark beer.  Better than Guiness.

Aus der flasche @ Ayinger speis und trank, München, Germany. Served up in that lovely small dessert wine-style glass pictured. We had just left Hofbräu, it was late afternoon and it appeared we were the only people dining here. A shame as the food was as wonderful as the beer, and this monster here truly matches its 100 percentile.  Lasting, dense, inch thick pad of beige adorns it, amassing a wickedly artistic lacing as it recedes down the glass. Body a tawny chestnut, not exactly bright and quite dull without sparkle. Heady, spicy and thick nose of those sticky desserts my Nanna used to make me. Raisins, sultanas and prunes, layers of gooey caramel, hazelnuts, vanillin and cinnamon, and just a touch of  brandy. In the mouth it excites and enters every crevice all greedily invited by my taste-buds. Its body is medium, its silky, liqueurish, smooth and openly warming. Again the Melanoidins, those complex malt flavours that remind you of everything from crushed nuts, to savoury fruits, up the flavour chain to stollenkuchen and wood, this accomplished a mix that held me guessing and savouring at each slow sip. It peaks in back, woody, nutty and sweet with a big dose of peppery spices before trailing off to leave so much malt flavour lingering. Its perfectly balanced in whatever it did. A beer I knew I would enjoy and had to taste whilst in Bavaria. Moorish, ample, sweet, savoury, thick and just damn good. A lovely bock! (33cL, BBE 12/07)

(Bottle BBE 07/07) Aroma of Ayinger Winter-Bock is roasted malty, slightly caramel and licorice. Red brown colour, clear and brownish, small, more or less fully diminishing head with fair lacing. Roasted malty, coffee, licorice, slightly caramel and slightly bitter flavour. Softly carbonated and medium to full-bodied palate. Very tasty brew! 11/11/06Earlier Rating: 5/11/2006 Total Score: 4.2(Bottle BB 05/2007) Coffee, licorice, strongly roasted malty aroma with a hint of alcohol. Dark brown (slightly reddish) colour and average size, brownish, slightly lasting head with fair lacing. Strongly roasted malty, coffee, slightly licorice and slightly bitter flavour. Softly carbonated, slightly astringent and medium to full-bodied palate with hint of alcohol. Simply delicious! 18/01/07 (original rating was 8/5/9/5/17)
This is among the best dark lagers available. It never disappoints. Dark, Malty, not too sweet, nice head. Among the best beers in the world.

Very dark red, some tan froth.  Aroma is mostly rotten fruit, caramel, and malt.  Flavor is similar, with old/dried fruit and some spices.  Sweet, but not overly.  Heavy-medium body and very nice finish

pours very deep brown with some garnet high lights and a thin light brown head and brilliant
Aroma:... and then the treat begins.... very rich & melanoindin laden malt nose, deep caramel, raisins, figs and some chocolate
mouthfeel: medium body, the medium low carbonation makes it lighter, some creaminess and long lasting richness dominated by dry fruits and a background note of hop bitterness making the finish balanced and velvety 
taste: "like the sweet center of a truffle" a symphony of flavors with high notes of dark fruits complemented with complex dark malts from caramel to slightly smoky , dark bitter chocolate  to the ever present melanoidin and of course the perfect (slightly spicy) moderate hop bitterness keeps this malt symphony in balance.
overall: What an archetype should be... the complexity of malt flavors ranging from melanoidin (from a long boil???) to  chococlaty, & dark fruits (some nutty qualities more apparent as the beer warms up) take the center stage with the smooth moderate hop bitterness keeping this from being cloying... great lager ... incredible doppelbock... a must try .. especially on a rainy evening

Bottle.  Pours a dark, chestnut brown.  Very  nutty and chocolaty aroma and flavor with fruit emerging more and more as it warms.  This is the best dopplebock and lager of any kind that Ive had.  Be careful not to drink this too cold.  Wonderful.
Best doppelbock Ive had.  Everythings already been said about this one.  Seems to go for about $3 a bottle and it is worth it for a great treat.  Wow, I cant get enough.
Pours out a beauty. nice brownish redish color. Dark tan color lacing. Smells nutty, spicy, chocalty, and citrousy cherry. The aftertaste is malty with a citrousy crisp finish to it.
I am a big fan of Doppelbocks and this is by far my favorite.  Fortunate enough to have had on tap & bottled.
Bottled. Dark amber coloured with a small head. Malty and slightly roasted with notes of dark fruits and hops.
light brown head , nice mahogany colour, lotsa toasted malt and small hop aroma. tasdte is huge!! lotsa dark malts somewhat bitter finish

Bottle at Floods in Stroudsburg. Where have I been while this was out? Ive tried doppelbocks before but none of them smoothly balance out the chewy black sugar candy malt inherent in this beer. The carbonation is good and the beer has a nice dry creamy texture. There is an element of nutmeg and figs thrown in a very floral mix but ultimately the sweetness predominates over these minutely bitter tones.

Great doppelbock! Had this on tap at Sharp Edge Creekhouse and bought the glass with it. The aroma was sweet and spicy...the pour a deep brown/black with a nice thin tan head. The taste was spicy and almost chocolately with a smokey aftertaste that didnt linger. Very little carbonation and it may have tasted even better if it were warmer. Great German!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dark dark black-amber in color. Smell of malts, bread, chocolate, coffee and cream. Tastes of coffee with subtle chocolate and nuts. Very malty. Good dark brew.

Smells malty.  Taste of of bready, creamy malts, with a great full finish.  Full mouthfeel, the carbonation is just about right, maybe bordering a little on too much carbonation.  I like the little plastic dealie.  Outstanding beer overall.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 Deep garnet, oaky in color, pushing black.  Its head disappears within seconds.  Dark aromas of chocolate, and woods, especially oak, give way to a heavily malted flavor with a little coffee and a faint white wine.  Silky and vinous.  Needed quite a bit of warming.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2006 Poured a very dark brown color with a dark tan head.  Aroma is of a nutty maltiness and some sweetness and  spice, but overall is not intense.  Mouthfeel is perfect.  Malt dominates the taste, with a mild spiciness and burnt tones as well.  Excellent, but I expected this to blow away Optimator and it didnt.  The palate was better and thats about it.  Ive have to do a side-by-side sometime.

Beer #1750. And what a nice beer. From my start at ratebeer, this was one of the highest rated beers, its still in the top50. And although it is brewed not too far away, I never was able to get my hands on this brew. Thanks to John (jbrus), who just had it in his cellar, I was finally able to get a good taste of the German #1 brew. Clear brown color, short brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, oatmeal, hop, some coffee. Bitter taste, very malty, roasted again. Very good brew. But during the years, I think it is passed by some great Scandinavian and American brews. Still, a classic!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2006 Nice 11.2 oz bottle with a necklace on it.  Smells like buttered toast. Pours very dark brown in my steeler stein and is transparent. Initially very tasty with no offense to the tast buds.  After a while however a hint of bitterness shows thru.  This carries on to the finish where it lingers for awhile.  This is really good beer but from the ratings it has I expected much more - perhaps even something great.  Falls short in this respect.  Troegs Troegenator is on equal footing with this beer and is a little less expensive. Weltenburger dopplebock is much better.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Smooth as Fred Astaire dancing, strong like my USA, finishes like the rich kiss of my lovely wife with chocolate undertongues.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2012 Back in the early days of Ratebeer, at which 5 ratings was still sufficient for a top 50 notation, this beer was the only European brew in the top 50 i just couldn´t find anywhere. While apparently widely available in Northern America, this one was impossible for me to find in Europe. Over the years i´ve been looking everywhere, including Bavaria, but the closest i got was an empty bottle in some bar in Sevilla, Spain. But finally, jbrus had obtained a bottle and was willing to share (big thanks John!). Naturally, it would be very difficult for this beer to live up to its reputation. And of course, it couldnt. Without going into detail i can say that it basically has all features a German Doppelbock requires,  but i can not say it has any exceptional qualities. A bit of a deception, but on the other side, it ends a 5 year quest. Re-rate: Bottled from Biernavigatie.nl. Besides the hype, i must say this is still quite nice. The coffee notes, in the aroma, roasted malts, not overly bitter. Nice bock. Overrated, but nice.

Darker than expected.  Colorful, iodine stained head that did not last too long.  Brew had pleasant molasses aroma and flavor.  Initially the brew does not overwhelm, but then erupts into expected complexity.  Balanced and worth trying. I was not feeling the smoky dry finish, rather a malty sugary one.  Probably the top tier bocks.  Good quality from Germany.  I dont see it as a party beer, I see it enjoyed on a cold day with a smoky fire burning.

Bottled, UDRBG. Finally the Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock! With such high expectations this brew can only be disappointing. And it was. Offcourse stille a good brew, but no top50. I had better doppelbocks. Aroma of grassy hops and caramel malts. Clear brown coloured with a slightly brown head. Taste is sweet, malty, well balanced. A bit sticky and a bit carbonated.

Pours very dark brown with a rich yet bubbly tan head.  The aroma is thick and malty with a mix of toffee and chocolate with some vanilla and cream.  Medium / full body with some moderately sharp carbonation.  Taste is lightly sour, vanilla cream, milk chocolate, roasted malt and dark toffee.  The finish has some carbonation sharpness and more sourness.  I dont know the age on this bottle.  I thought the beer was fine that I had but a far cry from one of the top rated beers in the world.  Ill have to retry this with a known fresh bottle at some point.

Deep brown with a hint of garnet.  Bubbles in head and lacing are particularly fine.

Sweet caramelly malt on the nose.

Slightly less sweet in the mouth, with piney hops and a little bitterness to balance the malt.  Lively and mouthfilling at the same time, with a smooth, sweet finish.

Delicious and drinkable doppelbock, but I wonder if its worth the premium price.
Lots of smoke flavor. Aroma of caramel and smoke. Wood flavors. This is a flavorful and excellent doppelbock.
Aroma is of sweet malts and slight chocolate.Pours dark with medium tan head.Flavor is of roasted malts and a small hint of chocolate.Very smooth and finishes with a touch of hops.
Great doppelbock -- pours dark brown with a medium tan head, strong roasted malt taste, very nice rich full body.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Stunningly beautiful deep red color. Roasted, with a hint of ash, yet sweet and a little fruity aroma which rolls through the mouth leaving a lasting finish. No sign of the alcohol what so ever, deceptive stuff. This has been my personal favorite for years, and still remains on top.Earlier Rating: 11/12/2006 Total Score: 3.6As Winter-Bock. Very dark red, beautiful. Smells quite sweet, but the roasted aroma hides any sweetness in taste. Nice bitter finish. Very well balanced, Ayinger doesnt disappoint.
Aroma of grain and carmel. Dark brown with medium head. Taste akin to coffee and rye. Very good brew.

12 oz bottle. This is such a great beer, very malty and a great taste that lingers nicely. A slight roasted taste and smell that finishes with coffee. This is the one beer that I always pick up when shopping.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2009 Bottled as Ayinger Winterbock. (heres the old rating: 6, 3, 8, 4, 7 )The aroma is malty, a bit roasted and very metallic... Full flavour. Strong dark roasted hops in the finish. Hard to analyze. Foamy and nice though. Big disappointment. I have to try the draught next. NEW RATING: Dark brown /mahogany body, thick beige head. Musty aroma of mämmi, tar, liqurice. Full palate with a taste of tar, liqurice, some chocolate. Simply fantastic.Earlier Rating: 10/11/2006 Total Score: 4.1Bottle. Wonderful aroma! Nuts, raisins, rum, pepper. Aah... Dark red ruby colour, thick light-brown foam. Strongly roasted. The taste starts with sweet pepper, thyme and coffe. In the middle, some menthe and walnut joins the party. The finish is dry, oaky and strong. Manly beast!

Bottle (with the ever-awesome ram pendant). Pours a gorgeous dark brown / ruby color with an enormous head. Aromas of roasted malt, dates, raisins. Taste is similar with a bit of smokiness - perfectly balanced with a slight coffee aftertaste and dry, clean finish. Mouthfeel is rich and full and complements the flavor beautifully. One of my favorites.

Wow! My 100th review!  As I grow older the beers seem to go by much more quickly!  This doppelbock came to me highly recommended and didnt disappoint! It comes in a quaint 11.2 ounce bottle with white plastic ram hanging from a string around the neck!  A large 3 inch head rose to the top of my clear glass mug making fizzing noises and settling into a creamy tan head.  Aroma is a bold strong brew with wisps of roasted malt and fruity sweetness of dates and raisens.  Taste was full bodied and strong flavor of fig, dates and plums.  Flavor is laden with smokey roast malt and slight underlying teasings of alcohol & light hops.   Finish is coffee, malt and lingering candied fruit.  This was a complex enjoyable brew that is to be savored and appreciated for all of its ingredients.  As I closed my eyes and listened to my German polkas while nursing this brew, I truly felt as if I had been transported into my own personal  bier garten!  Prost!!
11.2oz - Red/brown with light tan head, cream and wood on the nose, licorice and wood on the palate.  The best balanced bock Ive had.

Toasty aroma and very malty, No hop aroma whatsoever. Slight alcohol and chocolate, munich malts are apperant. Flavor is ver rich and malty significant melanoidins and some alcohol strength and flavor, very toasty. Clean lager like character, a little sweet on the palate. Some fruitiness of Plum and grape, may be from boil down, noble hop flavor.
Deep ruby color

Beautiful color. Rich and silky on the tongue. Slightly sweet and malty at first, with a mild hop flavor in the end. Very warming, from the inside out. This beer deserves all the accolades it has received.

Beautiful creamy head and mouthfeel.  Slight smokey characteristic that blends with the malty sweetness.  Nice lacing on the glass and another sip leads one to find the subtle use of hops that are hidden underneath.  Rich, slightly complex and interesting.  A staple brew that is easy to find and will always be a welcome addition to my cellar.

12 oz bottle: Aroma is nice roasted maltiness, some dark fruit ( Maybe plums), chocolate, and a slight hop presence.  Appearance is dark and black with a minimal tan head that dissipates quickly.  Flavor is nice roasted malts, some more of the dark fruit, sugary, and a very light chocolate note.  Palate is bitter/sweet and great.  Overall,  This is a very nice Doppelbock and is worth every penny that you pay for it.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2007 Thank you beerded_one. Poured a deep amber (beautiful pour) small white head with good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and a hint of chocolate. Good smooth taste. Not much sweetness  like some dopples. Good dry after taste. A really good brew (excellent)

Got this beer in a four pack with little goats tied around the bottles. It pours a very nice dark color with very little carbonation and a thick head that can be styled whichever which way. It has a very rich taste, which is hard to describe. It is not quite as chocolately as a porter, but definately has a semblence of it. Coffee flavor is probably most dominant with a subtle tint of hops and all. Indeed worthy of its rating. Truly an excellent beer that can be enjoyed by all, bot just by beer afficianados.
A dark brown beer with nice carmal color head. Has a hint of vanilla in it and kinda thick.

Rating #200.  Dark brown pour with a small tan head.  Great aroma.  Its almost creamy: roasted malt, vanilla, sweet dried fruits, just a slight hint of hops.  Smooth flavor of faintly roasted malts, sugary fruit, and a dry, very slightly hopped finish.  While this tasted good and was very balanced, the flavor didnt quite match up to the aroma.  Still, a solid and easy drinking doppelbock.
Dark brown, with a tan head.  Very smooth with hints of vanilla and caramel as well as a creamy finish followed by a trace of bitterness.  Smell was plain to me; perhaps a cold is on the horizon.
Pours a dark brown with a thick off white head.  Great roasted malty sweet aroma.  Fantastic smoky roasted malts combined with great sweet caramel and some coffee.  Great Beer.
Dark brown with small head. Smells of roasted malts, nuts. Great complex taste with roast, malts, nuts, some dark cherries, some vanilla. Coats your mouth and just a great beer.

Bottle.  Dark brown, almost black, with a thick head that slowly fades. Lots of carbonation on the side of the glass.  The aroma is roasted malt, with caramel and chocolate.  Medium body, with a full malt flavor.  A little bit of hops seem to be there.  Better than the typical Dopplebock.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: From the bottle, pours a very dark opaque black with thick but non-resiliant off white head.  Smells malty, with some caramel and maybe hazelnut in there too.  Taste is very smooth and silky, initially malty and a tad bitter, toffee and alcohol flavors emerge in the aftertaste.  Its pretty good, but I dont think its necessarily a 100 percentile beer.
Dark brown bordering on black.  Thick malty nose with hints of caramel.  Amazingly smooth and balanced with just a hint of bitterness.  Wonderful creamy texture.  A new favorite.

Brown bottle, 11.2 ounces, trip to Beers of the world with Dum, Ian and Lubière, acheté le 26 août 2006; eye: dark brown with a nice coffee head, nice effervescence, lacing; nose: caramelized malt, roasted malt, bitter chocolate, brown sugar, alcohol, dark small berries, leather; mouth: bitterness, caramelized malt, small dark berries, finale in caramelized malt with a hint of pepper, mildly sweet, very lightly bitter, medium body, surprisingly thin, creamy texture, not much carbonation; overall: ok

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 11,2 onces, voyage à Beers of the world avec Dum, Ian et Luc, acheté le 26 août 2006; oeil : brune foncée avec une belle mousse café, belle effervescence, dentelle; nez : malt caramélisé, torréfaction, chocolat amer, cassonade, alcool, petits fruits foncés, cuir; bouche : amertume, malt caramélisé, petits fruits foncés, finale en malt caramélisé avec une pointe de poivre, moyennement sucrée, très légèrement amère, corps moyen, surprenamment mince, texture crémeuse, peu carbonatée; en résumé : correct

Dark brown pour with fizzy tan head.  Aromas of nutty sweet malt, fruit, and coffee.  Flavors of caramel, sweet malt, fruit, nuts, roasted coffee, etc.  Medium, smooth mouthfeel.  Pretty complex doppelbock.  Very good.
12 OZ. Bottle: Malty cherry molasses with a light cup of coffee and cream The fruityness is impecably complex and delicious. Dark honeyed nectar with a micro bubbled lacy head.
Wonderful beer.  Great color and aroma.  Flavor is sweet, but not overly sweet, and very complex.  A definite must-have!

12oz bottle.  Hazy dark-brown appearance; khaki head with large bubble formation, maintained around the perimeter; attractive lacing.  Aroma shows plenty of raisins, caramel and sugar.  Sweet, medium-size mouthfeel: plenty of caramel and candy sugar, raisins and roasted malts; a light, toasty quality on the finish, maybe some smoke.  I remember this being far more satisfying on tap.
Pours a black with creamy tan head.  Overpowering grape flavor.Sweet.  A little roasty. Chewey. Obviously a lot of people like this beer, but its not my cup of tea.

finally got a hold of this nectar.  awesone awesone awesome.  pours almost black with a thin wispy head.  rich sweet malty aroma.  awesome taste with a mouthfeel that coats your entire mouth and stays even after you swallow.  flavor gets better as the beer warms.  nice crisp lagerish aftertaste.  best doppelbock ive had by far.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: ah, ive been looking forward to this: love ayinger and this is the last of the top 10 accessibles i have to drink.  probably the darkest dopple ive ever seen, with a brilliant head that crosses maybe porter bubbles with stout color.  that may not mean anything, but in my recent experiences the porter bubbles are a bit bigger and lighter.  anyways.  actually initially smells of chocolate and a bit of bourbon.  surprisingly some alcohol too given the abv.  some vanilla... pretty damn complex aroma.  could be a little more pronounced.  haha, so much more flavor than the anchor summer.  cant let that bias me.  if it isnt already too late.  it doesnt have at all the cloying sweetness that made me dislike doppels like 6 months ago, but ive liked some since then.  this isnt really a doppel compared to my experience.  im gonna stick with the bourbon notes here, add in a bit of dark fruit.  alcohol, too.  i kinda thing this must be closer to 7.5% or a bit more.  a bit simpler a flavor profile than aroma, but ill let it warm up further.  hmm.  still good.  great palate.  having seen a couple friends low ratings of this beer, im glad it wasnt a letdown.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2006 12 oz bottle pours a dark amber brown with a nice sized beige head that laces all the way down.  As it warmed the flavors and aromas began to emerge more as chocolate, brown sugar, malt, and carmel.  Nothing too strong but very nicely balanced with a super creamy mouthfeel that is almost chewy and buttery.  The corners are rounded out with a few hints of smoke, spice, and alcohol.  A very well balanced and executed dopplebock but in being balanced it lacked the intensity and off balance that i was hoping for.

I love this beer, and its hard to add to what others have already noted.  I could come up with a ornate explanation of the drinking experience but its documented clearly.  What I can add is this.  Celebrator was so good that it started my wifes love of beer.  All she drank before were fruity drinks with umbrellas and wine coolers.  What better endorsement is there than that.  Its rich, fragrant, and without any hanging aftertaste.  Its excellent from the bottle or from the tap.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2007 Poured a reddish dark amber with a tan head. A very smooth texture, and an interesting aroma with lots of caramel and malt.  It was an incredibly easy beer to drink and had a rich stout-like flavor with a subtle hop finish dominated mostly by caramel and roasty malt. Nice wheaty and yeasty flavors. Very ciomplex and interesting, while still being immediately enjoyable. Reminded me of a stout with some more hops.  Id buy again but its a little expensive, being $2.75 for a 12 oz bottle.

12oz, pours dark with some some which dissolves quickly.  Aroma of vegemite.  Tastes very smooth, almost syrupy malt texture, balnced with light hop and finishing with alcohol notes, some bitterness lingering. Hops emerge more as it warms.  Nice.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a big beige head that dissolves rapidly. Aroma almost reminds me of eggnog, although roasted malts are certainly present. Syrupy lacing yields to a delightful amount of varied flavors - huge amounts of malt,  toffe, nuts, coffee, even fruit - all ending in a nice roasted dry finish. The Celebrator is milky and thick throughout, perhaps the creamiest beer Ive ever had. But, what I like the most about this awesome brew  is how distinct each  tone remains. Nothing is muddled here; each note remains long enough to please, but not so long that it bores or bothers. Complexity and balance - the perfect combination for a nearly perfect beer. Fantastic.

12-oz. Whats left to say about this beer after 1100+ ratings? Ill see whether I have any nuggets of wisdom to add. Huge moussy, almost fluffy tan head on top of a churning, swirling mahogany-colored mass of thick body and flailing bubbles--just a gorgeous pour. Big malty nose, acres of lace, thick notes of nut and caramel. Complex body thats mostly dark malts but bears up some flashes of herbal hop, nut, caramel, dark fruit, and, alas, some metallic sour on the finish. Amazing stuff, the finish notwithstanding.

Bottle.  Sultry, decadent aroma ... grape, red fruit, and massive loads of malt.  Vinous, sweet, molasses, prunes (and suprisingly strong!), earthy notes, brown sugar, and very light alcohol.  Very dark red  pour  (to dark brown) with an ephemeral light brown head.  Rich and seductive taste, vinous and surprisingly dry, light smoke and heavy roasted malt under the heavy fruitiness.  Surprisingly dry.  Caramel and dark chocolate also jump to the fore .. lots of flavor here.  An explosion of flavor, really, in all parts of the mouth and throat.  Toffee continues even through the aftertaste.  Full body, thick and chewy, dry earthy finish.  One of the most pleasant aftertastes around.  Slightly sticky lips, but theyre dry.  Much drier, earthier, chewier than the Andechser, as well as slighly hoppier...choice between the two would be based on whim.

It has been a while since I had my first Celebrator, but I still remember it. And thats because its a damn good brew. I think my tastebuds started singing the Hallelujah chorus when it first hit me. I feel as though it is thick on the mouth with a bubbling presence and has an almost roasted quality on the palate. It isnt an easy drinking beer, so I wouldnt be buying a sixer to enjoy in one night, but it is a brew I would constantly go back to because of its thick flavor and great style.

mmm smells liek prunes and dried figs and molasses and alcohol. lovley molasses color much darker than the pic. the taste is roast chocolate molasses prune. but a little thin in taste but this beer is pretty rockin
Very good Double Bock. Very dark with small head. Mild, smooth flavor and sweet aftertaste. 6.7% a.b.v.
Very dark body, brown and minimal head. Aroma light soy and molasses. A very good Doppelbock.
Nice beer overall - very simple in flavor and content. It was very smooth and heavy, moderate sweetness, not much hop presence.  I really enjoyed it and would pay the $2.99/bottle again.
Viva the Celebrator!!! dark carmel malt body with smoky finish with a touch of sweetness.  Have no expectations, not usually a fan of bavarian beers...i have changed my opinion.

dark brown with some ruby highlights.  Aroma is nuts and chocolate, with some sweet malt, dark fruit and alcohol working its way in there.  Taste is nice and chocolately, roast, with a light amount of alcohol and hints of smoke in its well balanced finish. the body is medium on this beer.  excellent doppelbock.

Lovely dark brown pour with a little bit of a foamy tan head and tons of dark and fruity aroma.  Im picking up scents of chocolate, dark malt, prune, peat, and maybe a bit of toffee.  Flavor is a wonderful blending of most of the above, but the peaty/earthy flavor really comes out of the background and carries the load.  The chocolate flavors are there in the finish and the dark fruits are there up front.  Really well put together.  All that and you get a little dangly domesticated animal thing that you can hang on your rear view mirror... such a deal!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Deep and dark, in color, aroma, and taste. The taste had a nice chocolate maltiness, with the right balance of alcohol presence, some bitter hops, and fruit (raisins?)

Generous foamy, frothy head leaving some bubbly lacing on the glass.  Rich, sweet aroma of malt, dark caramel, molasses, dried fruits (raisins, dates).  Complex, well-balanced flavors of malt, hops, dried fruits (raisins, dates), molasses, carmelized dark brown sugar.  Perfectly dry, somewhat bitter finish.  Not too sweet--perfectly balanced.  Theres a reason this is considered to be best example of the style.

Beautiful brown ale with a big head. Very subtle nutty, slightly grassy aroma. Head to breath deep. Flavor is malty and earthy. The alcohol hits you immediately and is strong, but not overwelming. Medium bodied, very smooth, clean finish. Slight bitter aftertaste of the side of the tongue. Great brew.

Bottle.  Pours a deep amber with red and brown highlights.  Huge, creamy, off-white head.  Delicious roasted malty flavor - a creamy brew.   Very balanced and very smooth.  A bit smokey with an easy finish.  Great beer.

Pours a very dark, a hint of ruby where the light can make it through, with a nice light tan head.  Wonderful rich aroma of chocolate malts, subtle hops and dried fruits.  In the mouth, its rich and moderately carbonated.  It starts sweet and smooth, with the same tones as in the aroma.  I found the commercial description to be quite accurate, including the "faintly smoky dryness in the finish."  Ive had this beer many times, and Im never disappointed.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark rich amber color with a fat creamy tan head. Aroma of sweet chocolate with a hint of fresh roasted malts. Taste of malt and dried fruit. It has a smooth dry finish that makes you want more.  Very good!
Wow, this beer is somethin special, pours dark with tan head. Coffee, Chocolate, and caramel flavor. Good notes, cant wait to get more of this one

12oz Bottle Pors out a Very dark Marron Color with a Nice crean tan head.
Caramel and some roast malts. Just a hint of hops. Very good. O Ya like the little bonus RAM.

Lack of a strong aroma brings the score down a bit but a very tasty beer.  Pours very dark brown with some red tints and a thick tan head.  Texture is nice and smooth though it sticks to the roof of your mouth.  Flavor starts out strongly of dark fruits like cherries and plumsthen melts into a nice subtle roasted chocolate in the finish.
Molasses toffee and citrus scents.  Creamy light brown head.  Dark reddish brown.  Flavor moves from sweet to bitter, good and complex.  Bitter lasting finish.  Creamy body.  Very enjoyable.

Color is very dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet and earthy - bread and spicey hops. Flavor is malty, roasted grain, toasted bread, well balanced with spicey noble hops, dry finish. Mouthfeel is just right - not too thin, not too bubbly, but not syrupy. I find them to taste better than Paulaner Salvator or Spaten Optimator.

Nice and smooth. You need to drink a few to really understand the complexities of this one. The only problem is that youll probalbly be out cold by the time you can right a review. Its hard to find any beer that your can call bold and smooth but this one pulls it off.
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2007 dark brown color; sweet malts, fruits and caramel; smoky; excellent brew overall.
Excellent Doppel bock. More intense flavor than spaten. great taste but cant drink more than two (heavy)
one of the best beers ive ever had.  the celebrator is packed with complexity.  a well-balanced beer; highly recommended.
Without a doubt, my favorite doppelbock.  Delicious blend of malts finishing with a whisper of hops.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2006 Nice black body with a  very light white head.  Good caramel and peet notes.  Caramel and light hops are present in the taste, light roasted malts as well.  Semi-sweet, dry ending.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2016 Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent fully lasting head. Deepbrownamber colour.
Ok malty aroma. Nice chocolate flavor. long finish. Not so creamy palate as expected.Earlier Rating: 3/17/2006 Total Score: 4Draught at brewery-restaurent. Fantastic appearence. Creamy light-brown good mostly lasting head. Brown colour. Very malty and hoppy aroma. Too many coffenotes in an otherwise fantastic taste. <long finish. Very oily palate. A great beer, but not the best german doppelbock!
Beautiful aroma, poured dark red.  Very strong chocolate/fruit flavor.  All aroud solid beer
Draft. Dark reddish brown with tan head. Malty nose with caramel, raisins, chocolate and fruit. Nice chocolate and malt flavor with hop hints. Great beer.

Almost completely black body with about a half inch tan head.  Smells mostly sweet with chocolate, caramel and just a hint of hop.  Tastes chocolate, with some sourness to it.  Nice and roasty.  Excellent.  Similar to Sam Adams Chocolate Bock, only better (and cheeper, at least to try).  Theres a distinct possibility Id get this again.  Its very good.

Bocks are not my favorite style, but I believe this hits all the right notes.  A nice sweet malty aroma and it poured a clear dark ruby with a tan head.  Medium complexity with a hint of raisins.  The aftertaste is very strong and hangs around for awhile.  Definitely worth celebrating.

Bottle - ... WOW.. AWSOME BEER.. i breezed by this one a few time in the store and saw it in Michael Jacksons Ultimate Beer book and said what the hell...Pours an almost black with a creamy off white head.. Very lovely aroma of sweet malt and fruitiness... the flavor is even better.. sweet caramel , fruits, roasted malt with a slightly bitter (slightly) finish.. very good for a cold December night.. even tho its 92 degrees outside right now..   19 out of 20 on me!!!!
awesome awesome awesome. its all been said before. i agree.  great solid beer for a celebration!!!!!!
Dark and frothy pour gives a nice full head that is manageable.  Surprisingly sweet but well balanced and a unique fruity malty taste.  A great smooth finish that rivals any Doppelbock.  A great beer

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 Pours a dark brown with a nice ruby highlight.  1 finger, quickly diminishing tan head.  Aroma is warm molasses, orange and smoky malts.  Sweet brown sugar & molasses flavor with figs and other dark fruit fading to a smoky roasted hop bitterness.  Nice medium to full body.
Has a great sweet smell.  Pours nice dark brown with a little tan head.  Very smooth palate, is not to thick, but still has a nice creamy mouthfeel to it.  A very good bock.

one of my favorites as well.
kept a few goats to hang from my xmas tree.
the big surprise is that my wife likes it.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 Bottle pours a dark brown with a tight tan head. Rich aromas of toffee, dark fruit, and caramel, with some roastiness. Nice malty flavor, with hints of the dark fruit and nuttiness. A smooth, slightly hoppy finish makes this a winning brew.
perfect amount of fruit added without making it overbearing.  very good finish.

bottle.  Aroma:  Bigtime malt aroma.  A little bit of toastiness, some light caramel, a hint of chocolate, and a good helping of grape and fig.  Also getting a little bit of a nutiness in the nose.  This is one I could bury my nose in all night.  Appearance:  Dark brown with some garnet highlights.  Head was light tan, big, and rocky.  Very nice lacing.  Flavor:  Deep malt flavor.  A little bit of toasted bread, toffee, and light chocolate.  Dark fruits come through, as well.  Some grapiness and the figs again.  Very clean flavor.A touch of hop bitterness in the finish melds perfectly with the residual malt sweetness.  Palate:  Full bodied.  Light carbonation.  Nice clean, dry finish.  Some alcohol warming perceived towards the end of the sample.  Overall:  I love a malty beer, and this one is awesome.  So smooth and drinkable.
A nice dark brown pour with nice tight carbonation that doesnt linger. Also a very nut and flavorfull drink. My favorite.
pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head.  aroma is malty with subtle hops.  very smooth, rich beer with multiple levels of flavor.  finishes dry with hop notes.  fantastic beer.

This beer is my all time favorite and must be drunk fresh, which is hard to find in the US. I have only found one location in my area that pours draft and this makes a dramatic difference. I was also fortunate enough to drink a few at the Ayinger restaurant/bar in Munich. This experience had me liking this beer even more as the flavors were so much more distinguished and was one of the most enjoyable things I have done with clothes still on. 

If you have never drank this beer and have had other Doppelbocks that you did not like, give this one a try, just make sure the supplier has stored the beer correctly and goes through enough supply to keep the inventory as fresh as possible. This beer pours with a dark brown head, if fresh will leave lace on the glass. Stop and smell the aroma as this beer seems to change character after each whiff. Flavor also does the same as it will have a nutty flavor during one tip and on the next a chocolate flavor dominates. Very fun and enjoyable drink with many characters in one glass.

Bottle: Dark brown pour, with a quickly dissapating light tan head. Aroma, toffee, roasted notes, dark fruits. Flavor, prunes and other dark fruits, some floral hops, roasty and dry on the finish. Deliciously smooth. Medium bodied. Ive only ever had this at a bar before, but with a chance to think on it, this beer really shines.

33cL Bottle. Effusive pour of tawny clear coca-cola, with a rocky rambling head of peach skins and brandy syrup. In the nose, a pungent deep dusky reign of nutty tannins blending profusely with glowing raisins and currents in a bath of pure cream. Alcohol and grain dust dance in a warm spring breeze and the barn door slides gracefully opened. Aroma subdued, but deep and explicit. Flavor is a blasting wind of creamed grains in a stew of fig juice and warm apple pie. Fusels are a little hot on the tounge, but bring a pleasent and lightly hoppy varied and muddled fruit. Im surprised by the heavier than average levels of hay smacking hops that bring heavenly balance to the beer. Im also taken a back by the lighter bodied. I expected a dense abyss of malty weight, but instead it retains drinkability. Theres a plane of processed character, where it lacks roughness in the edges. The melon heavy background glows. Overall, well built and nicely drinkable, but not a Top 50 for me.

Hey this is nice; a deep brown, opaque bdy with a large, light tan, creamy head.Well balanced, smooth and yet a hearty, roasted malt flavor. The hops come inat the end of the swallow, just right! The head lasted to the end of the glass.

Poured a very dark chocolate brown with a good-sized coffee tinted head.  Did not retain well, save for a few watery lacings.  Smell is of sweet and roasted malt.  Palate is creamy and fizzy.  Had I not poured the bottle myself, Id swear that it came from a tap.  Taste is sweet malt, with coffee, caramel and hints of roasted malt and smoke.  Alcohol taste is masked well but does lend a little warmth to the brew.  There is a subtle presence of hops in the aftertaste, just enough to balance the sweet flavors.  This is my favorite doppelbock thus far...

Had it out of a bottle. Smelled delicious as soon as I had the top off. At first I was a little disapointed because it had a rather biter aftertaste. However, as it warmed up, the taste became much better. While I prefer Belgians, this is easily the best German beer I have had.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2006 Very very good doppelbock. Dark Dark brown, almost black in color. Nice mild chocolate/coffee aroma. This is only the 2nd double bock beer i have tried, the first being Broken Top Bock. This one is very good, but has nowhere near the complexities of the Broken Top Bock. Very straightforward and malty. Quite smooth, roasted malt flavor. Some coffee,vanilla and chocolate, but all very underlying and not overpowering. Very balanced and not too hoppy. Could drink several of these.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Reputation certainly preceded this beer.  Poured into my Duvel snifter, I found that this beer appeared much the same as Coca-Cola when poured into a glass.  It looked like there was a great deal of carbonation seen on the bottom of the glass. Aroma was of vanilla, coffe, and roasty malts.  Flavor was slightly roasty with caramel vanilla flavors coming through most prevelant.  My one critique of this beer is the body.  It simply seems too watery.  I am not a huge fan of oily dark beers, but I do prefer a brew that doesnt feel like soda in my mouth.  Overall its pretty good and judging by the raves of others, perhaps I should give it another shot at some point.

Pours a very dark reb amber with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is imperial stoutish, with dark fruits, coffee, roastiness and a very slight hint of hops underneath it all.  Flavor once again reminds me of an impy stout, coffee, malts, dark fruits (prunes, plums), as well as raisins.  The image that appears in my head over and over is of raisin bread - not necessarily a bad thing.

Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, dark fruits, bit of coffee.  Flavor has a nice roasty malt taste, nice bitterness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is amazing, velvety and smooth, almost like a big stout.

What a wonderful brew. The Celebrator pours a black color with a very full brown head. The head stays around awhile. The aroma is fantastic, it reminds me of black licorice and coffee. The taste is very smooth--with an incredible mouthfeel. The flavors are of espresso and dark chocolates. One of the best tasting beers Ive had to date. A great finish, with lots of sweet malts in the aftertaste. I could put these away all night!

Pours a  chocolate  color with a nice light colored head .Nice aromas of roasted malt and chocolate with a hint of vanilla .Smooth ,full bodied with a complex flavor of dark chocolate .molasses and a hint of vanilla and fruitiness.This is a well crafted beer worth the effort of locating and having.
Deep amber.  off white head dissipates quickly.  malty aroma.  Smooth flavor with hints roast and tiny chocolate.  roasty bitter finish.  nice bock

(on bottle, thanx hopscotch)Deep brown, chestnut hue, steady white head. Exelent aroma of fresh made ryebread, vanilla and canemolasses. Great snif for sure. After a while, tasting began. Theres a plesant carbonation, fast rising, yet suttle. Taste is both rich and full, but the finish does turn a bit too coffeeish-bitter-burning on me. Has resemplents to a underfermented stout in that afterburn. Still a treat I waited for my whole rating career, thanx for sending it, Eric.
Pours a very dark amber/brown with a pillowy beige head. Aromas of roasted malt and a faint trace of alcohol. Full bodied taste with a little spicyness on the backside. Quality brew.

Pours a clear reddish brown with a lacy tan head. Full, syrupy body with fine carbonation. Taste of prunes, roasty malt, and a hint of smoke, like a really sweet sherry. Relatively quick, bitter finish.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2007 Pours dark brown with tan head. Has a sweet chocolate malt aroma, slightly roasty. Flavor is smooth malt character with slightly roasted chocolate & cinnamon flavors. Nice toastyness with a long dry finish. Balanced, with a slight coffee like spicyness.

Pours a three finger light brown head that fades quickly no lace.  Almost black color.  Light carbonation and heavy bodied.  Molasses nose.  Starts with a sweet molasses flavor, hints of roasted coffee in finish.  Great double bock.  $2.45 for a 11.2oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

Poured deep ruby with large orangish tan head. Smells roasty, caramel, little vanilla, little alcohol. Taste is sweet with some spiciness... maybe a rum cake with raisins, because the alcohol does make an appearance. Could be overly sweet if not for the perfect balancing hops in the finish. Ends smooth and smokey.
Bottle- first tastes are of chocolate and a smokey taste. Very easy to drink. One of my favorites!

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2006 Dopplebock, but is extremely reminiscent of a complex porter.  Pour is almost opaque... the deepest prune known (and only when held in direct light).  The head is quickly diminishing, creamy tan.  The nose is great.... country tobacco and sileage meets a roasted grain, with notes of molasses.  Beautiful complex flavors happening here....  Im picking up vegetables, legumes, dark tart fruit, roasted malt, smoke, and a hint of molasses.  The finish is dry, porter-like, and almost fruit and bean (like pintos, but certainly not disgusting)... everything in this brew is about effervescence.  Truly comforting, as it definitely reminds me of my younger years in the countryside.  One of the best beers Ive rated, by far.  Great!  I could use this as a comforting session brew, or a special occasion beer.  Very versatile, and VERY good!

I really like this-- from the smell to the finish.   It looks like Coke. It has very little head.  it has a fresh, light, grassy aroma.  The taste is light and nutty, with a light aftertaste.  Overall, light and malty.  Solid.  Solid.

On tap at the Brick Store Pub in Decatur, GA.  It was a dark ruby red in color with a good tan head.  The aroma was of smoky malts.  The taste was smoky, malty and very complex.  Reminded me of a porter more than a doppelbock.

Draft at Zenos.
Sweet, sweet aroma. Very dark look with decent head that stays. The real prize for the beer is the taste. Excellent balanced flavor. Almost taste like purple soda but not in a bad way. I think this is probably one of the best malt and hop balances in a beer Ive ever had. Goes down exceptionally smooth and is very drinkable. Cheeer! Cheers! Cheers!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 Pours a nice dark brown with a good sized head.  Aroma is all malt.  Flavor is caramel with a definite roastyness.  There is a bit of a hop presence which helps to round out   the flavor.  A well balanced and flavorful brew.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark mahogany under a tight creamy two finger light brown head.  Nice lacing remained.  Thick syrupy malt aroma, very clean, with notes of tobacco, carmalized sugar, and caramel.  Flavor is all malt again, with a thick roasty malt up front.  Finish is lightly smoky with tobacco and light alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate fine carbonation.  Slightly syrupy and cloying on the finish.  A good Dopplebock for sure, but not a top 50 beer in the world.  Then again, thats not anything that hasnt been said a thousand times before.

There is something in the aftertaste here that I dont like.  I was convinced that I had a bad bottle so I waited and bought more so I could re-evaluate.  I just dont like something about the taste that lingers....the first taste is chocolatey and creamy and I guess ok.

very dark brown with a few amber tinges, and decent sized long lasting tan head.    aroma is chocolate and carmel malt, with lots of dark fruits, and some molasses, some grape, cherry, toffee.
