Smells and tastes great - the best doppelboch Ive tried. Nice round malty sweetness  Sometimes the aftertaste bothers me a little, sometimes not.

Darker and stronger than the Doppelbocks made just to the north in Munich.  This sweet, malty, strong brew plays out with more caramel as well.  Not at all roasty, but with some fruit/chocolate mingling with the warming aroma of alcohol.  At $14 as six pack, I rarely treat myself to this brew, there are better and more interesting beers in that price range.  Still a remarkably well made Dopplebock.
Like the name says, celebrate and enjoy.

This is on tap at Ashleys, a fine multitap in Ann Arbor, Mich.  At first sip it reminded me of Rasputin - that heady, complex warmth of alcohol and fine dark malts.  But the tastes dampened as i went and the body weakened, taking it out of Rasputins league.  Its a beautiful, mysterious beer and Ill happily drink many, many more.

I was finally able to buy  a single of this and I may now foot for the whole six. I avoid dblbock at almost all costs. But, as this is a top 10 here forever; Ive been curious. I am glad that cat got killed. This is not like any of this style I have ever had. It is closer to a Belg. dbl. than one might think. A nice caremel roundness makes this beer and its malts jump. There is even a perfectly balanced hoppiness in this bottle.
This stuff comes on like gangbusters with a huge nose and a smooth but kaleidoscopic blend of malts.
Strong complex Chocolate/Malty nose.  Very dark, almost black color...Looks like I just poured a glass of Coca-Cola.  Sweet chocolate, malty, sweet mouth with a very distinct lingering aftertaste.
Definatly one of my top 10 beers.  Even if your not a dark beer drinker, youll still like this one.  More flavor and body that your mouth can handle.
Nice Strong beer, with slight hints of coffee and almonds.  Reminds me of a fine Belgian Ale. Definitely a must try if you havent already.

Pours to a deep black color with the vaguest tints of reddish brown. Light signs of carbonation are barely detectable, while an impressive light brown foam forms. Head retention is pretty weak. The aroma is slightly oily, with a deep malt fruitiness suggesting prunes, raisins and sultanas, with burnt caramel and a strong alcohol presence. 
The medium to full bodied palate , is smooth, dense and thick leaving a little chewiness, while there are very light signs of carbonation. The palate is richly flavorful and complex, starting out with a predominant malt of caramel and a wonderful dark fruitiness pretty much as I described in the aroma and some almond nuttiness. This is countered turning to a very well balanced burnt toasty dryness mid palate and a noticeable hop bitterness towards the end. The long lingering, dry aftertaste shows a stronger hop character as well as a significant alcohol warmth, while the sweeter fruitiness slowly returns. The longer you sip this beer the sweeter it seems to get, although not overly so as one reviewer I highly respect suggested. I also get something of a winey character as the beer warms.

This is a great full flavored and hearty brew, perfect for a late winter night. A must try.

Oh my, and to think the reason i finnally decided to buy this one over a few others was the little plastic goat....One of the best beers i have ever had the pleasure to drink, wonderful balance and oh so rich and tasty.
Manna...
Dark, Smooth, I liked it.  Sip slowly, enjoying all flavers & scents.
Nice,  malty,  smooth,  and not too sweet with a clean dry finish.
What a wonderful beer. Sweet to start with a suprisingly dry finish. A nice creamy head. I can see why it is rated so high. And I love the tassle on each bottle.

I wanted my 100th beer at ratebeer to be special, so I picked this one.  I was not disappointed.  Im not quite sure what flavors Im experiencing here (molasses?), but this is great stuff. Its A well crafted, smooth beer.  I didnt think i would enjoy the sweetness, but I do (i also enjoy the alcohol content).  Not a beer to have when youre having more than one, but still teriffic.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Excellent doppelbock.  You get a nice little goat with it, too.
great.
excellent!
Warm and malty with a certain smoothness to the mouthfeel.
Very nice strong caramel flavor, indicitive of the style.  long lasting finish.
Very robust, with tons of caramel aroma and flavor.  The fairly sweet, assertive malt is well balanced with the hops.  Powerful without being overpowering, and an excellent example of the style.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2003 Strong toffe and caramel flavors with a full body that seems to melt in your mouth, combined with a nice hop finish.  Simply fantastic, the best dopplebock in the world.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 Definitely well built, and gorgeous with its near black body and substantial Coke colored head. The nose is subdued toffees and yeast. Roast flavors of bitter cocoa and caramel.  Clean and soft mouthfeel and finish.
I dont see what all the fuss is about. Not the best dopplebock that I have encountered. Very dark but thin on the tounge and cloyingly sweet.

Thick, dark and alcoholic aroma. Thin head on top of root beer body.  Delicate Brussels lace clings to the glass like grungy cobwebs. Wonderful palate of soft and mushy  mouthfeel. Tastes has many notes, dark and earthy notes like currant or licorice. Alcohol is beautifully managed, I hardly noticed it on the tastebuds. Finish is slightly hoppy and very smooth.  Not nearly as sweet as I anticipated- a plus.  A very enjoyable drinking experience.  This was obviously the inspiration for Anchor Christmas beer.
a fine dopplebock!

great beer, the only reason i didnt give it a perfect score is just incase i die tomorrow and there something better in heaven. this stuff is simply awesome. the whole process from taking off the foil wrapped cap to your last sip is enjoyable. the only negative is the price and the fact that i have only found one place in my home town (buffalo) that sells it.
user_name: Almeter, The Aryan God of Beer

text: The only negative I can find is the prohibitively expensive price. This sets the standard for the doppelbock style; its main competitor, Salvator, doesnt hold a candle in terms of richness and/or chewiness. Savor this with a thick pepper steak, game, or after the meal.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2003 what a double bock should be, dark  malty sweet, rich and full bodied.
Cant really add much to whats been said. This is awesome stuff.

Very good, so many flavors to discover in this. My tastebuds were overwhelmed by the various flavors, so much so that I spent the majority of the bottle just trying to identify some. One underlying flavor is chocolate, the rest I leave to you to find. My only complaint is that it is slightly fizzy on the tongue, perhaps even too much alcohol taste. Still, a most excellent doppelbock.
I figured it must me good by the ratings, and I was not disappointed, it was everything I thought it would be and more.

Plums, figs, grapes...just a few of the flavors that make up the taste of this incredibly complex, delicious beer. Once poured and held up to the light, I was surprised to see it was almost opaque, with a very dark, cherry color.  Despite its high alc. content, there was nary a scent of alcohol.  Instead, I was instantly reminded of purple grape juice, with a hint of butterscotch. Incredibly smooth and tasty, I probably would have given this a 5, however I felt the carbonation was a little off. Nonetheless, I was quite impressed.

There are some beers that just cannot live up to the hype.  This is not one of those beers.  The appearence is incredible; almost opaque with a beautiful cream coloured head.  An inticing butterscotch malt aroma, and finally the flavour does not dissapoint.  A very smooth buttery malt flavour with hints of butterscotch and chocolate, but not overdone.  This beer is quite strong, but does not taste it.   Incredible smooth and satisfying.  Celebrator puts Salvator to shame!  Well done!!

This has to be THE best doppel on the market; I have to still evaluate the taste of this complex brew.  From chocolate to fig to licorice, just about anything is imaginable on the palate!  Excellent beer! (many thanx to THE BEER BARON for the graduation present!)
WOW! Chocolate, Coffee, Fruit, Malt....etc, etc. A very nice beer deserving all kinds of good adjectives

Sadly enough, i was not able to finish this beer tonight at the bar. However, that was due to a sudden stomach ache and not because i dont like this brew.  This has a nice dark color and malty aroma, and a strong, strong malty chocolately/toffee flavor. I think i may enjoy it more the next time. (Cool bottle as well)
It probably deserves a five, but at this point I just dont think that I can justify it, because I need more to compare it to.

I finally had this beer tonight and let me tell you it is the best ^$*&%#%(@^% beer on the planet!!  Nothing even can compare to this God of beers.  Smooth finish with an intense aromatic taste.  It has a beautiful dark color that has to be admired.  If you can find this, drink it now.  I was lucky to drink it on tap.  Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock is the best beer ever!!!
Holy malty.  I really like this beer.  Beautiful color, and a great aroma to match.

Wow!  The presentation is amazing - dark reddish-brown, great clarity for such a dark beer and a wonderful head.  The maltiness is overwhelming, yet very pleasant with the chocolate characteristics you would expect from dark malt. The aroma seems to be an extension of the malti, heavy character of the brew.  The mouthfeel on this beer is sensational - full of body and complexity.  Im not a big fan of the style, but this dopplebock had everything I would expect in great quantity.  Exceptional.
Excellent beer. Great appearance, great taste. Probably the best Ive had recently.

Much better than Spaten Optimator.  Mine did have a huge head, but it dissipated quickly.  Big malty, chocolatly aroma, equally wonderful taste.  Very slight hint of bittering in the aftertaste.  The bottle was neat too, it came with a plastic goat figurine tied to it.

Good dark color, nice hint of red when held to light.  No haze.  Not much of a head on this, but that is to be expected with this much alcohol.  

Malt and alcohol aroma!!  Nice Munich malt aroma.  Not much of a hop aroma, but with this that is to be expected.  

Malt sweetness upfront and nice alcohol warming in the finish.  I love the taste of Munich Malt!!!  No hop bitterness, only there to balance the sweetness.  

Nice mouthfeel, full almost chewy!  This beer has a huge malt bill and it shows in mouthfeel!

This is a world class beer!

Coffee and fruity nose, beautiful deep black color.  Pours with a fizz, but is not over-carbonated.  Not an exceptionally weighty head, and a lighter mouthfeel than would be expected.  Taste is sweet and warm.  Marshmallow tasting when chewed.  Wonderful stuff, this beer.
Excellent.  The aroma alone with its scent of choclolate and coffee is outstanding.  A wonderful beer.

A world class Dopplebock. Tons of rich, sweet malt aroma and flavor balanced so well with the higher alcohol content. One of those brews that you sip ever so slowly and delight in each and every mouthful.

Full of dark malt, chocolate and toffee flavours and  a long finish.Earlier Rating: 6/25/2000 Total Score: 4.6Reddish accent to the bright red body.  Thin, caramel head.  The aroma is gorgeous, an explosive liquid bread with rich accent of piloncillo, hints of roasted nuts and dried fruits.  Soft body is thick and supple.  The flavour is sweet molasses, tempered with an earthy rich bread character.  Subtle dark fruits underlie this.  A deep, long, dark sugary finish with a hint of bread crust.  If its fresh, its killer.
chocolate, coffee overtones (two of my favorites!) A heavy beer, great for the colder months.  All around excellent brew!
UPDATED: APR 9, 2004 The double bock to end all double bocks.  Truly worthy.
An amazing lager.  Chocolatey aroma and flavor.  Smooth and full bodied.
Pleasant chocolate aroma and very malty flavor.  Not quite as good as I was hoping after all of these reviews, but still a great beer.

Its easy to taste why this beer is so acclaimed.  Perfectly balanced, velvety smooth, you wouldnt guess the high alcohol content by taste.  Lovely appearance, too--evidently this its whats in all the mugs in every picture of Oktoberfest Ive ever seen.

An awesome beer experience. Get ready for malitness that will knock you on your ass.
This beer is BIG. Big flavor, aroma, mouthfeel, and alcohol content.  This is THE Dopplebock.
Ive had a few...but this one kicks ass! Rich, smooth, and intense.

Usually when a friend tells me about a beer Ill only try one at a time just in case Im disappointed.  This one came so highly recommended to me that I bought this by the six pack.  I must truly say, that I am not disappointed.  This is an incredible beer.  The way it tastes and feels on the palate is amazing and smooth.  I would highly recommend this to anyone just starting out.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2003 Dark and mysterious with a ruby-red hue. Dark fruit nose is complex, also very evident in the flavor. Rich, bold, and very flavorful. Alcohol is virtually undetectable, obscured by it's smooth body. Great level of carbonation. Huge, sweet and roasty malts. Lasting, chewy flavors with a rich hoppiness.

Delicious. While this beer has a higher alcohol content, I could not tell it until a few moments after finishing the second sip. It is SO smooth. Very delicious taste and smell. Everyone, even those who arent particularly fond of dark beers, should definitely give this one a shot.

This one really surprised me.  First that I could find it in Atlanta, secondly that I really enjoyed (am enjoying, 1/2 way through) it.  Very dark color.  Could not see any light through it, extremely dark.  Chocolately(?) taste.  Very malty, not very bitter at all.  Very thick and chewy.  Very pretty head on it.  All around really nice beer.
This is the perfect example of a German Dopplebock. Full bodied, rich, perfectly balanced. A great beer for after dinner.

My favorite doppelbock.  Very rich
and malty, almost like candy (caramel?).
Thick and chewy, but remarkably
easy to drink - goes down smooth.
Of all dark and heavy beers, this one makes
a great introduction to the style for the novice
(albeit in the sink or swim mentality).
It was my first double bock and remains my
favorite.
